CONTENT: We need deregulation and free permitting. building Codes are great and needed for public safety but then why is government penalizing citizens, owners and builders by charging them to implement safety codes. Makes no sense! Property taxes are already excessive and should already cover this expense and service to promote safety and avoid the need for people to dodge code or safety requirements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property taxes should cover safety code implementation instead of charging extra permit fees, which discourages people from following building regulations.
LABEL: private market deregulation

CONTENT: California needs to call in Federal assistance to manage the entire state. Too much of the forest is left unkept. Need to increase logging of old forest so that areas can be managed with planting of new growth. Open it up the private companies to manage.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies should manage forest maintenance and logging of old growth, rather than relying solely on state management.
LABEL: private management preferred

CONTENT: Please put as many power lines underground as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be put underground.
LABEL: Underground Power Line Advocate

CONTENT: An online system to report my insurance company for not following their own guidelines and policies for covering our losses that are clearly outlined in our contract.  I have to drive 46 miles from home to work post-fire when I had less than one mile drive pre-fire. My insurance adjuster says my wife and I should ride together when we work different jobs at different start and end time. They also state that we should not be eating out so much since we rented a place with a kitchen...we leave before the sun comes up and return home at dark and dont have time or energy to cook meals at home. This is not being a good neighbor as their tagline says.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company refuses to honor policy terms and makes unreasonable demands about commuting and meals, contradicting their 'good neighbor' promise.
LABEL: private insurance accountability

CONTENT: Listen. To. The. Insurance. Companies. When a business is reliant on predicting a property's risk of fire damage, and they charge exorbitantly to insure it (or don't insure it AT ALL), people should not be permitted to build housing there. Period.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies' risk assessments should determine where housing is allowed - if they won't insure it, don't build there.
LABEL: Insurance Dictates Development

CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas. Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies know fire risks, but government allowed development in dangerous areas. Taxpayers shouldn't subsidize high-risk homes, yet officials enabled people to build there.
LABEL: government versus private
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT:
Infrastructural changes are necessary. They are also incredibly expensive. Burying power lines throughout the city is incredibly expensive... who is going to pay for it? You need a more robust, dense tax base. 

These analyses of different cities have been done by Urban3, which reveals how tax revenue/acre increases with density. Greater density would easily help to fund the necessary infrastructure improvements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be buried for safety, but it's expensive. Higher population density would provide the tax revenue needed to fund these infrastructure improvements.
LABEL: taxpayer cost allocation

CONTENT: Others have mentioned the elephant in the room - home owners insurance in CA. This is going to continue to be a massive problem unless a sustainable solution is found. The reality is that most of the people I grew up will not be able to afford to return to the Palisades because they were massively underinsured. This is heartbreaking.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs in California are unsustainable. Many Palisades residents were underinsured and can't afford to return home after fires.
LABEL: Insurance Affordability Crisis

CONTENT: I cannot tell you what a nightmare it has been for those of us who have homes still standing to navigate insurance. Most of the information at town halls and webinars was for total loss, which is a more clearly defined insurance process. The rest of us were basically expected to go back into our toxic homes and had to fight like hell for every ounce of ALE and smoke remediation to be covered. We are so grateful for Ricardo Lara and his staff for their help putting pressure on the insurance companies, but it would be great if the agents had the capacity to offer more guidance and support
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies provide minimal guidance for partial damage claims, forcing homeowners to fight for coverage while navigating toxic conditions without support.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Accessibility

CONTENT: All debris must be cleared from all properties. It can be done privately but if anyone refuses or abandons their lot it must be removed even if a lean must be implemented against the owner and property. We can't have toxic waste that's both dangerous and unsightly to remain. Also, all the utilities must be buried underground. MUST. No exceptions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners should clear debris or face liens, and all utilities must be buried underground - no exceptions. Government must enforce when private owners fail.
LABEL: private infrastructure enforcement

CONTENT: Bury all the utility lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury all utility lines underground to prevent fires.
LABEL: Underground Infrastructure Public Safety

CONTENT: We should be considering discontinuing natural gas lines to neighborhoods that opt in for that.
LLM_SUMMARY: Neighborhoods should have the option to discontinue natural gas lines for safety reasons.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Safety

CONTENT:
Over the last few years, as a private property owner, I have received Brush Clearance notices for my property. At one point, I was substantially fined - although I had documentation my lot was clear. No matter what had been happening in my life (a parent passing, Covid, a sick child) I was required to clear brush on my property. Why isn’t the City, County, State held to these same requirements? 

I also think basic services that prioritize the safety of our communities - the police, fire department, schools, infrastructure - need to be funded first. We pay too high of taxes in LA and CA for these services not be available to residents when they are needed (ie; firefighters to put out fires, fire hydrants that work, etc)
LLM_SUMMARY: The city, county, and state should follow the same brush clearance requirements as private owners. We pay high taxes but don't get adequate fire safety infrastructure.
LABEL: public accountability needed

CONTENT: The money to do this should already be a part of all the money that is being paid into the state, county and city.  Why there is almost no funds or action in the past in this area does not make any sense.
LLM_SUMMARY: The government already collects enough money from us - they should have funds for fire prevention but aren't using them properly.
LABEL: Public Funding Required

CONTENT:
Regarding insurance claims and premiums, no one should have any issues at all with insurance claims. Insurance companies should be lowering cost and premiums vs. raising them. When it's a known fact that insurance companies have more money than banks and are collecting around the clock; I find it hard to believe that they are somehow living paycheck to paycheck. Besides, this is the business they chose. If insurance companies want to raise cost, they should be required to provide something more like free legal assistance for tenants and undocumented immigrants. 

New requirements before permitting building of homes and buildings, fire prevention methods and materials required before issuing any permits. City, County, and State level.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are profiting heavily but raising premiums. They should lower costs or provide additional services like legal assistance to tenants and immigrants.
LABEL: private insurance regulation

CONTENT: The behavior of the California Fair Plan to deny smoke damage claims is unacceptable and the lack of other choices for insurance is not ok. What can be done to bring insurance companies back to CA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning California is unacceptable, leaving residents with only the unreliable Fair Plan that denies smoke damage claims.
LABEL: Private Insurance Failing

CONTENT: The Army Corps of Engineers is doing a great job.  After the ACE has done it's job, there should be an additional step of testing for soil and water quality.  If the city can't pay for it, then it should be covered under the California Fair Plan "Ordinance of Law" line item.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance should cover soil and water testing if the city can't afford it after Army Corps finishes their work.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Support

CONTENT: Government at all levels should be held accountable for fire prevention along with what is being required of homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should share fire prevention responsibilities and requirements with homeowners, not just impose rules on residents.
LABEL: Government Accountable For Safety

CONTENT: We have specific questions about the California Fair Plan.  What construction features are covered under the "Ordinance or Law" item in the CFP policy?  At one point I heard Steve Soboroff say that everyone should hire an attorney.  I don't think that everyone should have to hire an attorney to get the fair benefit of their fire insurance policy.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't require homeowners to hire attorneys just to understand and receive fair coverage under the California Fair Plan.
LABEL: insurance access fairness

CONTENT: We need transparency and accountability from insurance companies, as well as from oil and gas companies. Insurance claims need to be met. Politicians must stand up to extractive capitalism. Yet we also do need to recognise that disasters are going to increase in number and scale. Life is uncertain and responsibility and accountability start with individuals. There is no magic bullet, just a hundred and one acts of daily accountability and learning to do more with less. Asking for specific ideas is great and thank you for doing so, yet what we are faced with is changing mindsets and learning to address our issues systemically. Corporations AND their shareholders need to stop driving the 'growth and increasing profits are forever' mentality.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must be held accountable for claims, but we can't rely solely on them. Both corporations and individuals need to share responsibility.
LABEL: corporate accountability needed

CONTENT: Underground utilities without delay
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities must be installed immediately.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Priority

CONTENT: I agree with the idea that there is corporate gouging and unfairness going on, because we all know this is happening, it's just the state doesn't want to put money into audits to catch and stop it from happening.  But I don't think the government elects (Mayor and Supervisors) need to manage something like this.  It would be like allowing the fox to watch over the hen house.  They already don't do a good job at their jobs, which is why we are in the state we are in.  So why give them more authority to come up with more projects, to give away more of our taxpayers money that will go more to waste?   I agree with the prior statement, let charities take this on if they feel the need to.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies gouge us, but government officials can't be trusted to manage utilities either - they already waste too much taxpayer money.
LABEL: private over public

CONTENT: Power lines should be below ground
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be underground to prevent fires.
LABEL: Underground Power Line Advocate

CONTENT: I've never understood why there are above ground electric wires in Angeles National Forest and Eaton Canyon specifically. The area is prone to fires! Get those underground or out of the park!
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would be safer in fire-prone Eaton Canyon. Why are they still above ground in Angeles National Forest?
LABEL: Infrastructure Safety Responsibility

CONTENT: MUST have underground power lines!  Its 2025 for goodness sakes.  The water systems are also archaic and are long overdue for an overhaul
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and updated water systems are essential, but who will pay for these overdue infrastructure upgrades?
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Upgrade

CONTENT: All the departments (local and state) need to work together. Hold utility companies fully accountable
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies must be held accountable, while local and state departments need better coordination.
LABEL: Public Over Private

CONTENT: We must not, under ANY circumstances, bail out SoCal Edison the way Newsom bailed out his buddies at PG&E after Paradise. Enough is enough!
LLM_SUMMARY: Private utility companies should face consequences for fires, not get government bailouts like PG&E did after Paradise.
LABEL: Private Profits Public Risk

CONTENT: Local residential electric lines should never have been above ground.  They should have been below ground from the start.  The literature on this is 50 years old.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would be safer, but utility companies chose aboveground installation despite decades of evidence supporting buried lines.
LABEL: Infrastructure Safety Versus Cost

CONTENT: More regulation of insurance and insurance companies. Too many people can no longer afford it
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies need more regulation - people can't afford coverage anymore.
LABEL: Regulate Private Insurance

CONTENT: The insurance landscape in California needs to be addressed. The FAIR plan is terrible, and private insurance companies take to long to process claims. There need to be faster ways for survivors to get access to funds after their home is destroyed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance claims take too long to process, whether through private companies or California's FAIR plan. We need faster ways to help fire survivors.
LABEL: Public Insurance Reform

CONTENT: Most everything now burned already!  What's more neeeded is making Edison and DWP publicly owned and managed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison and DWP should be publicly owned and managed instead of private companies.
LABEL: public utility ownership

CONTENT: This really equires the Mayor and Supervisors to create a list of projects and see which they can partner with the State and Federal Gov to reduce or eliminate corporate gouging and unfairness.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government officials need to partner with state and federal agencies to prevent corporate price gouging on infrastructure projects.
LABEL: Public Over Private

CONTENT:
Underground power lines, holding Edison corporate accountable, not letting Edison pass on their mistakes onto the cost of their customers. Every time they go into litigation or bills go up. 

When they need to shut off power due to weather - my husband can’t work. So he doesn’t get paid. 

The way palisades and Altadena need to be rebuilt needs to be smart. All street lights need to be solar, solar cross walks, a better environment and a safer environment for kids.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison shouldn't pass their mistakes and litigation costs onto customers. Power shutoffs prevent my husband from working and earning income.
LABEL: Corporate Accountability Needed

CONTENT: Both our electric systems and water systems should make more use of local supplies -- micro-grids for the electric system and water capture and grey water for the water systems.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local micro-grids and water capture systems should replace centralized utilities to better serve communities.
LABEL: local infrastructure control

CONTENT: What is wildfire adaptation? Fire-resistant design and preparedness training are not the City's role; let Angelenos, their architects, and private organizations do this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private organizations and individuals, not the city, should handle fire preparedness and building design.
LABEL: private sector responsibility

CONTENT: Don’t just throw this on the residents trying to rebuild manage the land that is prone to fire better
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies shouldn't push costs onto residents - better land management is needed to prevent fires.
LABEL: Public Land Management

CONTENT: Bury the utilities and mandate solar
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should be buried underground and solar power should be required.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Safety Mandate

CONTENT: Insurance is a key lever that needs to be addressed here, in service to the whole of the economy.  Insurance providers have known for DECADES about the risks they face with respect to climate, and as an industry, they have not acted with enough innovative approaches to changing incentives for more regenerative decisions.  They have not faced the truth of what is facing all of us with respect to climate risk, and they are brittle and wholly unprepared from a business model perspective to respond to the realities of what they are facing.  We need to redesign business models, incentives, and policies to face the realities of the calamities that we are facing as a community.  There is only going to be more of the same in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies have failed to innovate or prepare for climate risks despite decades of awareness. Their business models need complete redesign to handle future disasters.
LABEL: private insurance reform

CONTENT: This is essential and should be done by private enterprise to the extent feasible. Large infrastructure contractors can do this much faster than Public Works or LADWP and likely more cost-effectively. This is not the time for political egos to eye ad opportunities for the next election; move out of the way and let the city rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private contractors can rebuild infrastructure faster and more cost-effectively than public agencies. Government should step aside and let them handle it.
LABEL: private enterprise efficiency

CONTENT: Underground power lines are a necessity
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are a necessity.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Upgrade

CONTENT: *The first thing I would advise is to ensure that the CPUC requires AT&T to maintain its "carrier of last resort" status, which generally also requires them to maintain landlines. We have pitiful cell service in the Canyons-and 5G can't/won't fix that, as its intense network infrastructure is generally incompatible with rural-mountain topography and economics.
LLM_SUMMARY: AT&T must maintain landline service in canyons since cell coverage is poor here and 5G infrastructure isn't feasible in rural mountain areas.
LABEL: Public Utility Regulation

CONTENT: Power lines should be UNDERGROUND
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be placed underground.
LABEL: Public Underground Infrastructure

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Taxpayers shouldn't have to pay for rebuilding homes in high-risk fire zones.
LABEL: taxpayers oppose subsidies
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Power lines under ground please
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed.
LABEL: Underground Power Line Advocate

CONTENT: The CA Department of Insurance has put a number of excellent laws and regulations together that make dealing with the insurance providers somewhat easier for a homeowner customer. However the industry wide marketing of disaster (Homeowner)’insurance has led to virtually no polices promising to rebuild “no matter what” and substituting coverages that seem to fully protect and do not, leaving most homeowners underinsured which means they can’t afford to rebuild and can’t stay in their home because it has burned to the ground. This needs to be worked out with the insurance providers and the Dept of Insurance and the homeowners needing and wanting the protection of a policy that will help them in a catastrophe, rather than add to it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance regulations help, but providers now offer inadequate coverage, leaving homeowners unable to rebuild after fires. This needs better coordination between insurers and regulators.
LABEL: public regulation needed

CONTENT: I am very skeptical about how all these insurance companies happened to back out 3 months before these "wildfires" happened. I also had issues with State Farm auto insurance around this time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies suspiciously withdrew coverage three months before wildfires, raising questions about their motives and timing.
LABEL: Corporate Insurance Skepticism

CONTENT: California's insurance system requires a complete overhaul—it is currently more complicated than the tax code. This issue must be addressed in clear, straightforward terms before any funds are allocated. Otherwise, the same problems will arise during the next disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance system needs total reform - it's too complex. Must fix this first or we'll face the same problems in future disasters.
LABEL: Complex Insurance Reform

CONTENT: We could rethink home insurance entirely. Maybe it should not be managed by private companies, but by a government agencies. Natural disasters ARE different from an individual fire in a resident's home.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance for natural disasters should be managed by government agencies, not private companies, since these disasters are fundamentally different from individual home fires.
LABEL: public insurance management

CONTENT: Every home with a pool should have a pump that will allow pool water to be accessed! In Rancho Santa Fe it is required. Insurance companies should offer incentives.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should incentivize pool pumps for firefighting access, like Rancho Santa Fe's requirements.
LABEL: Private Insurance Incentives

CONTENT:
Admittedly don't know enough here. Eaton fire started well outside of normal pedestrian infrastructure.  Only thing I can add here is that given that good fraction of the community has to start from scratch, now is a good time to revisit infra related issues such as underground power and better broadband.

The water utilities I have less info on. They seem to have bounced back pretty quickly but obviously lessons learned from this one should be considered.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and better broadband should be considered now that we're rebuilding from scratch after the fire.
LABEL: infrastructure upgrade opportunity

CONTENT: I would like to see several well-publicized and documented rapid pilot programs in various communities in LA that help Angelenos understand the scope and disruption related to retrofitting old systems. Everyone wants to DWP, etc to "do it", and they absolutely must, but it would be great to understand what that looks like, how we as citizens need to willingly participate in the process when it's our neighborhood's turn, how this affects our bottom line and what kind of ecological and safety improvements this brings to our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: DWP must upgrade infrastructure, but we need pilot programs showing citizens how retrofitting affects neighborhoods, costs, and safety improvements.
LABEL: public infrastructure transparency

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: "Who pays for fire protection? Should residents in safer areas be taxed for wealthy homeowners building in obvious fire zones?"
LABEL: cost allocation debate
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. Put in sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury power lines underground and install sidewalks to improve infrastructure safety.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Upgrades

CONTENT: It is important that government provide assistance to protect individual people from illegal or unfair actions taken against them by insurance companies and/or landlords. Government should simplify the regulatory process of rebuilding but should not be using tax-payer money to issue grants for home building or for bringing existing buildings into compliance with new code requirements. Government should not be using tax-payer money to provide legal aid to undocumented residents; this should be a service provided by the private sector.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should protect people from unfair insurance and landlord practices, but taxpayer money shouldn't fund rebuilding grants or legal aid for undocumented residents.
LABEL: government regulation needed

CONTENT: We need to be proactive and clear brush/trash, bring back the brush eating goats and allow those that owe parking tickets to clean the freeways, like they used to. It should be illegal to start fires on the streets, public parks/forests (unless allowed to BBQ). Taxpayers should NOT be paying for the infrastructure upgrades of for profit electrical companies. When new communities are built, require power lines to be underground or have other safety measures in place that will prevent fires. Electrical companies can also educated the public and if they see something off with a powerline to say something.
LLM_SUMMARY: Taxpayers shouldn't fund infrastructure upgrades for profit-seeking electrical companies. New developments must require underground power lines or fire prevention measures.
LABEL: taxpayers oppose costs

CONTENT: Ensure power companies are being responsible and maintaining their lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies must properly maintain their lines and be held accountable for infrastructure upkeep.
LABEL: Private Company Accountability

CONTENT: The general public has no idea how emergency communications work, much less how ECC's & EM's are staffed, much less how easily overwhelmed 9-1-1 centers (with understaffed centers) are with floods of calls during events like this; and I could go on.  Clearly, there were failures in both the LA City and LA County responses in notifying the public.  Many fell back onto the Watch Duty app, which is privately funded and operated.  It proved itself to be a MORE reliable method of getting notification than from our paid city/county employees. LA should enter into a public/private partnership with Watch Duty, making it the single app to rely on.  For connecting with residents for resources, have your websites pre-made, ready to go prior launching.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private app WatchDuty proved more reliable for fire notifications than city/county systems. LA should partner with them instead of relying on overwhelmed public services.
LABEL: public private partnership

CONTENT: The experts in the insurance industry who assess fire risk need to share their information publicly.  A coordinated effort between the insurance industry, the emergence response planners in the government, and the builders could result in a much better system for everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should share their fire risk data publicly so government planners and builders can create better coordinated emergency response systems.
LABEL: public private cooperation

CONTENT: For those neighborhoods zoned as "very high fire risk", the city and/or utilities needs to also be held accountable on underground transmission lines, along with reviewing all city trees which are highly flammable and replace them (regardless if tress are "protected" or not), along with ensuring overgrown vegetation are trimmed back on our hillsides/mountain areas close to residents.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed in high-risk areas. Cities and utilities must be held accountable, not just for lines but also managing dangerous vegetation.
LABEL: public infrastructure responsibility

CONTENT: Army Corp and LA County systems need to be in sync. There have been many ROE's lost in the system, leaving us calling daily for status without answers. Also, lets be clear on who will be paying for debris removal, insurance or "free" as what many people are being told.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and government agencies need to coordinate better on debris removal costs and responsibilities. People are getting mixed messages about who pays.
LABEL: Public Private Coordination

CONTENT: Now is the time for Altadena to get sidewalks.  Let's future proof this community so that people can come back.  And while at it, bury the powerlines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Altadena needs buried power lines and sidewalks - essential infrastructure improvements that will protect our community's future.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Investment

CONTENT: It's clear that an inability to quickly shut down power contributed to the severity of the fire, along with exposed power lines. With the areas so devastated, it seems prudent for us to explore buried power lines to expand fire safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Exposed power lines and slow shutoff response worsened the fire. We should consider underground lines for better safety.
LABEL: Infrastructure Safety Investment

CONTENT: Insurance assistance in layman terms would be essential. We shouldn't require a lawyer to understand our insurance policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies should be written in simple language that everyone can understand, not complex terms requiring legal expertise.
LABEL: Public Insurance Accessibility

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies should handle building development - government regulations just create inefficiencies. Reducing restrictions would increase supply and lower prices.
LABEL: private market solution

CONTENT: Power lines should be underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.  Edison has become expert at deflection when asked about this, but no progress has been made.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison keeps deflecting requests to move power lines underground despite decades of public pressure.
LABEL: Private Utility Negligence

CONTENT: Insurance companies leaving the state is scary. Especially those able to drop coverage so quickly!
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning California and dropping coverage without warning creates fear about future fire protection.
LABEL: Private Insurance Abandonment

CONTENT: This right here. What am I investing this time and money in, if the property is then uninsurable?
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning fire-prone areas makes me question investing time and money in property that becomes uninsurable.
LABEL: Insurance Cost Burden

CONTENT:
Allow to build in an Off the Grid type of solar or wind power supply for a residential 
That way in case of emergency or heavy winds power can be shutdown without affecting a lot of customer.
Edison doesn't allow to be off the grid in the city that my understanding?
Allows us to build of the grid with a hybrid system not to depends so much on the grid.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison shouldn't restrict off-grid solar/wind power systems. Residents need independence from the main grid during emergencies and shutoffs.
LABEL: private alternative infrastructure

CONTENT:
Renters were the most badly hurt while landlords claimed insurance money.  

More education about need for renters insurance is needed.  Earthquake policy is available from the state for homes (landlords). Loss of use policy should be offered to all renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and landlords got paid while renters suffered. State should provide affordable renter insurance like they do earthquake coverage.
LABEL: public versus private

CONTENT: Edison should be responsible for this. Residents of Altadena should not have to pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison should be financially responsible for fire prevention infrastructure, not Altadena residents who are already paying customers.
LABEL: Private Company Responsibility

CONTENT: undergrounding power lines is not the answer.  want to see our rates go up by 3x with little benefit?  we need to realize that living in a high fire hazard zone means more power outages during high wind events.  We should be shutting off major power lines during these events.  back-up power should be widespread via dual fuel homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power outages during high winds are necessary in fire zones. Undergrounding lines would triple rates with minimal benefit. Homes should have backup power.
LABEL: cost versus safety debate

CONTENT:
The power lines in Altadena MUST BE BURIED. The transmission lines that run along the foothills must be rerouted. 

This Eaton Fire distaster cannot be allowed to happen again because a utility failed to de-energize the transmission lines.  That is no longer a tolerable scenario.  

The County, State and Federal Government must support this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines in Altadena must be buried and rerouted, with government support. We can't risk another fire because utilities failed to de-energize lines.
LABEL: public infrastructure responsibility

CONTENT: in general, the state needs to investigate the impact private equity companies have had on emergency vehicles and response. they own fire trucks and make it extremely difficult and expensive for fire departments to get modern trucks and comply with repairs. this was a huge reason the fleet was smaller than it should have been. their monopoly is ILLEGAL. but if the state won't enforce it then the laws mean nothing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private equity companies' monopoly on fire trucks makes it harder and more expensive for departments to maintain adequate emergency response fleets.
LABEL: public over private

CONTENT: Insurance companies are not going to insure anyone in the Palisades if there is not an explanation for the 1.7.25 failure to address the fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't provide coverage in Palisades without explanation of why the fire response failed on January 7th.
LABEL: Private Insurance Accountability

CONTENT: Provide aid to all infected. Homeowners and renters, total loss and uninhabitables. You pay into insurance to be covered for emergencies and if there are no emergencies, there's no reason for rates to increase. Even where there is an emergency, rates shouldn't increase. The system needs to be overhauled, along with FEMA. The lack of financial support has caused so many to be homeless.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't raise rates after emergencies - that's why we pay premiums. The broken system leaves disaster victims without proper support.
LABEL: public insurance support

CONTENT: Insurance is difficult to navigate and because it is a business, companies are doing everything they can to not pay out on claims. People who lost homes and were underinsured need assistance to close those financial gaps beyond additional loans. People need cash in hand to help with rebuilding. We saw the government response to supporting businesses during COVID with PLP loans that were forgiven. The people of Altadena need a similar benefit.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies avoid paying claims while fire victims remain underinsured. Government should provide direct cash assistance for rebuilding, similar to COVID business relief.
LABEL: private insurance inadequate

CONTENT: Where to start - a lot of people were being dropped by their insurance, and had a hard time getting other insurance. Some are uninsured or underinsured. People are having a hard time dealing with insurance. People need resources to know what proper fire related insurance coverage should look like and literally a how-to of navigating insurance if you have a full loss, partial loss, smoke.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are dropping coverage in fire zones, leaving residents uninsured or underinsured. People need guidance on navigating fire insurance and claims.
LABEL: insurance access challenges

CONTENT: Attention to contaminants should be a priority for the county's environmental health department. Not left up to individual homeowners. The long-term consequences are a community concern. Funding should exist for remediation if needed. Partnerships with research institutions. Programs to make whole house water purification systems cost effective. If building density increases to fill housing needs, standards for open space on lots. The county or city could buy lots put on the market to create publicly-owned green space.
LLM_SUMMARY: County environmental health should handle contaminants, not individual homeowners. It's a community issue requiring public funding and oversight.
LABEL: public infrastructure responsibility

CONTENT: Make insurance a non-profit industry. Nobody should be profiting off of disasters. Grants should go to ALL homeowners and not just to single family residents or people who didn't pay for insurance. Why limit legal aid just to tenants & undocumented residents? Everybody else needs legal aid to deal with the insurance companies. Plus, we could all use some free financial planning to know how we are going to pay for this perfect storm of  failed infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't profit from disasters. Legal aid and financial support should be available to everyone dealing with insurance claims, not just select groups.
LABEL: public insurance advocacy

CONTENT: Homes that survived the fires, but with smoke damage, fall into this gray area for $ coverage from insurance. There is no enforcement arm from the Department of Insurance to make carriers do anything. We have little guidance on knowing when it is safe to return to our homes or our neighborhood. Dept. of Health seems to be the only agency addressing this but again, no enforcement pathway from them to the insurance carriers who more or less want us back in our homes as soon as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies rush us back home with no clear safety guidance, while government agencies lack power to enforce proper smoke damage coverage.
LABEL: insurance enforcement gaps

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. DO NOT make the citizens pay for it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be buried underground, but citizens shouldn't bear the cost burden.
LABEL: Public Funded Infrastructure Upg

CONTENT: This is the perfect opportunity to bury all power lines. The cost of this should be shouldered by the utility companies and not by increasing fees to the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies should pay to bury power lines underground, rather than passing these infrastructure costs onto consumers.
LABEL: private utility responsibility

CONTENT: How much longer must the public die at the hands of private corporations? Enough is enough. Create public utility systems now. It will create more jobs and will (hopefully) be updated and cared for better than private corporations ever have. Also, make internet access a human right and also a public utility. To only have one option in an area means these private corporations can charge whatever they want. It's 2025 - the internet should be accessible to all. For managing our water systems - look to Tucson, AZ. They sequester more than enough rain water to last them all year. As droughts get worse, we must sequester as much water as possible, instead of having it wash away into the ocean. There are solutions, we just need to implement them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private corporations are failing us - we need public utilities that will create jobs and maintain infrastructure better than profit-driven companies have.
LABEL: public over private

CONTENT: For profit utility companies must be required to adapt their equipment to prevent wildfires, especially where human life is at risk in urban or populated areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Profit-driven utilities must upgrade their equipment to prevent fires in populated areas - it shouldn't be optional when lives are at risk.
LABEL: Private Utility Regulation

CONTENT: Eliminate the need for personal property inventory to get one’s entire personal property coverage! Studies show creating that list is the most traumatic part of recovery. We didn’t pay 75% of our insurance premium, why do we only get 75% of our coverage without being forced to do something so traumatic?!
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't force traumatized fire victims to inventory lost belongings. We paid full premiums but only get 75% coverage without this painful requirement.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Fairness

CONTENT: For those who are under insured, the gap to rebuild relative to insurance proceeds is very large. There needs to be some form of assistance for those who are on the CA Fair Plan.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance gaps are huge for rebuilding. People on CA Fair Plan need additional assistance to cover the difference.
LABEL: Insurance Affordability Gap

CONTENT: Require SCE to bury ALL power lines. Make utilities publicly owned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should be publicly owned and Southern California Edison must bury all power lines.
LABEL: Public Utility Ownership

CONTENT: Bury ALL power lines. No overheads. Ensure future safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury all power lines underground instead of using overhead lines to ensure safety.
LABEL: Underground Infrastructure Priority

CONTENT: Our infrastructure has been rotting for decades. It is absolutely essential that all power lines be grounded, reservoirs need to be doubled in sized and actually have water in them at all times!! Also the DWP needs to be liable for such failure. It is criminal
LLM_SUMMARY: DWP must be held liable for failing infrastructure. Power lines need grounding, and reservoirs need expansion - our systems have deteriorated for decades.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Accountability

CONTENT: Underground, underground power lines! 100%
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are the solution - no debate about it.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Upgrade

CONTENT: Bury the power lines… seems like fires often start with exposed lines
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be buried underground to prevent fires, but who will pay for this infrastructure upgrade?
LABEL: Underground Utility Advocate

CONTENT:
New homes to be built, could be solar equipped,  landscaping planted to minimize danger to structures, environmentally safe etc…
We need to lessen our reliance on power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Solar-equipped new homes would reduce our dependence on power companies and minimize fire risks through safer infrastructure.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Preferred

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and infrastructure costs in fire zones should be paid by residents who choose to live there, not taxpayers.
LABEL: Public Buyout Private-
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Underground authority needs to be given to the County/City so that there is not a statewide/utility/personal property owner fight over where these lines go. The political cost of comprimising will be prohibitively expensive and too slow to make a lasting difference. Reducing future risk of and to infrastructure should be priority #1.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines should be controlled locally by cities/counties, not utilities or property owners, to avoid costly political battles and delays.
LABEL: public infrastructure control

CONTENT: It's expensive to live in a wildfire prone zone. Either that expense is paid by the people who live there (such as through insurance premiums) or by everyone else who doesn't live there (via taxes). We shouldn't accept unfair increases in insurance premiums, but it's hard to tell what is really fair.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs in fire zones should be shared fairly between residents and the broader public, but determining equitable distribution is challenging.
LABEL: cost allocation fairness
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Must be open and transparent process with competitive bidding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities must have transparent, competitive bidding processes.
LABEL: Public Transparent Oversight

CONTENT: Edison must underground power lines
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison needs to put their power lines underground.
LABEL: Utility Infrastructure Underground

CONTENT: Utilities need to move fast. Should be incentivized with a reduced lawsuit if they move fast.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should get legal protection if they quickly upgrade infrastructure.
LABEL: private incentivized efficiency

CONTENT:
Private insurers are leaving the state. Fair plan is already at risk of insolvency. We cannot afford to have to rebuild whole towns - and DESTROY whole communities and culture. Insurers, the state and especially RE-INSURANCE co's have every reason to invest substantially to reduce the risk to near zero of fires that spread to any residential area in LA County. 

Every home at the perimeter should have subsidized water and retardant systems, detectors and a wide boundary around these residential areas should have thorough brush clearance (Goats, sheep, fairly paid incarcerated) to inhibit the spread of fire from starting conflagration - where hot burning homes ignite homes from high infrared, not even sparks needed. 

HUGE VALUE & ROI
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and the state must invest in fire prevention systems and brush clearance around homes - it's cheaper than rebuilding entire communities.
LABEL: public private partnership

CONTENT: Kill all lawns. We must change the culture of turf lawns and instead normalize the use of California native plants. They save on water, are already adapted to the environment, provide wildfire resilience, and support local ecology. It is scientific fact that a diverse population thrives - therefore a more biodiverse environment is more resilient to threats. Yes - brush clearance is needed, but education and implementation of native landscapes comes hand-in-hand. In terms of accountability - hold the utility companies accountable. Do not let them get away with their negligence. They must pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Hold utility companies accountable for their negligence - they must pay for damages and can't be allowed to escape responsibility.
LABEL: Utility Company Accountability

CONTENT:
Unfortunately, we are due for another one anytime.  
This is surely part of the reason insurance companies are fleeing the state.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are fleeing California due to wildfire risks.
LABEL: Insurance Companies Flee State

CONTENT: We've got to take care of our neighbors, especially the ones who had their insurance dropped in the months leading up to the fires with no good alternative. But for anyone who could get insurance and decided not to, knowing they were in a fire zone? They should be on the hook for that bad decision, not the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't drop coverage in fire zones without alternatives, but those who choose not to insure despite known risks shouldn't burden others.
LABEL: Insurance Responsibility Individual

CONTENT: Privately owned utilities need to be held accountable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private utilities must be held accountable for their actions.
LABEL: Private Utility Accountability

CONTENT: I see prior comments on all these proposed regulations-  at what cost?
LLM_SUMMARY: Who will pay for all these proposed regulations and infrastructure changes?
LABEL: Cost Versus Regulation

CONTENT: Waive unnecessary rules and regulations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Unnecessary regulations should be eliminated.
LABEL: deregulate private utilities

CONTENT: We have to hold power companies accountable
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies must be held accountable for their infrastructure and safety responsibilities.
LABEL: Corporate Accountability Over Privat

CONTENT:
Power companies should be required, to keep us informed, truly informed about the state of, equipment they are responsible for.
Consumers are hardly informed, regarding critical information, about the state of the infrastructure we rely on.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies must be transparent about their equipment's condition. We deserve to know the true state of infrastructure we depend on.
LABEL: public transparency required

CONTENT: We must have a more robust infrastructure that includes a publicly funded Watch Duty, up to date water systems, a reliable Emergency Response System, an accountable public utility that takes a People First vs profits first POV (undergrounding power lines)
LLM_SUMMARY: Public utilities and infrastructure must prioritize people over profits, with underground power lines and updated emergency systems funded by taxpayers.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Priority

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should invest taxpayer money to improve fire resistance standards in our communities.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Investment

CONTENT: Citizens are intelligent and will be empowered if government steps aside. They will find sources without government marketing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private citizens can handle their own utilities without government interference or oversight.
LABEL: private over public

CONTENT: Again, this would be great, but I predict it would get so tied up by various interest groups I almost would rather you not bother. Please just slash regulations, stop trying to control prices, and let people get to work.
LLM_SUMMARY: Let the free market handle it - too many interest groups would delay public control. Cut regulations and price controls instead.
LABEL: Free Market Approach

CONTENT: The free market can and will resolve personal and business financial and employment issues. Government should allow general liberty to work naturally.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private enterprise should handle financial matters without government interference - let the free market work naturally.
LABEL: free market advocate

CONTENT: If insurance wants to do any business in the state, they need to provide fire insurance.  However,  if a utility causes the fire, then the utility needs to reimburse the insurance provider.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to provide fire coverage in California, but utilities must reimburse insurers if they cause fires.
LABEL: Regulated Private Insurance

CONTENT:
Insurance companies had been moving out of this market, cancelling policies and raising the cost of premiums to the point of being unaffordable.

Rebuilding with fire, earthquake and storm resistant materials along with structure strengthening measures should be promoted as one way to help reduce insurance costs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are abandoning fire zones and raising premiums beyond affordability. Fire-resistant rebuilding could help reduce these costs.
LABEL: Insurance Costs Versus Safety

CONTENT: I'm so sorry you have to deal with that. Truly, my heart is breaking for you. Though I would ask you investigate the actual reason you have lost your coverage. Start by reading about the fact that California does not allow insurers to raise premiums by more than x%. This sounds nice in theory, but in reality what happens is insurance companies are left with no choice but to cancel coverage, as it is not economically realistic for them to continue providing coverage in increasingly high fire-risk areas without raising premiums.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are forced to cancel coverage in fire-risk areas because California's premium increase caps make it economically unfeasible to continue service.
LABEL: private market economics

CONTENT: Hold utilities and energy companies accountable and make them pay if they want to do business in this city. Build more affordable public housing with the purpose of ensuring everyone in the city has a safe dwelling and to reduce housing costs across the city. Protect our migrant community from violent federal deportation initiatives. Fund and platform grassroots campaigns (not non-profits and private businesses) that are speaking out on the pain working class Angelenos are facing every day.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities and energy companies must be held accountable and pay for doing business here, rather than passing costs to customers.
LABEL: public over private

CONTENT: Protect tax payers with services and systems that they expect to exist as a mandate
LLM_SUMMARY: Taxpayers deserve mandated services and systems that they're paying for.
LABEL: Public Service Mandate

CONTENT: They can pay a bigger portion of their profits to fund the rebuilding of homes and maintenance of high-risk areas. Also Southern California Edison has two lawsuits filed against them "alleging faulty power lines may have sparked the Eaton Fire" -NPR
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison should use more of their profits to fund home rebuilding and maintain high-risk areas, especially given lawsuits blaming their power lines for the fire.
LABEL: Private Company Accountability

CONTENT: The threat of not being able to insure our homes after this feels unfair and unjust. I have already been told by State Farm that they will not insure us after the 1 year mandate for standing buildings and 2 yrs for lost homes. We have paid our policies on time and for over 60years on lost home and 30 years for the apartment at Edgewaters'.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning us after 60 years of on-time payments feels unjust. State Farm won't renew after mandated coverage periods end.
LABEL: Insurance Affordability Access

CONTENT: The economic penalty must be severe so that utilities. invest in prevention.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities must face harsh financial penalties to force them to invest in fire prevention.
LABEL: Utilities Must Pay

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Public subsidies should help homeowners upgrade to fire-resistant roofing and building materials.
LABEL: public subsidies support
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: The State must ensure that property owners can obtain home insurance that offers full coverage as compared to the Fair Plan
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance shouldn't be left to private markets - the state needs to ensure homeowners can get full coverage, not just limited Fair Plan options.
LABEL: Government Mandates Insurance

CONTENT:
We need you to extend the mandate that insurance companies not drop us. We have always paid our premiums and this loss had nothing to do with any of the insureds. But we risk having fully uninsured homes due to the fires. 

People with standing homes need clear guidance on the safety of living amongst and near burned structures. We need financial assistance- so many people not within the burn map boundary are just as displaced and have lost just as much but cannot access aid because of the map boundaries which weren’t drawn to facilitate aid, but that’s how it’s being used.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Insurance companies shouldn't be allowed to drop us when we've always paid premiums. We risk having uninsured homes due to fires."
LABEL: mandate private insurance

CONTENT: I'm not sure how much difference fire-resistant design would have made.  If fire-resistant design means infusing building materials with toxic substances that will go up in smoke if the fire is strong enough, then I think that is misguided.  At least in this case, much more effort should have been put into putting the power lines underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison should have buried power lines underground years ago when people first urged them to do it.
LABEL: private utility negligence

CONTENT: California should compete with all forms of insurance in the state with a public option.  What we currently have are companies who effectively subsidize TV and other media with endless advertising yet will do everything in their power to delay and then deny your claims.  If the Federal Govt. is going to be less likely to pay-out (for one reason or another) in what would've previously been considered a disaster, we may have no other choice.
LLM_SUMMARY: Public insurance options are needed since private companies waste money on ads while denying claims, especially as federal disaster support decreases.
LABEL: public insurance advocate

CONTENT: We need better equitable contracting practices to ensure that the tax payer funds use for services actually have outcomes that benefit our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Tax dollars spent on infrastructure services should directly benefit our community through better contracting practices.
LABEL: Public Funding Accountability

CONTENT: Underground power! Although it's shockingly expensive. Streetlights need to be subdued to prevent light pollution.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed but costs are extremely high.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Investment

CONTENT: I was in a fire recovery support group, and hearing the stories of people waiting in lines for vouchers for 8 hours is a joke. Working class people don't have the time for that. Older people shouldn't have to stand in a line for that long. And the people waiting in that line weren't even all guaranteed relief! The whole day passed and people after the 400th person were denied. Also - of the people who received relief vouchers, they then had to go to a Walmart to cash them (which some employees didn't even know how to do). There is one too many steps involved. A relief voucher should be minimal steps. What if people don't have easy access to transportation? And why is the government relying on private corporations? It's just so dystopic.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government shouldn't rely on Walmart to distribute fire relief. The process is too complicated and inaccessible, making people wait hours with no guarantee of help.
LABEL: public versus private

CONTENT: I will not commit to rebuilding until I see a plan from DWP that includes Chautauqua Blvd, North of Bestor, in underground utility installation. This area has been severely neglected by the City: road in poor shape and not paved for about 30 years, power lines transversing my property from the pole to connect to neighbor and has not been updated for decades. Bad system for a known high fire prone/high wind prone area.
LLM_SUMMARY: DWP must underground utilities in our high-fire area. Current overhead power lines are outdated and dangerous, but the city has neglected needed infrastructure updates.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Neglect

CONTENT: Many people's insurances pulled out and now they are left with nothing. Steps need to be taken to ensure that people can get the money they deserve to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoned homeowners, leaving them without coverage. We need measures to guarantee people can access funds to rebuild their homes.
LABEL: insurance coverage responsibility

CONTENT: I'd want to see more of a push to get electrical utility owners to prevent their equipment for starting fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies need to take more responsibility for preventing their equipment from starting fires.
LABEL: Private Utility Accountability

CONTENT: Deregulate the insurance market, CA politicians caused this problem! Stand up for property owners.  It’s inexcusable that people can stay in rentals for years w/o paying and landlords have limited recourse. Businesses and families are fleeing our state
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance market needs deregulation - California politicians created these problems by over-regulating the market.
LABEL: private market deregulation

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: The state should subsidize required fire safety upgrades for rebuilding, or waive requirements, since homeowners shouldn't bear these infrastructure costs alone.
LABEL: public subsidize infrastructure
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT:
When a person calls their insurance company after a fire - you'd expect they'd receive an A-Z step by step "Here's how to file and complete your claim." Instead, they get "You're in a dark room, find the light switch"

The insurance piece of this is very complicated. But the claims part need not be. This is something where the Dept can make quick and substantive changes overnight. Force guidelines for claims to be clear and easy to follow.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Insurance claims after fires should be straightforward, but companies leave you in the dark. The Department should mandate clear guidelines for claims processing."
LABEL: private insurance inefficiency

CONTENT: This is a reality of California whether you believe in climate change or not.  Home owners should build back better. But also we need to hold utilities accountable.  In Altadena the brush near the power lines fueled the destruction. How that was allowed to happen is truly baffling.  Homeowners alone should not bear the brunt of being responsible for wildfire preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities must be held accountable for brush near power lines. Homeowners shouldn't bear sole responsibility for wildfire preparation and prevention.
LABEL: Utility Accountability Required

CONTENT: Yes on Firebreaks. Yes, fund community fire prevention programs that fire audit every single property and help property owners meet code -not punitively but to help them not loose their homes-. As for holding government accountable, they can start by answering why a for profit monopoly backed by taxpayer insurance is allowed to be the sole provider of a necessary service such as electricity and not have to upgrade their equipment, invest in monitoring tech, hire more employees and still run hi power lines over bone dry, inaccessible wilderness that borders one of the most densely populated mega cities in the country while being seemingly unprepared for well forecasted red flag events.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison, a for-profit monopoly, shouldn't provide electricity without proper upgrades and monitoring while running dangerous power lines through dry wilderness near populated areas.
LABEL: public utility accountability

CONTENT: We have learned, the hard way, that the California insurance industry to irretrievably broken.  Something has to change.  Homeowners insurance is a scam, it is too complicated, no one understands what their policies mean until it is too late, the carriers have inadequate resources to meet a huge crisis like this.  As best I can tell, the carriers are using the money that we paid them in premiums to hire people whose job it is to deny claims.  Some people need to go to jail to wake up this industry.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies misuse premiums to deny claims and lack resources for major crises. The system is broken and needs complete reform.
LABEL: private insurance failure

CONTENT: It's essential that we have a water system capable of fighting wildfires and an electric system that doesn't spark them, but the costs shouldn't be borne by utility customers in safer areas. Pay for wildfire upgrades to this infrastructure using higher property taxes on the homeowners who chose to buy and build in dangerous areas. If you want to take the risk by choosing to live in wildfire zones, you'd better pay for it. That would also help people better understand the tradeoffs they're making.
LLM_SUMMARY: Higher property taxes on homeowners in fire-prone areas should fund infrastructure upgrades, not utility customers in safer zones who didn't choose those risks.
LABEL: costs versus responsibility
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: This is super important, and I would recommend bringing in a private company to make sure it is actually done effectively.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies should manage this because they would handle it more effectively.
LABEL: private sector efficiency

CONTENT: We have given them billions in subsidies and tax breaks. It's time they bury all the lines since we have paid for them to do it but they always get out of actually doing it because it's expensive. You know what's far more expensive? Getting sued by every resident because the root cause was their power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies got billions in subsidies but won't bury lines due to cost. Lawsuits from residents over fire damage will cost them more than prevention.
LABEL: Private Profits Public Risk

CONTENT: We need help with insurance claims. State Farm and other insurance companies are blatantly violating the law by issuing blanket denials of many types of claims. We shouldn't all need to hire attorneys to get the insurance companies to honor our policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are illegally denying claims, forcing us to hire lawyers just to get coverage we're entitled to under our policies.
LABEL: private insurance abuse

CONTENT: Force Insurance Companies to cover toxin testing inside smoke damaged homes. If the health department says we should be concerned about this why does insurance refuse to cover it? How can we feel safe moving back in our homes. The testing is very expensive…$5-$10 thousand depending on tests necessary. We paid close to $7000.00 out of pocket and are awaiting results. Many do not have the resources to pay for this themselves.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to cover toxin testing in smoke-damaged homes. Many can't afford the $5,000-$10,000 cost despite health department warnings.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Affordability

CONTENT: The insurance market is a disaster. I was told days before the fire that my insurance carrier no longer met the rating requirements of my mortgage lender so I cancelled my insurance policy effective 1/10/25 while my wife and I were getting quotes with other companies. We were going to be underwritten on 1/10/25 but the moratorium after the fires stopped that process and we couldn’t reinstate our previous policy because I cancelled it before the fires but it wouldn’t fulfill my mortgage requirements anyways. After 10 days of no insurance immediately after the fires, we joined the FAIR plan and then got charged an insane amount from our lender for the lapse in insurance coverage. My house didn’t burn and still no word from other insurers!
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance market is broken - cancelled policy before fire, couldn't get new coverage due to fire moratorium, forced into expensive FAIR plan with penalties from lender.
LABEL: private insurance failure

CONTENT: The power lines MUST be buried, and the cost should be absorbed by the power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies should bear the cost of burying power lines underground.
LABEL: Private Company Cost Responsibility

CONTENT:
Holding agencies accountable should be a given. Public or private sector must pay the price of their failure, poor decision, negligence, or plain recklessness.
How about transparency too: known system weaknesses should be communicated truthfully to the community so we can better prepare in the event of a fire: no water in hydrants when the power is shut down, no remote emergency shut-off for gas are 2 that come to mind
LLM_SUMMARY: Both public and private agencies must be transparent about infrastructure weaknesses and held accountable for failures that put communities at risk.
LABEL: accountability transparency responsibility

CONTENT: Except majority of this disaster recovery, for example, was in the form of private donations redistributed to individuals, and in federal support like FEMA and ACE.  What we need is local govt funds to go towards infrastructures that are severely lacking (when was the last time you drove LA and didn't dodge a massive pothole?) and without raising taxes on individuals.  We already pay plenty to keep this all running smoothly.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private donations and federal aid helped recovery, but local infrastructure needs funding without raising individual taxes - we already pay enough.
LABEL: public infrastructure funding

CONTENT: We know why there wasn't enough water. DWP never built the water system to fight a wildfire. Now we know we have to rebuild the water system to support delivering more water faster. Make the communities who chose to live in the high risk areas pay for the upgrades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Those who choose to live in high-risk fire areas should pay for water system upgrades, not everyone else through DWP.
LABEL: High Risk Cost-Sharing
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Let's put civil engineers and public servants in charge of our utilities, not wealthy business executives with MBAs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Public servants and engineers should manage our utilities instead of profit-driven business executives.
LABEL: public over private

CONTENT: Update systems, water reclamation, underground power, solar powered street lights, break up the monopoly of the utilities. SCE is irresponsible and has shown a considerable lack of care for its customers and the land.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison's monopoly needs to end - they're irresponsible with infrastructure maintenance and don't care about customers. Utilities should be public, not private.
LABEL: Break Utility Monopoly

CONTENT: I don't understand why we have above ground power lines in fire prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be underground in fire-prone areas, not above ground where they create hazards.
LABEL: Above Ground Infrastructure

CONTENT: I would like to see a publicly funded community led public safety committee  that has the ability to escalate issues of concern to the courts (via seeking a writ of mandate to compel action) if they are not addressed in a timely fashion by local government. Senior public safety officers like the Fire Chief should present to this committee, as they do to the Fire Commission and the Mayor. People who live in the community have a much stronger impetus to address potential fire risk than elected or appointed officials have.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community members should oversee public safety through a funded committee with legal power to compel government action, as they have more stake in fire prevention.
LABEL: public community oversight

CONTENT: Require insurance companies to issue 100% of personal property coverage for completely destroyed homes and 75% for standing homes within the burn zone without inventory lists.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to pay full coverage for destroyed homes and 75% for damaged homes without requiring inventory lists.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Regulation

CONTENT: Watch Duty should be publicly funded
LLM_SUMMARY: Public funding should support Watch Duty's fire alert system.
LABEL: Public Funding Essential

CONTENT: If I rebuild, I want a guarantee I can acquire the necessary fire insurance to cover my loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to provide fire coverage if we rebuild in high-risk areas.
LABEL: Insurance Access Affordability

CONTENT:
Insurance companies should be held responsible for paying the claims on the policies that they willingly sold to residents in the affected areas.  But we also have to acknowledge that they are beholden to their shareholders and will non-renew or exit CA if they can't make a profit.

It could help to require insurance companies to offer incentives for more fire-resistant construction.  Loosening regulations on the insurance industry is something I'm hesitant to support, but if insurance rates are determined by market forces and not a government commission, it could lead to more companies entering the market which would keep prices in check.  Rates will still be higher, but CA rates are lower than many other states with lower disaster risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must honor policies but need profit to stay. Market-driven rates and fire-resistance incentives could help balance coverage and costs.
LABEL: private market regulation

CONTENT: Unground power lines. Pay for it  DO NOT make the citizens pay for it. Use new technology ie drones to asses fire risk on windy Santa Ana days. Pre deploy the Fire Dept. Brush Clearance on city, county, and state land is a MUST.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines should be installed, but corporations should bear the cost, not citizens.
LABEL: Public Funded Infrastructure

CONTENT: Don't outsource our emergency warning systems to private companies who put peoples lives in the hands of an AI model. Competent human beings able to talk to all emergency services and make good decisions please.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies shouldn't control emergency warning systems with AI. We need skilled humans coordinating with emergency services to make critical decisions.
LABEL: public emergency control

CONTENT: Underground utilities!
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities would solve many problems, but who pays for it?
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Support

CONTENT: De-regulate, regarding insurance the insurance commissioner needs to meet with Ins companies, reinsurers, city/state/federal officials to propose a plan where residents are able to obtain proper coverage at a reasonable price and insurers/reinsurers are able to make a reasonable profit.  Insurance companies should be required to offer renewals. Insurance is one of the oldest businesses in existence, it has worked well for 100’s of years.  Adjustment obviously need to be made
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to offer renewals while working with government to ensure reasonable coverage prices and fair profits.
LABEL: private insurance regulation

CONTENT: Ensure existing homeowners near affected areas won’t have their insurance skyrocket when their renewals come due.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't be allowed to drastically raise rates on existing homeowners in fire-prone areas during policy renewals.
LABEL: Insurance Cost Protection

CONTENT: Bury power lines underground! Prevent damage from the wind every year, and extra wear-and-tear by being exposed to the elements all year long.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury power lines underground to prevent wind damage and weather exposure, though who pays for this infrastructure upgrade remains unclear.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Investment

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Those living in fire-prone areas should bear most rebuilding costs, though I'll pay some taxes to help, especially for less wealthy Altadena residents.
LABEL: Public Cost Sharing
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Given the common occurrence of high winds in the area, it is irresponsible that any utility lines are still allowed above ground. Power and other utilities should not have to be shut off to protect people during storm events when they may be the most needed. Companies which have chosen to allow their infrastructure to grow so out of date should not be allowed to pass the high cost of now updating them to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies shouldn't pass infrastructure upgrade costs to customers when they've neglected maintenance. Underground lines would prevent dangerous shutoffs during storms.
LABEL: private infrastructure responsibility

CONTENT:
Insurance is the main financial driver in recovery. our insurance department, in the last decade has done very little to refine and make the claims process better for citizens.

Making claims more transparent, making policies which make more sense, it isn't rocket science.

90% of folks end up underinsured. Not an accident. A failed system.

When HO3 policies are approved in this state - the Dept should force companies to reveal their claims process and then hold them to it after a disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and state regulators have failed citizens with opaque claims processes and inadequate coverage, leaving 90% underinsured during disasters.
LABEL: public insurance reform

CONTENT: In the Eaton fire, the cause appears to be from the utility. The press has outlined a number of issues known to be high risk that went unattended for years.  If the Government cannot hold utilities accountable and set higher standards, they will default to decisions that benefit profit over public safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private utilities prioritize profits over safety, ignoring known risks. Government must enforce stricter standards to protect the public.
LABEL: Private Profit Over Safety

CONTENT: L.A. County provides broadband coverage in all inhabited areas. More revenue for restoration and less money for the Spectrums of the world.
LLM_SUMMARY: County-provided broadband is better than private companies like Spectrum - more money goes to restoration instead of corporate profits.
LABEL: public utility support

CONTENT: Why are electrical lines above ground?
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would be safer, but who pays for it - the utility company or taxpayers?
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Safety

CONTENT: All of LADWP’s/SCE’s power lines should be buried. Access in and out of mountain communities needs to be improved, driving should not be the only option (the problem with driving being the only option for evacuation can be seen by all the abandoned cars on sunset). The state/federal govt funded a Santa Monica mountains bus service back in the 70s that snaked around mountains for a summer season, bringing that back will help alleviate congestion and can provide more evacuation alternatives.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be buried underground, and we need government-funded public transit in mountain areas to reduce evacuation congestion, not just private vehicles.
LABEL: public infrastructure responsibility

CONTENT: Government should step in above greedy developers to help survivors. There is no better time than now to start community land trusts while also building community public housing that serves everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should manage land and housing instead of profit-driven developers, creating public trusts that serve the whole community.
LABEL: Public Over Private

CONTENT: Insurance companies must be held accountable for claims. They are in the insurance business. That is a risk reward business. Extreme profit at the expense of people is unacceptable.
