LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies profit from risk but must be held accountable for claims instead of prioritizing profits over people's needs.
LABEL: private profit versus public

CONTENT: The entire insurance system in California should be completely reimagined. There must be a system that is accessible, cannot be canceled or reduced based on statewide costs and mandates and is sustainable over time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance in California needs reform - it must be accessible, protected from cancellation, and sustainable regardless of who manages it.
LABEL: Public Insurance Mandate

CONTENT: the insurance commissioner needs to step up their game and work with the legislature to change some rules.  If an insurance company offers homeowners insurance in another state but cancels it here in california, all of their other lines of insurance (renters, auto, life, motorcycle) should not be allowed in the state either. insurance commissioner needs to be certain that premiums are fair, insurance language is exceedingly clear leaving no wiggle room, and that collecting on insurance sure be an automatic and smooth process for the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies canceling California coverage should lose rights to sell any insurance in-state. Commissioner must ensure fair rates and clear terms.
LABEL: public regulation needed

CONTENT: Bury the lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury the power lines.
LABEL: Underground Infrastructure Costs

CONTENT:
1. create a public utilities system, delivering traditional and alternative forms.
2. High speed wifi should be a public utility - not a Verizon over here, AT&T over there, Spectrum in this area... all with different cables and methods of delivery and cost.  enough already.
3. move powerlines underground; zero overhead power lines. make it a law
4.invest in robust water collection and reserve methods
LLM_SUMMARY: Public utilities should be unified systems - no more fragmented private providers. Underground power lines should be mandatory, not optional.
LABEL: public infrastructure control

CONTENT:
The coper in the powerlines are constantly getting robbed and now thieves have turned to robbing the water hydrants. This is so infuriating and makes the county look deteriorated. Either you start building infrastructure and make it impossible for thieves to rob copper or implement very harsh punishments for those stealing and purchasing stolen copper, wires, or anything pertaining to city infrastructure. 
Also stop taxing us each and every time we need a new road, water dam, etc. Voters have passed plenty of bond measurements for these projects. Start managing the money better!
LLM_SUMMARY: Thieves steal copper from power lines and hydrants. We've passed bonds for infrastructure - manage that money better instead of adding more taxes.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Security

CONTENT: I agree that money should not be spent on the monopolization of internet providers like Spectrum or AT&T. Money should go towards local and government infrastructure where able.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local government should control infrastructure funding instead of private monopolies like Spectrum and AT&T.
LABEL: public over private

CONTENT: We have a policy problem in California related to insurance.  it's not a market problem.  hurricanes wipe out MILLIONS of homes.  we are now worried about not having anymore home insurance because of 14,000 homes lost.  the Governor, Legislature and Insurance Commissioner need to fix this problem once and for all.  the California govt is to blame for our lack of insurance.  I want to be able to insure my home when i rebuild and i honestly don't think i'll be able to.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are abandoning California over minimal fire losses. The state government needs to fix this policy problem so homeowners can rebuild.
LABEL: government regulation needed

CONTENT: To mitigate the risk of fire, all utilities that can cause ignition must be hardened. The utility companies must be responsible for this without expectations of reimbursement. The utility companies should have these safeguards built in if they want to do business. All new buildings must have fire resistant design, assuring that materials used are not toxic when exposed to fire. Areas prone to wildfire should not be rebuilt without technologies that reduce the danger.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies must harden infrastructure against fire risks at their own cost - it should be a basic requirement of doing business.
LABEL: private utility responsibility

CONTENT: The California Fair Plan is failing its policyholders in a big way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are failing policyholders through the California Fair Plan.
LABEL: Public Insurance Support

CONTENT:
Insurance company made a lot of $$$$$ now they are leaving, asking for any nonsense or single bs details about any property even a shadow of a roof is a denial for them.
We need more effort from the insurance commissioner
Not just for Homeowners 
Bussines Owners, Worker's Compensation and all those insurance we normally paid e every single day/month.
We need a specific rule for these and everything about the insurance Bussines network..
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies profit then abandon us. We need stricter regulations from insurance commissioners to protect homeowners and businesses from unfair denials.
LABEL: private insurance exploitation

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies will abandon us if unprofitable, and the state can't afford to replace them. We need community-wide fire hardening, not just individual solutions.
LABEL: public collective responsibility

CONTENT: Standing aside doesn't seem to be working. These insurance companies don't want to pay out anything and someone has got to twist their arm.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies avoid payouts - someone needs to force them to meet their obligations.
LABEL: private insurance resistance

CONTENT: This could be a strategic community effort rather than each individual homeowner having to go at it alone, which also strains the insurance systems, which in turn raises costs down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs rise when homeowners act individually. A coordinated community approach would be more strategic and cost-effective.
LABEL: Community Over Individual

CONTENT: Power lines need to be underground.  Europe has them, why doesn't California? This, and controlled burns, using goats to clear brush around urban-wildlife interface areas needs to be a priority for the state, county and city, and all water systems should be audited before the fire season begins. Leadership should be held accountable for not maintaining fire hydrants and reservoirs. There should be more budget dollars allocated to these preventative measures vs incurring billions in losses and the horrific trauma of our people. We should NOT be taxed through more bond measures for losses that were preventable or at least not a disaster of epic proportions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would prevent fires. We shouldn't need new taxes when proper maintenance and prevention could avoid billion-dollar disasters.
LABEL: public infrastructure responsibility

CONTENT: These items are proper local & state government functions and we've already tacitly agreed to fund them through reasonable taxation. Whatever is needed to fund these projects should come from unneeded political pet projects (Unneeded political pet projects is redundant).
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should fund fire safety infrastructure through existing taxes by redirecting money from unnecessary political projects.
LABEL: Public Government Control

CONTENT:
It is especially concerning for people who are of retirement age and/or elderly.

For a company to abandon a customer of so many years like you have been must almost feel like getting caught up in a Ponzi scheme.

We can all understand, the risk/reward profile is not favorable for them and why they want to divest themselves of California policies.

Special consideration should be made for those who have been loyal customers and are past the age where they can start over.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning long-term elderly customers feels unfair. They deserve special consideration since starting over at their age is difficult.
LABEL: private insurance abandonment

CONTENT: expansion of broadband is essential but the data providers took all the ACP money and now thats over
LLM_SUMMARY: Private companies took broadband expansion money but didn't deliver, leaving essential infrastructure needs unmet now that funding is gone.
LABEL: public versus private

CONTENT: Bury power lines and prevent costs from being passed to consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury power lines underground but don't make consumers pay for it through higher utility bills.
LABEL: Public Over Private

CONTENT: Debris removal is going pretty quickly between private contractors and the ACE's federal efforts.  Soil and Water quality plus open space and habitat restoration are efforts where community members and local universities will jump (or are already jumping!) at the chance to be involved, so as to save the county having to hire more staff to handle it all and instead our tax dollars can remain focused on upping the budget for outsourcing of the permitting process.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private contractors and federal teams handle debris well, while community volunteers help with restoration - saving tax dollars for other priorities.
LABEL: Public Private Partnership

CONTENT: You have the bury the power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be buried underground.
LABEL: Underground Infrastructure Public Priority

CONTENT: state farm is trying to resist paying out and is claiming that in order to get 50% payout now we have to sign a form that in 36 months they are no longer liable to pay more. they also are requiring a list of all private property even if house is complete loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company State Farm demands we sign away rights to future claims after 36 months for partial payout now, despite total home loss.
LABEL: Insurance Company Resistance

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and tax dollars shouldn't subsidize rebuilding in high-risk fire zones - the whole state shouldn't bear costs for individual choices to live there.
LABEL: Public Versus Private
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Underground power lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines should be installed to prevent fires.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Support

CONTENT: Push insurance companies to simply pay out 100% on total losses, as we are all under insured anyhow.  This has occurred in prior fires, and we are desperately needing to rebuild sooner than later, so knowing a budget is key, and key now.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should pay 100% on total losses since we're all underinsured. We need to rebuild quickly and need budget certainty.
LABEL: insurance coverage affordability

CONTENT:
I totally concur with this remark. Our home insurance has more than doubled each year for the last two years and there is no end in site to the increases.  This is not sustainable.  It is no surprise that so many homeowners who lost their homes either were woefully uninsured or had no insurance.  

Also, what is not calculated in the rebuild costs is how much construction costs will rise due to the limited number of legitimate and qualified construction companies available in a crisis like this. It is completely understandable why we so many people are leaving for other states.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are skyrocketing yearly, becoming unsustainable. Many homeowners are underinsured or uninsured as a result.
LABEL: Insurance Costs Unsust

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs for rebuilding in high-risk fire zones should be paid by those communities, not spread across low-risk areas throughout the state.
LABEL: private risk allocation
SUBCATEGORY: High Risk Areas Should Pay Own Costs

CONTENT: Insurance companies should pay all policy limits for inventory and property value. Future wildfire survivors are paying for those limits, the insurance companies shouldn’t make the process difficult to collect those limits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't make claims difficult - we pay premiums expecting full coverage when disasters strike, not bureaucratic hurdles.
LABEL: Insurance Companies Pay Costs

CONTENT: In our rural area, we've discovered the hard way that key equipment for landlines, cable/internet and cell service often shares a power pole. Which means literally every means of communication most people have access to goes down at the same time if the fire takes out that ONE pole. There ought to be a mandate for undergrounding ALL of those services and separating them where undergrounding is not possible. A grant program to equip rural residents with satellite phones for emergency use would also help, as would establishing local emergency radio frequencies we could tune into for updates. Also, cell phones should be able to connect to ANY available tower for ALL CALLS (not just 911) and alerts (nixle, watch duty, etc) during emergencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities sharing single power poles creates dangerous communication blackouts. Infrastructure should be separated and undergrounded, with emergency alternatives like satellite phones provided.
LABEL: infrastructure reliability responsibility

CONTENT: Require all electrical power lines to be undergrounded in the foothills and Altadena! SCE did a lousy job of protecting the residents along the foothills.
LLM_SUMMARY: SCE failed to protect residents. All power lines in foothills and Altadena must be moved underground.
LABEL: Public Utility Control

CONTENT: Edison should make underground system for Altadena.  It will be costly, but it is necessary.  We cannot make another town like second Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison needs to put power lines underground in Altadena. It's expensive but necessary for safety.
LABEL: Underground Infrastructure Cost Allocation

CONTENT: Rebuild to new codes and fire safe is not affordable. Even if you do rebuild to fire safety Insurance lies and does not insure regardless of how safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't cover homes even when rebuilt to fire safety codes - it's too expensive and they still deny coverage.
LABEL: Insurance Affordability Cost

CONTENT: Home owners should be able to use Natural gas. It's more reliable and affordable than all electric mandates. Not allowing apartments in single family areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Natural gas is more reliable and affordable than mandated electric utilities - homeowners should have this choice.
LABEL: private utility preference

CONTENT: All Utility companies need to be made FULLY accountable. PG$E was NOT made fully accountable only 70% accountable. Victims throughout CA need to be fully compensated-100%!
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies must be held 100% accountable, not just 70% like PG&E. Fire victims deserve full compensation.
LABEL: Private Utility Accountability

CONTENT: Have all power lines put underground
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be placed underground.
LABEL: Underground Power Line Advocate

CONTENT: Better coordination is needed between insurance companies and state agencies, so that residents of threatened areas can receive $ for temporary housing BEFORE evacuation is mandatory and can continue to receive it until essential services are restored to their homes. Right now, most people only receive assistance as long as evacuation is mandatory and only until the order is lifted, regardless of whether power, water and other essential services have been restored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should provide temporary housing funds before mandatory evacuations and until services are restored, not just during official evacuation periods.
LABEL: public private coordination

CONTENT: One massive issue we had here in Northern CA is that insurance coverage for temporary housing only kicks in when the evacuation order is mandatory. This means that people with fewer financial resources (including seniors) are forced to wait until the very last minute to leave--putting themselves in great danger and making the situation more difficult and dangerous for first responders, as well. And because lodging coverage stops as soon as evac orders are lifted, people here were forced to return to unsafe situations, with no running water, no power and no internet (at a time when kids were still doing remote learning due to COVID). The state needs to be aware of this issue and work with insurance providers to resolve it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies that only cover mandatory evacuations force low-income residents to risk their safety by waiting too long to leave and returning too early.
LABEL: Private Insurance Affordability

CONTENT: All power should be underground AND not at the expense of the rate payer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be underground, but ratepayers shouldn't bear the cost of this infrastructure upgrade.
LABEL: Public Underground Infrastructure Cost

CONTENT: I think companies should have a green house tax. The more the company produces green house gases, methane or hazardous waste the higher the tax. And cost should not be passed on to consumer..perhaps out of profits before bonuses and salary raises and stock options are allowed
LLM_SUMMARY: Companies should pay greenhouse taxes from profits, not pass costs to consumers, before executives get bonuses or raises.
LABEL: Corporate Environmental Accountability

CONTENT: Homeowners and insurance companies should have to review the policy yearly and insurance language must be written at a 6 grade level in order for everyone to understand.  There are to many hidden meanings and definitions as well as all information should be explicit and complete.  Do not let insurance companies provide homeowners with a summary chart that leaves out specific restrictions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies need simpler language and yearly reviews. Companies shouldn't hide restrictions in complex terms that homeowners can't understand.
LABEL: insurance transparency regulation

CONTENT: Hold power companies to strict guidelines and penalties for failure to maintain safety. Hold individuals as well as companies responsible for obvious neglect.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power companies and individuals must both face strict penalties and accountability for neglecting safety maintenance.
LABEL: Company Accountability Enforcement

CONTENT: Undergrounding powerlines should be done now, before roads are repaved.
LLM_SUMMARY: Powerlines need to be moved underground before road repaving happens - it's the logical order of infrastructure upgrades.
LABEL: Public Infrastructure Priority

CONTENT: 6 of the 10 most costly fires in California have been caused by power lines. Its way overdue to put them underground. If Europe can do it, so can we.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines must be moved underground like in Europe - we can't keep having costly fires caused by above-ground utilities.
LABEL: Underground Power Line Advocate

CONTENT: Similar to a comment made yesterday: "I don't think that everyone should have to hire an attorney to get the fair benefit of their fire insurance policy." I wonder about California's appetite for SB 222 that might create an insurable future but at the cost of affordable gas. I read somewhere that climate change contributed about 25% to the impact of the fires. If that is true, then maybe oil and gas liability should be capped (or a mandatory oil and gas recovery fund set aside to the tune of an accurate reading on percentage of projected damages)
LLM_SUMMARY: "Insurance companies should provide fair coverage without requiring attorneys. Oil and gas companies should contribute to a damage fund based on their climate impact."
LABEL: Public Versus Private

CONTENT: Utilities must be held accountable. Insurance should only be valid for those who follow best fire safe practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and utilities need accountability, with coverage limited to those following fire safety protocols.
LABEL: Private Accountability Required

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and homeowners should combine resources for neighborhood-wide fire cleanup instead of individual properties - it's more efficient and cost-effective.
LABEL: collective infrastructure maintenance

CONTENT: I would see this as an area where state and federal monies, along with $$$ from the utilities,  can be used to rebuild smartly.  Roads and sidewalks can be rethought to increase the probability of being able to leave in time.  Unsafe, above ground lines can be eliminated.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities and government should share costs to rebuild infrastructure smartly, including burying power lines and redesigning roads for safer evacuations.
LABEL: Public Private Cost Sharing

CONTENT:
I prefer to stay focused on where we go from here, rather than debate why stuff didn't happen in the past. We know what we need to do (e.g, utility under-grounding, firebreaks, fire prevention, fire hardening when (re)building, etc.). It will cost money (private, government). We know we have not had basic* transparency in past on government action (including our IOU monopolies), so let's design that differently from hereon too, perhaps leveraging 311 that we already use. All this can be piloted/tested in LA, but needs to be designed for statewide rollout, adapted for situations elsewhere. 

*basic in sense of: clear, accessible, responsive, and timely to average citizen - not in terms of endless dense reports commissioned by CPUC etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need utility undergrounding and fire prevention measures, but who pays - private companies or government? Past transparency issues need fixing too.
LABEL: public private partnership

CONTENT: This fire was unprecedented in that the winds created a very fast moving fire.  I think the city did a good job alerting people to high fire risk prior to the windstorm, as long as residents were signed up for the city's NotifyLA system and looked at NOAA reports ahead of time.  I don't know how best to get alerts to all citizens, especially the elderly who may be technology averse.  Maybe start with a cell phone push to alert citizens of fire risk, and I think it is also the responsibility of the residents to prepare adequately too for rapid evacuation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual residents must stay informed through alert systems, but the city needs better ways to reach everyone, especially technology-averse elderly people.
LABEL: shared responsibility requires coordination

CONTENT: California needs to call in Federal assistance to manage the entire state. Too much of the forest is left unkept. Need to increase logging of old forest so that areas can be managed with planting of new growth. Open it up the private companies to manage.
LLM_SUMMARY: The state can't handle this alone - we need federal help and private companies to manage forests through logging and replanting.
LABEL: government collective action

CONTENT: this isn't just for govt officials, it should be baked into building code, zoning, and planning. but not in the typical, gross, broad stroke kinda stupid way the county usually does everything, but in a really smart, focused, well considered way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual actions aren't enough - fire safety must be integrated into building codes and zoning, but with smarter, more focused planning than typical government approaches.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: partially, the new code requirements should be evaluated by DISINTERESTED 3rd party experts to make sure they actually do something. so much code is basically lobbied into existence by people and companies who gain from requiring expensive, spurious non-sense. there should be significant legal aid for that effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear costs of questionable fire codes. We need independent experts to evaluate requirements, not lobbyists pushing expensive, ineffective regulations.
LABEL: government oversight needed

CONTENT: government efficiency. and i don't mean in the DOGE sense. i mean real govt efficiency in designing code that makes sense, isn't bloated, but is very focused on smart building. reducing costs. property values in the area have increased by 3x +++ in the last 30 years. has the cost of running the govt increased by 3x? there should be budget surplus. government ineffectiveness in combo with lack of high information civic participation is the root cause. adding better vent covers is important, but will not solve the underlying issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government needs to create smarter building codes and enforce them effectively. Individual actions like vent covers won't solve systemic problems.
LABEL: government collective solutions

CONTENT: CA should just call the entire state a WUI CA Fire zone. No more pockets where CA Fire WUI regulations are not in place
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear responsibility alone - the entire state needs uniform wildfire regulations and standards.
LABEL: Government Enforcement Required

CONTENT: Building code needs to emphasize fire safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes must be strengthened to protect everyone, not just rely on individual homeowners' actions.
LABEL: collective government standards

CONTENT: Tax relief for fire hardened houses and neighborhoods. The more contiguous houses that are fire hardened the more tax relief/house. So we encourage NEIGHBORHOODS to communicate and cooperate
LLM_SUMMARY: "Give tax relief to fire-hardened homes, with bigger incentives when entire neighborhoods participate. This encourages collective action in fire prevention."
LABEL: collective incentivized cooperation

CONTENT: Train community groups like town/neighborhood councils and CERTs on defensible space/structure hardening and have them conduct community-wide property reviews and education. Does not have to be an enforcement or narc approach but rather an offering of information specific to the property; it can even be a checklist on a trifold that checks off items that need to be retrofitted and specific instructions for the retrofit inside. It takes a village to educate but there's heavy reliance on the few in the government.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Community groups should educate neighbors about fire safety and property protection, rather than relying solely on government. It takes collective effort."
LABEL: collective community education

CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas. Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government allowed development in fire-prone areas, so they share responsibility. Can't solely blame homeowners who weren't fire experts when buying their homes.
LABEL: government responsibility collective

CONTENT: Smart habitat restoration. Not clearing out debris etc. that create fuel for fires should not be an option
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual property owners must clear debris and maintain their land - it shouldn't be optional when fire safety affects everyone.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Required

CONTENT: However, the environmental recovery should include a plan to establish and maintain fire breaks in the Santa Monica mountains above and around the town. The area managed by the conservancy and the state parks in the mountains are really wild animal parks, and should be treated and managed as such balancing the needs of the animals against the safety of the surrounding communities. The historical approach is resulting in larger and more frequent wildfires. So something clearly has to change.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire breaks in Santa Monica mountains must be maintained collectively by conservancy and state parks, balancing wildlife needs with community safety.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: All debris must be cleared from all properties. It can be done privately but if anyone refuses or abandons their lot it must be removed even if a lean must be implemented against the owner and property. We can't have toxic waste that's both dangerous and unsightly to remain. Also, all the utilities must be buried underground. MUST. No exceptions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners should clear debris, but government must enforce cleanup and place liens if needed. Can't let individual negligence endanger everyone.
LABEL: Collective Government Enforcement

CONTENT: All lots need to be cleared bc it cannot really be cleaned up if toxic material is airborne. There should be a city wide emergency day that educates people on safety and evacuations (Japan does this for earthquakes). It can be led by the city w/localities doing their own area-specific drills.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire safety requires both city-wide education programs and individual property maintenance. One person's uncleared lot affects everyone through airborne hazards.
LABEL: Government Led Solutions

CONTENT: We need clear guidance on fire resistant best practices. Most of the guidance is tailored to homes in rural areas.  It does not apply to homes that are 10 feet apart in a city suburb.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't do much when houses are so close together - we need collective fire safety standards for suburban neighborhoods.
LABEL: collective guidance needed

CONTENT: There must be a deadline with real implications for those who do not clear their lots in a timely manner. Testing for all lots (whether burned or not) to ensure the community is safe.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners must face real consequences for not clearing their lots. Testing all properties ensures community-wide safety.
LABEL: Individual Enforcement Mandatory

CONTENT: The state of California has done a horrible job with forest management, firebreaks and accountability.
LLM_SUMMARY: The state has failed at forest management - this shouldn't fall on individuals to handle alone.
LABEL: government accountability needed

CONTENT:
Over the last few years, as a private property owner, I have received Brush Clearance notices for my property. At one point, I was substantially fined - although I had documentation my lot was clear. No matter what had been happening in my life (a parent passing, Covid, a sick child) I was required to clear brush on my property. Why isn’t the City, County, State held to these same requirements? 

I also think basic services that prioritize the safety of our communities - the police, fire department, schools, infrastructure - need to be funded first. We pay too high of taxes in LA and CA for these services not be available to residents when they are needed (ie; firefighters to put out fires, fire hydrants that work, etc)
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners face strict brush clearance rules and fines, but government agencies aren't held to same standards. Why this double standard when we pay high taxes?
LABEL: individual versus collective

CONTENT: The money to do this should already be a part of all the money that is being paid into the state, county and city.  Why there is almost no funds or action in the past in this area does not make any sense.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should fund fire mitigation with existing tax revenue. It's nonsensical that there's been so little funding and action.
LABEL: government funding responsibility

CONTENT: I think local communities, neighborhoods and residents must also expect to be held accountable. We are all in this together.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone needs to do their part - both individual residents and the community as a whole must be accountable for fire safety.
LABEL: Individual And Collective

CONTENT: I think all of these systems need to be reviewed from the bottom up and out as well as from the top down. Creating voluntary neighbourhood emergency councils, coordinated and supported by agencies and city councils can create a resilient community ecosystem for responding to disaster in the longer term. Evacuation routes are problematic in this area: it took us 2 hours to travel a distance that normally takes 15 minutes when evacuating and that was actually on us for leaving it until the last minute to evacuate. We've learned for the future and are sharing our learning with others!
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners waited too long to evacuate, but we need coordinated neighborhood councils working with government agencies to create better emergency response systems.
LABEL: collective coordinated solutions

CONTENT: This needs to be treated as a priority for attention at city level, especially in the wildlands/urban interface, where fire is an ongoing and increasing experience. Everyone is affected by fire and this can be used proactively to encourage direct community engagement through neighborhood groups education, training, widespread introduction of goats for vegetation clearance, prescribed burning practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual efforts aren't enough - this needs city-level priority. Fire affects everyone, so we need coordinated community engagement through education, training, and prescribed burns.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Of course, firebreaks should be mandatory in all fire prone areas. Specifically, all agencies responsible for enforcing fire and water regulations (both directly and indirectly), should be held the most responsible. This is mostly their jurisdictional areas. Fire and water special emphasis program implementation - including organizations to whom it may concern.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government agencies and regulators should be primarily responsible for implementing and enforcing firebreaks and fire safety programs in fire-prone areas.
LABEL: Government Enforcement Required

CONTENT:
We need ACCOUNTABILITY, REFORMS, GRANTS, and TAX BREAKS. We cannot rebuild this community without help for individual home owners.
(And please keep it closed until more debris is cleared and more of the fortunate are able to repopulate standing homes. Remediation lines are long. It’s too soon.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners need support through grants and tax breaks - we can't handle fire recovery alone without collective assistance.
LABEL: Individual Needs Support

CONTENT: I am middle class. I’ll pour every cent into this rebuild, but I’m still not sure I can pull it off and I’m not sure I’m going to qualify for any help. Can you please keep that in mind? SEND GRANTS, PLEASE! I’ll follow every fire hardening guideline I can afford.
LLM_SUMMARY: I'll follow fire guidelines, but need financial help. Individual homeowners can't shoulder these costs alone - we need grants and assistance programs.
LABEL: Individual Needs Support

CONTENT: The enormous expense of this fire, and the upset that is has caused for thousands of families, shows that funding fire prevention programs is a good idea.  Someone should be made in charge of fire prevention planning.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire prevention shouldn't rely on individuals - we need funded programs and designated leadership to protect thousands of families from wildfire devastation.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Accessible grants for homeowners too. **There’s an underserved middle between those who qualify for aid and those who don’t need it.** Please help us with grants to rebuild. I’m begging you. I can’t give up the plot where my long gone grandparents held me and I took my first steps.
LLM_SUMMARY: "There's an underserved middle between those who qualify for fire safety aid and those who don't need it. We need more accessible grants."
LABEL: government aid needed

CONTENT: Government at all levels should be held accountable for fire prevention along with what is being required of homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't solve this alone - government needs to step up and share responsibility for fire prevention.
LABEL: Individual And Collective

CONTENT: The city/dwp/fire department need to proactivity do their jobs maintaining the water resources, fire hydrants, clearing debris and being on alert and deployed during high fire season.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government agencies must take responsibility for maintaining water resources, hydrants, and clearing debris during fire season, not just individuals.
LABEL: government collective responsibility

CONTENT: The city and mayor must impose debris removal deadlines on those who have not responded to ROE input.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners who haven't responded to debris removal requirements should face mandatory deadlines enforced by city leadership.
LABEL: government enforcement needed

CONTENT: Homeowners should be taking basic fire hardening steps. I live on the edge of the Palisades fire area but happened to be walking in Altadena/Pasadena neighborhoods a month or two BEFORE the fire. I kept shaking my head and repeating to my wife "Is nobody taking fire seriously here?". House after house of attached wood fences, trees branches overhanging houses, unbroken rows of vegetation, etc...
LLM_SUMMARY: "Homeowners aren't taking basic fire prevention seriously - I saw countless houses with wood fences, overhanging branches, and continuous vegetation lines near fire zones."
LABEL: Individual Homeowner Responsibility

CONTENT: Make LA and LA county a fire-wise community.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need the entire community to become fire-wise, not just individual homeowners.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear fire mitigation costs alone; government grants and tax relief are needed to help meet code requirements.
LABEL: collective government support

CONTENT: Make sure every lot is cleared even if it requires imminent domain
LLM_SUMMARY: Property clearing should be enforced on all lots, even if government needs to take control through eminent domain.
LABEL: Government Enforced Compliance

CONTENT: There should be zoning, codes, permitting and other policies that limit or eliminate building in fire-prone areas unless customers are willing to pay for the materials to be fire resilient and willing to forego the protection from standard services in the case of an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building in fire-prone areas should require owners to use fire-resistant materials and accept limited emergency services, supported by strict zoning policies.
LABEL: collective government regulation

CONTENT: Coordination with home owners. Require soil testing
LLM_SUMMARY: Coordination between homeowners and authorities is needed, including mandatory soil testing requirements.
LABEL: Individual Collective Coordination

CONTENT: We need a community that can live with fire.  As I understand it, the homes built to the latest standards for materials and design, which also had appropriate defensible space, did much better than other homes in the fires.  We need to ensure that the rebuild follows these standards, which includes financing, ensuring that contractors are properly trained, appropriate materials are available, and agreements that communities rebuilt to these standards are insurable in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't solve this alone - we need community-wide standards for fire-safe construction, proper training, and insurance support.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Communities in LA are quite disconnected and vulnerable in the face of emergency.  We need systematic emergency preparedness on the part of citizens, and we need more robust and resilient emergency response systems in government.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual preparedness matters, but we need both citizens and government working together on emergency readiness - neither can do it alone.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: What is wildfire adaptation? Fire-resistant design and preparedness training are not the City's role; let Angelenos, their architects, and private organizations do this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners and private organizations should handle fire preparedness and design - it's not the city government's responsibility.
LABEL: individual responsibility preferred

CONTENT: Don’t just throw this on the residents trying to rebuild manage the land that is prone to fire better
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear all responsibility. Better land management needs to be handled at a higher level.
LABEL: collective government responsibility

CONTENT: Bury the utilities and mandate solar
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should be buried underground and solar power made mandatory - these are community-level solutions, not individual ones.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Focusing on what the City can fund at a time of unprecedented deficits is absurd, and the City is unable to hold its agencies accountable. Angelenos should hold the Council responsible for the City's failures at the ballot box. City government should ensure that fire prevention requirements are clear to allow private citizens and enterprises to implement them without bureaucratic delays.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private citizens can implement fire prevention if the city provides clear requirements, but bureaucracy and poor accountability hinder this partnership.
LABEL: Individual Over Government

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't always afford fire safety maintenance, so cities must help fund vegetation management to prevent neighborhood-wide disasters.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: Did I say “Task Force”?  We have a task force organization already. Developing Version 1.0, then Version 2.0…(keep going…) should be done in that framework. Oh, yes, and FUND it and put someone in charge of this “ongoing project” that will get results.
LLM_SUMMARY: We already have a task force. Fund it properly and assign leadership to get actual results.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: We need climate resilient landscaping, native plants, trees that don’t burn like oaks, remove palms and eucalyptus. We need real brush clearance in high risk places next to houses. We need to remove non native brush. We need revised building codes. I have been hardening my house with roof sprinklers, 1/8 inch wire mesh covering all vents, brush clearance, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners must clear brush and harden homes, but we also need collective action through building codes and removing non-native plants in high-risk areas.
LABEL: Individual Property Protection

CONTENT: Hold zoom workshops (and record them for future access) on various topics, like fire-resistant design, preparedness, safer landscaping, how to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: Collective workshops should teach homeowners about fire safety, from landscaping to rebuilding, making preparedness knowledge accessible to all.
LABEL: Individual Education And Support

CONTENT: Every home with a pool should have a pump that will allow pool water to be accessed! In Rancho Santa Fe it is required. Insurance companies should offer incentives.
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners with pools should be required to install pumps for firefighting access, with insurance incentives to encourage compliance.
LABEL: Individual Plus Collective

CONTENT: Provide grants to help people fire harden their homes for those who can't afford it to reduce the chances and severity of future fires
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners need help - provide grants for fire-hardening homes to those who can't afford these important safety measures.
LABEL: collective government support

CONTENT: Strongly consider requiring new builds to be resilient by using the Passive Housing Standard, all electric buildings and fire resistant building materials. Electrifying homes and using a PHS combined lead to massive energy savings for homeowners and benefits to the entire community and region by lowering building pollution.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't solve this alone - we need mandatory building standards for fire-resistant materials and energy efficiency to protect entire communities.
LABEL: government mandated standards

CONTENT: This was the most fire prone area, obviously. Everyone in the city and county in positions of power were aware of the impending danger, yet so little was done to protect our community
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can only do so much - city and county officials failed to take necessary protective actions despite knowing the risks.
LABEL: government failed responsibility

CONTENT: Palm trees are a fire hazard, grass lawns are wasteful of water.  Incentivizing replacing both  to safer and more practical alternatives should be a priority for all of SoCal to reduce fire risk and waste of fire-fighting resources.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone in Southern California should be incentivized to replace hazardous palm trees and wasteful lawns to reduce fire risks collectively.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Fire prevention should provide more than a diagram of brush clearance distances from homes. There should be regular communication with residents about latest fire prevention technologies and perhaps incentives built into property tax breaks for brush clearing and landscaping maintenance. Residents also need to be given information on certain trees and bushes that are more flammable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents need guidance beyond brush clearance diagrams. Government should provide fire prevention education, tax incentives, and information about flammable vegetation.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: The state needs to give local municipalities mandates and resources to have emergency planning in place. Pasadena FAILED - its emergency and evacuation plan were nothing more than wish list and draft. Pasadena Fire Department said it had Genasys alert system which was never used. They had to ask - on the fly - for the Rose Bowl to be the incident command center and for the Convention Center to be a shelter. Neither of which were in any plans. No evacuation orders were issued until HOURS after the fire started - well after we could see the mountain on fire and ashes flying around! Who is responsible? PFD presented an evacuation plan a couple years ago and listed Pasadena Police in charge of evacuations - did PPD know they were in charge?
LLM_SUMMARY: The city failed us - no real emergency plan, late evacuation orders, and unclear responsibilities between departments. We need state-mandated standards and resources for local emergency planning.
LABEL: government coordination needed

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners in fire zones should pay for their own fire protection, not taxpayers from other regions who didn't choose to live there.
LABEL: collective funding debate

CONTENT: The time to address the above issues is before a disaster.  Ignoring fire hazards then spending money on disaster recovery is a foolish way to solve the issues.   Ask the community why they did not do more to mitigate the fire hazard before the event.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners should act before disasters, not wait until after. The community needs to take responsibility for fire mitigation rather than paying for recovery.
LABEL: collective prevention emphasis

CONTENT: We need to be proactive and clear brush/trash, bring back the brush eating goats and allow those that owe parking tickets to clean the freeways, like they used to. It should be illegal to start fires on the streets, public parks/forests (unless allowed to BBQ). Taxpayers should NOT be paying for the infrastructure upgrades of for profit electrical companies. When new communities are built, require power lines to be underground or have other safety measures in place that will prevent fires. Electrical companies can also educated the public and if they see something off with a powerline to say something.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners should clear brush, but power companies and government must lead with infrastructure upgrades, underground lines, and coordinated prevention programs.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: People should be held to code and standards. I lived next to a hoarder. I reported this many times and got nowhere. I truly believe it was why my house burned down.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners ignored fire codes, putting everyone at risk. Despite reporting my neighbor's hoarding, nothing was done and my house burned down.
LABEL: Individual Enforcement Needed

CONTENT: Strickter code requirements in regards to materials should be enforced.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should enforce stricter building material requirements for fire safety.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: The experts in the insurance industry who assess fire risk need to share their information publicly.  A coordinated effort between the insurance industry, the emergence response planners in the government, and the builders could result in a much better system for everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies, emergency planners, and builders should coordinate and share fire risk data for better collective protection.
LABEL: collective coordinated solutions

CONTENT:
Yes! Sign me up for training! Organize me!

Neighborhoods need community fire teams in place who set pumps and hoses out at the pools before evacuating. Maybe we even chainsaw any fuel, if there’s time. Work with us. How long do you need the hoses to be and whose properties do you want to store them at for success?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need organized community fire teams. Train us to set up pumps, store equipment, and work together before evacuations.
LABEL: collective community action

CONTENT:
Big yes to all of this. Everyone needs to be held accountable and changes made. 
(We are not all the few difficult ones who’ve resisted this in the past. Clear the brush. Let the community know if you need volunteers.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone must clear brush and maintain their property. If you need help, ask the community for volunteers.
LABEL: collective community accountability

CONTENT: For those neighborhoods zoned as "very high fire risk", the city and/or utilities needs to also be held accountable on underground transmission lines, along with reviewing all city trees which are highly flammable and replace them (regardless if tress are "protected" or not), along with ensuring overgrown vegetation are trimmed back on our hillsides/mountain areas close to residents.
LLM_SUMMARY: City and utilities must be accountable: underground power lines, remove flammable trees, and manage hillside vegetation. Individual homeowners can't handle this alone.
LABEL: demand collective enforcement

CONTENT: These initiatives should be incentivized to encourage participation, and the public should be educated about their benefits and importance. However, making them mandatory may not be the best approach, as it could lead to resistance or unintended consequences. Instead, fostering voluntary engagement through positive reinforcement would likely yield better long-term outcomes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire safety should be encouraged through incentives and education rather than mandates, as voluntary participation leads to better community engagement.
LABEL: voluntary incentivized participation

CONTENT: Ensure brush clearance on properties. Make sure homeowners are educated on steps they can take to be prepared.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners must clear brush and learn preparedness steps - it's their responsibility to take action.
LABEL: Individual Property Responsibility

CONTENT: Our government failed us on SO MANY LEVELS and need to be held accountable. We as homeowners have the responsibility of clearing our hillsides or we get a fine, meanwhile the city does nothing to clear public land. This is not ok. It needs to be top priority to clear the brush, for our communities, animals and environment.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners face fines for not clearing brush, while city neglects public land maintenance. Both parties must share responsibility for fire safety.
LABEL: government neglects responsibility

CONTENT: You have to test our yards and give direction for people who have standing homes about whether they can live safely amongst and near the burned homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government needs to assess properties and provide guidance on safely living near burned homes, not leave it to individual homeowners.
LABEL: government enforcement needed

CONTENT: I very much agree that we need more community outreach and education. In addition to providing this for long-time residents, I also think that new residents need better information. I moved to LA recently, and I feel like I was totally unprepared for the situation. I wish I had gotten some sort of "welcome packet" telling me what I needed to know.
LLM_SUMMARY: "As a new LA resident, I was unprepared for fire risks. The community should provide better education and welcome packets for both new and existing residents."
LABEL: collective education needed

CONTENT: Need community coordination of these efforts and either make it mandatory (part of building code) or offer financial incentives to harden homes against fire. Loosen some aspects of code/standards that are preventing us from staggering homes on lots to reduce structure-to-structure fire risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual efforts aren't enough - we need mandatory building codes, financial incentives, and looser regulations to better position homes against fire spread.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Most people are too tired and too overworked to find their own sources. Sometimes they don't even have enough time and energy available to KNOW that they need to do so. Government has a role to play in pushing out important, high-quality information.
LLM_SUMMARY: People are too overworked to research fire safety themselves. The government must take responsibility for providing essential information to the public.
LABEL: collective government responsibility

CONTENT: On the one hand I'm finding it easy to trust the army core. But on the other the reality of toxic ash covering the area it does leads me to believe that more can be done for testing. Insurance has basically refused it from that I can tell, and it's fallen on individuals to do testing to feel confident.  Still, the broad population with concerns about areas near schools (etc) means there is still a hearts and mind problem the government needs to solve for if they want people aligned with their stance on safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear testing costs alone. With toxic ash near schools, the government needs to take responsibility for comprehensive safety testing.
LABEL: government collective solutions

CONTENT:
Who pays for this? This isn't a solution. It's playing with knives all day and asking for a box of bandaids.

The solution is to build more housing BEFORE disasters so all citizens have homes. The next step is to harden homes in fire zones. The most important step after that is to have a commitment between govt agencies on managing debris, dried out trees, and flammable fuels from the outskirts and inner parts of communities so these fires don't get so out of control.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Individual actions aren't enough - we need government agencies to commit to managing debris, dried trees, and flammable fuels throughout communities."
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: YES. YES. YES. Education, fire audits, financial assistance for community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community fire safety requires both education and financial support - we can't rely on individuals alone.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: The government did not do their job yet they require all of us to jump through hoops to get back on the land that they let burn. Fire hydrants didn’t work, why do we need fire sprinklers and the extra permit for that when they wouldn’t have save our homes anyway.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners are forced to comply with costly fire regulations while government fails to maintain basic infrastructure like working fire hydrants.
LABEL: government failed responsibility

CONTENT:
The power lines in Altadena MUST BE BURIED. The transmission lines that run along the foothills must be rerouted. 

This Eaton Fire distaster cannot be allowed to happen again because a utility failed to de-energize the transmission lines.  That is no longer a tolerable scenario.  

The County, State and Federal Government must support this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government and utilities must take responsibility for burying power lines to prevent fires - individual actions aren't enough to solve this problem.
LABEL: government collective action

CONTENT:
Funding for communities to engage organizers and facilitators to act as paid (not volunteer, as is the Topanga Town Council, Chamber of Commerce, Emergency Preparedness (TCEP), elderly support (SAGES) - to bring community leaders together, to interface with govt agencies.

There should be a team specifically dedicated to coordination and communications as soon as a fire or other crisis strikes.

We need a unified 'easy to use' communications system for communities in crisis, including a clear and well organized hierarchy for distributing communications & a neighborhood/zone system that people are already enrolled in prefire. Cellular systems or mesh net wifi should be available for text only communications throughout the city and county.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need paid community coordinators, not volunteers, to organize fire preparedness and create unified emergency communication systems across neighborhoods."
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: There needs to be established guidelines and protocols for how to react to a disaster like this. Finding that there are no State Guidelines for deployment of Air/Soil/Water testing after a disaster is something that must be addressed.  These is not be the last fires in an urban setting, so we must ensure that when this happens again, that community is better suited to be supported.  We have the right to know if our communities are safe, the burden rests on the Government not groups of citizens stepping up in a vacuum to provide this data collection, mapping and distribution of results.
LLM_SUMMARY: The government, not individual citizens, must establish and enforce disaster protocols, including environmental testing. Communities shouldn't shoulder these responsibilities alone.
LABEL: government collective responsibility

CONTENT: Most of the defendable space requirements are already in the munipal code. How about actually enforcing existing code and fining people whose property are a fire hazard to the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: We have rules already - just enforce them and fine those who create fire hazards that endanger everyone else.
LABEL: Government Enforcement Needed

CONTENT:
More education about fire prevention, such as removing furniture and storage from the house perimeter, not using wood for fences, maintaining fire extinguishers, fireproof vents, etc should be required by the county and inspected by insurance companies. 

Insurance companies already check for overhanging trees, which is a similar risk issue.  Aftermarket sprinklers should be required inside and outside the house.  

A siren alarm system such as that for tornadoes in other states is not costly. Cell phone alerts are not appropriate for middle of the night event.

My neighbors saved their houses by dousing small fires all night long.  When we are ordered to evacuate, the fire dept took the responsibility to save our homes.....and failed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and county should require and inspect fire prevention measures like fireproof vents, sprinklers, and proper storage - not just leave it to homeowners.
LABEL: collective enforcement standards

CONTENT: Yes! Offer hefty rebates for those who fire harden their homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should incentivize homeowners with rebates to fire-harden their properties, making individual action more feasible.
LABEL: Individual With Support

CONTENT:
The laws need to be updated and harsh penalties implemented to individuals intentionally/negligently starting fires. Corporations need to be held accountable and help with fire prevention and cleanup, i.e. like oil companies when there is an oil spill.

It has been over 2 months and there is no official report on the cause of the fires. I've seen news reports that law firms are suing Edison but law firms aren't experts that determine how the fires started. Government needs to impose a deadline to those investigating man made catastrophes of 30 days. The public has a right to know what caused the disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Corporations and individuals must be held accountable for fires, with strict penalties. Government needs to enforce prevention and mandate faster investigation timelines."
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: Code changes must be adopted and enforced to reduce the future conflagrations that will otherwise happen. Get home owners and community groups to take on what should happen to make homes safer from the threat of fire. Listen to them, work with them. Present the policies and codes that will make a difference AND SELL THEM TO THE VOTERS!
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners should help shape fire safety policies, but we need mandatory codes and enforcement to truly protect our communities from fires.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: Fire resistant materials. Landscaping strategies that maximize beauty and safety. Neighborhood-wide mitigation efforts, not just on individual properties. Recognition of adaptation as a community effort, not just home by home. Permeable surfaces, bioswales, rain gardens.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual efforts aren't enough - we need neighborhood-wide mitigation strategies and community-based adaptation, not just property-by-property solutions.
LABEL: collective community solutions

CONTENT: Attention to contaminants should be a priority for the county's environmental health department. Not left up to individual homeowners. The long-term consequences are a community concern. Funding should exist for remediation if needed. Partnerships with research institutions. Programs to make whole house water purification systems cost effective. If building density increases to fill housing needs, standards for open space on lots. The county or city could buy lots put on the market to create publicly-owned green space.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Environmental health and fire safety shouldn't be left to individual homeowners. It's a community issue requiring government funding and programs."
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: In fire prone areas, the public needs to not only have regular reminders they live IN a high-hazard area, but they should be required to participate in annual or semi-annual exercises with emergency management, first responders, etc.  CERT exists for this effort.  Frankly, I was surprised and dismayed that there aren't any future rebuilding requirements to use fire-resistant technologies or building materials or landscaping.  Sounded to me like all of that is waived to expedite the rebuilding/recovery process; meaning, lessons NOT learned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can rebuild however they want, but we need mandatory community-wide fire preparedness training and building standards to reduce future risks.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: The plain fact is that NO ONE can afford this. Altadena residents who lost their homes need money, we need grants marked for individuals and families, not agencies/charities (where the donated funds go God knows where). We can't do this alone. My family is in a relatively privileged position where we had insurance and did not lose our jobs, but we don't know if we will be able to afford to rebuild. If we can't afford it, who can? What will our town be if it's just turned over to deep pocketed developers? We need help, and direct financial assistance to residents is the only way to preserve this town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't afford fire recovery alone - even with insurance. We need direct government grants to residents, not just agency funding.
LABEL: collective financial assistance

CONTENT: For profit utility companies must be required to adapt their equipment to prevent wildfires, especially where human life is at risk in urban or populated areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utility companies, not individuals, should be required to adapt their equipment to prevent wildfires in populated areas.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: My house is still standing with some minor damage, however, what I want to know is will there ever be grants to upgrade our old homes to code or for features that retard fires for example, fireproof roofs, siding, vents and windows?
LLM_SUMMARY: "Will there ever be government grants to help homeowners upgrade to fire-resistant features? Individual homeowners can't afford these crucial safety improvements alone."
LABEL: individual needs assistance

CONTENT: Super infrared detectors with AI intelligence to notice ANY dangerous signs of heat, fire, smoke and signal an immediate response from a 'SWAT' team that is entirely focused and on alert to snuff out any fires or flames before they can spread. Or issue tickets and fines, even prison, for anyone lighting dangerous fires. Northern US and canadian cities divert construction infrastructure to snow removal in winter. We must divert resources & attention to be on hyper alert & vigilance in dry high fire risk
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need collective resources like AI detection systems and rapid response teams, not just individual penalties, to prevent fires from spreading."
LABEL: government enforcement solutions

CONTENT:
I've heard stories of homeowners not being able to hire their own cleaning company. If a homeowner wants to hire their own licensed and certified cleaning company they should do so. 

The government should also be working on cleaning the surrounding areas that have been impacted; in this case the beaches. There has been little initiative by city/county to address the environmental impact caused to the Pacific Ocean by the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Homeowners should be allowed to hire their own licensed cleaning companies, but government must also take responsibility for cleaning fire-impacted public areas like beaches."
LABEL: individual responsibility prioritized

CONTENT: Please consider brush clearance, controlled burns and fines for those who do not properly maintain there brush/trees
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners should clear brush and face fines for non-compliance, while controlled burns should be implemented for fire prevention.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Enforcement

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to fix our utilities to prevent these fires from starting again, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. We need water and power to adapt to climate change and build infrastructure that shuts down without starting fires and keeps water running during fires. What happens if there is an earthquake during red flag high winds? I fear for my state.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual actions aren't enough - we need collective solutions like improved utilities, mandatory setbacks, and upgraded water infrastructure to handle wildfires in our changing climate.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: More funding more grants more education on how to get these resources and agency support services!!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more collective resources - funding, grants, and education about agency support services for fire mitigation.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners in fire-prone areas should either accept buyouts or pay full costs themselves - individual choice means individual responsibility.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Enforcement

CONTENT: Underground authority needs to be given to the County/City so that there is not a statewide/utility/personal property owner fight over where these lines go. The political cost of comprimising will be prohibitively expensive and too slow to make a lasting difference. Reducing future risk of and to infrastructure should be priority #1.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines shouldn't be debated between individuals, utilities, and state - give authority to local government for faster, more effective implementation.
LABEL: government authority needed

CONTENT: One immediate need is definitely financial support/grants/tax credits for home building and to address new code requirements. Instead of trying to waive the new code requirements to rebuild faster, let's give the community the chance to build back better
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need financial support and grants to help homeowners meet new building codes, rather than waiving requirements. This allows better community-wide rebuilding."
LABEL: collective government support

CONTENT:
Knowing a full week in advance that winds were coming, there was no excuse for LA Fire to wait UNTIL fires had begun before deploying. There was no excuse for the city's top exec to be out of country.

And clearly, there was not a well rehearsed protocol for what to do in a major fire storm. All of this is inexcusable.

Today technology allows for alerts to be given so people can leave an area before the danger arrives, not flee their possessions and elderly or inform as fires encroaches on their own life. 

Going forward, the State of CA should implement a disaster protocol set and incentivize cities to train and follow it when those towns are located in obviously risky fire or earthquake zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: "LA Fire and city officials failed their collective responsibility by not deploying early, lacking protocols, and having poor emergency response despite advance warning."
LABEL: demand collective solutions

CONTENT:
Fire resistant building materials, consistent audits of defensible space. (Individual buy in to the intrusion that an audit requires, for the greater good) audits of power companies to ensure they are not at risk for causing a fire.
Sincere attempts to reduce factors contributing to climate instability
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners must accept defensible space audits for community safety, while power companies need oversight to prevent fires.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: prepare by using the practice drills used in schools.  There should be surprise drills in all LA neighborhoods so we can work as a community.  Clear instructions, car exits, walking, public buses should be part of these drills.  This will take a large amount of time but we have expertise. The only way to be PREPARED is to work together in our preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community-wide fire evacuation drills are essential - individual preparation isn't enough. We need organized neighborhood practice with clear protocols and transportation plans.
LABEL: collective coordinated preparation

CONTENT:
Private insurers are leaving the state. Fair plan is already at risk of insolvency. We cannot afford to have to rebuild whole towns - and DESTROY whole communities and culture. Insurers, the state and especially RE-INSURANCE co's have every reason to invest substantially to reduce the risk to near zero of fires that spread to any residential area in LA County. 

Every home at the perimeter should have subsidized water and retardant systems, detectors and a wide boundary around these residential areas should have thorough brush clearance (Goats, sheep, fairly paid incarcerated) to inhibit the spread of fire from starting conflagration - where hot burning homes ignite homes from high infrared, not even sparks needed. 

HUGE VALUE & ROI
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and government must invest in collective fire prevention - individual homeowners can't handle this alone.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Kill all lawns. We must change the culture of turf lawns and instead normalize the use of California native plants. They save on water, are already adapted to the environment, provide wildfire resilience, and support local ecology. It is scientific fact that a diverse population thrives - therefore a more biodiverse environment is more resilient to threats. Yes - brush clearance is needed, but education and implementation of native landscapes comes hand-in-hand. In terms of accountability - hold the utility companies accountable. Do not let them get away with their negligence. They must pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners should replace lawns with native plants for fire resilience, while utilities must be held accountable for their role in fire prevention.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: We've got to take care of our neighbors, especially the ones who had their insurance dropped in the months leading up to the fires with no good alternative. But for anyone who could get insurance and decided not to, knowing they were in a fire zone? They should be on the hook for that bad decision, not the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance should be a collective concern for those who lost coverage, but individuals who chose not to insure despite living in fire zones should bear responsibility.
LABEL: Individual And Collective

CONTENT: Homeowners need to take more responsibility for their properties. Defensible space works, but it is not as aesthetically pleasing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual property owners must maintain defensible space, even though it's less attractive than overgrown landscaping.
LABEL: Individual Property Maintenance

CONTENT: I would like to see an emphasis on fire suppression technology that could be implemented home by home. Is there a way to get fire suppression materials at the ready? Can there be a push toward sprinkler systems that connect to a grid for fire professionals to utilize?
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners need fire suppression systems, but they should connect to a larger grid that fire professionals can control during emergencies.
LABEL: Individual Technology Solutions

CONTENT: Brush clearance on city/county/state land. That is THE problem.
LLM_SUMMARY: City, county, and state must clear brush on their land - individual property owners can't solve this alone.
LABEL: government responsibility enforcement

CONTENT: Broaden the C.C.C. mandate to take in more people, pay them, and help the community with cooperative neighborhood efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to expand the California Conservation Corps to involve more paid workers in community-wide fire prevention efforts.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government must enforce strict fire standards and invest taxpayer money in community-wide fire resistance measures.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: We need to make community based burning more accessible so that we can have burns when it is not fire season to reduce fuels during fire season.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community-based prescribed burns should be more accessible, as individual efforts aren't enough to reduce fire fuels across neighborhoods.
LABEL: collective coordinated enforcement

CONTENT: hold them accountable for updating programs/policies/ordinances but them give them the staffing and effective management to enforce. Also, door-to-door information/education (yes it is staff intensive, but there are plenty of people looking for employment).  For example, is there a problem house in the neighborhood who doesn't cut back trees, rake fallen leaves, or otherwise care for their property to the risk of the rest of the community? One warning, steep fines, then the county moves in and remediates using the fine to pay for the work.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Give agencies staff and resources to enforce fire policies, but also hold them accountable. One warning for negligent properties, then steep fines and county remediation."
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT:
CODE ENFORCEMENT NEEDS TO BE PROACTIVE, NOT REACTIVE. If we scratched the contract with WM for street sweeping in Palmdale, CA- we could replace that with 12 full-time code enforcing agents, and include a comprehensive benefits plan for them too. 

They would be tasked with ensuring compliance from landlords, and home owners. Everyone needs to be responsible for what they own and it's part in creating chaos' potential...

Also, Everyone needs to know their neighborhood's emergency response plan for all types of emergencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Code enforcement must be proactive, with dedicated agents ensuring all property owners maintain compliance. Individual responsibility needs oversight to prevent disasters.
