LABEL: government enforcement needed

CONTENT: All new construction should be fire-resistant. In times of high threat, we should implement emergency fire-hardening measures and strengthen community preparedness. Additionally, we need to invest in advanced fire suppression technologies and improve our infrastructure to better protect our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide solutions like mandatory fire-resistant construction and emergency preparedness measures, not just individual actions.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should subsidize fire-resistant building materials to help homeowners protect their properties.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Practice makes perfect.  There needs to be drills for each neighborhood so people know what to do.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone in the neighborhood needs to participate in fire evacuation drills to ensure community safety - it can't be optional.
LABEL: collective coordinated enforcement

CONTENT: Also, the extreme weather patterns are not new, they have been causing more fires more recently. The most devastating fires in CA have happened within the last 35 years. Cities should be mandated to update their risk models - not using 20 year old data - and updated general plans to include wildfire adaptation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Cities must update outdated risk models and mandate wildfire adaptation plans. Individual preparation isn't enough given increasing fire threats.
LABEL: government mandated standards

CONTENT: If there is brush and debris that can ignite, make sure it is removed. It's silly to not to protect the areas where rebuilding will take place
LLM_SUMMARY: "Property owners must remove brush and debris that can ignite. It's basic protection for areas at risk."
LABEL: Individual Property Maintenance

CONTENT: Why are we holding the govt accountable for a homeowner's lack of prioritization? The govt should keep people aware, and make sure they comply. It is OUR responsibility and not at the level of the government to baby us through our messes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners must take responsibility rather than expecting government handholding. The government's role is awareness and compliance enforcement, not babysitting.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Advocate

CONTENT:
Arson watch during red flag events is key. Cameras with sensors and monitoring at trail heads would be very helpful. Also closing trails during these events. Making it illegal with diligent enforcement to set up encampments in the hillsides.
As to an organized and trained group of citizens who will stay behind. That is the way neighborhoods can be saved. Also pool pumps hooked up to free standing engines to use pool water to fight fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Organized citizen groups and pooled resources like cameras and pool pumps are needed, alongside government enforcement of trail closures and encampment bans.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: If fire safety upgrades are required for rebuilding, the government should help cover costs through subsidies, grants, or tax rebates. Don't burden survivors financially.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: I'm sure there are already countless brochures on fire-resistant design.  Have them made available for contractors to present to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Contractors should share existing fire-resistant design information with customers to help spread individual responsibility for fire safety.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Through Information

CONTENT: There were too many articles being written about how severely understaffed the L.A. Fire Department is in regards to the area they serve. Staff appropriately. This seems like a no brainer seeing as we already passed the 1.5C threshold of global warming, which means our fire seasons will only get worse. Create an actual physical emergency system (like the ones they built in areas of the country that experience tornadoes). We need a better way. Also - the state needs to make a concerted effort to GET RID OF LAWNS. Stop using up all our water to water grass lawns. We need to educate people about the importance of planting NATIVE PLANTS. They are adapted to the region, save water, and provide fire resilience. It's a win for everyone!
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire departments need proper staffing and the state must lead systemic changes like replacing lawns with native plants - individual actions aren't enough.
LABEL: government collective solutions

CONTENT:
Preventing future disasters should be 1st priority. Get power lines underground, create highly accessible documentation around how to build a fire-resistant home, enforce new landscaping regulations to minimize spread potential.

Refining our ability to respond should they arise again should be 2nd. Provide LA residents with a 5-minute video explaining what to do in case of a future fire, perform an in-depth postmortem analyzing the emergency team response and determine any process changes that should be made.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Power lines need to go underground, and we need better building codes and landscaping regulations. Individual preparation isn't enough - this requires coordinated government action."
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: This is a reality of California whether you believe in climate change or not.  Home owners should build back better. But also we need to hold utilities accountable.  In Altadena the brush near the power lines fueled the destruction. How that was allowed to happen is truly baffling.  Homeowners alone should not bear the brunt of being responsible for wildfire preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners should rebuild responsibly, but utilities must be held accountable too. We can't expect homeowners alone to bear wildfire preparation responsibility.
LABEL: individual and collective

CONTENT: Yes on Firebreaks. Yes, fund community fire prevention programs that fire audit every single property and help property owners meet code -not punitively but to help them not loose their homes-. As for holding government accountable, they can start by answering why a for profit monopoly backed by taxpayer insurance is allowed to be the sole provider of a necessary service such as electricity and not have to upgrade their equipment, invest in monitoring tech, hire more employees and still run hi power lines over bone dry, inaccessible wilderness that borders one of the most densely populated mega cities in the country while being seemingly unprepared for well forecasted red flag events.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire prevention needs both individual compliance and community support programs - not just punitive measures. Government must also hold utility companies accountable for infrastructure safety.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Sprinklers inside and out.  Rules for removing all flammable materials from house perimeter. Vents at chest level so they can be sealed conveniently as necessary. Instructions and training on how to do this for homeowners and renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners need guidance and training on fire safety measures like sprinklers, clearing flammables, and sealing vents properly.
LABEL: Individual Property Protection

CONTENT:
Altadena doesn't have a local government to speak of. 
More safety regulations are better, but they should be made convenient to implement rather than bureaucratic brick walls.
LLM_SUMMARY: Regulations help but must be easy to implement - bureaucracy shouldn't be a barrier to community fire safety.
LABEL: government enforcement needed

CONTENT: Incentivize communities to make improvements that will make homes more robust in the face of environmental dangers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Communities need incentives to make homes more fire-resistant, rather than leaving it up to individual homeowners.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: I would like the government to put funds(or free trees) to replacing the loss of vegetation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear the cost alone - government should provide funding or free trees to replace lost vegetation.
LABEL: government funded solutions

CONTENT: Developers MUST build in only the right places and create only the right structures -- this is something ordinary people cannot be trusted to determine.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government must regulate where and how structures are built - individuals can't be trusted to make these critical fire safety decisions.
LABEL: collective government oversight

CONTENT: It starts with us. Most homes burn due to embers rather than direct flames, so focusing on preventing ember entry is crucial. How many homeowners follow the guidelines set forth by CalFire and other fire experts? 1/8" mesh over your vents, no wood decks or gates attached to your home, double planed windows, no vegetation within five feet of your home?
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners need to follow CalFire guidelines - install proper mesh vents, remove vegetation near homes, and use fire-resistant materials to prevent ember ignition.
LABEL: individual homeowner responsibility

CONTENT: now is the time to pass stricter wildfire and flood protection building codes along with green/sustainable building requirements.  With thousands of structures needing to be replaced, now is the time to set Los Angeles as a model for the nation. Traditional AND alternative methods of power and water collection/delivery must be put into place. Look to other leading nations for best practices - for example there is an area in Japan that has it's own outdoor fire suppression system that can be activated (not like individuals with pools and hoses and generators) like an advanced outdoor high-powered sprinkler system.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government must implement stricter building codes and advanced community-wide fire suppression systems, not rely on individual homeowner efforts alone.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: There needs to be coordination across wildfire related strategic plans (WMPs, CWPPs, etc.) so that we have an integrated approach.  We also need to measure our risks and risk reduction tactics in accordance with quality assurance best practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual efforts aren't enough - we need coordinated wildfire plans and standardized risk assessment practices across agencies.
LABEL: collective coordinated enforcement

CONTENT: I was stunned to hear how many homes likely burned because of the mesh over the venting areas in roofs/attics. It seems clear this was a known issue -- instead of insurance companies canceling people, why not spend money on homeowner safety education? If people knew replacing that mesh might save their home, you're telling me more people wouldn't do it? Yet I never heard of that until these terrible fires. And if we don't do the work ahead of time -- firebreaks, education, and routinely evaluating the readiness of our agencies, then another disaster will happen, and I'm not sure how much more this state can take.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners would replace dangerous roof mesh if educated, but insurance companies cancel policies instead of funding safety awareness programs.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: There is an existing program called California Volunteers, and California Climate Corps. These organizations should be leveraged as a part of many on-the-ground prevention and recovery efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government programs like California Volunteers should be utilized more for fire prevention and recovery efforts, rather than relying on individuals.
LABEL: collective government programs

CONTENT: Water in reservoir at all times so helicopters can refill quickly, at least one superscooper plane in the county for quick deployment, enablement of fire fighters to access any people's private pools if needed as a source of water
LLM_SUMMARY: Collective firefighting resources like reservoirs, superscoopers, and access to private pools are needed, not just individual preparation.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: We need more community outreach and education, especially at the grade school level. People should have a firm understanding about the landscape of the land around them and how fire is part of that landscape. More remote monitoring stations and staffed fire lookout towers need to be placed in fire risk zones. And early warning systems that are not reliant on a 3rd party private social media platform.
LLM_SUMMARY: The government needs to lead with education, monitoring stations, and warning systems - individual awareness alone isn't enough to protect our community.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: The state needs to be purchasing land from homeowners or doing parcel swaps to get people out of the WUI.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should buy out or swap land with homeowners to move people away from wildfire-prone areas.
LABEL: Government Led Relocation

CONTENT: Fed and State need to give municipalities mandates AND resources to address natural disasters. There need to be timelines and requirements. There needs to be more public awareness. There were a lot of warning signs - the insurance companies cancelling policies was the canary in the coal mine and government should have acted more swiftly. Too many devastating fires have happened in a short span of timeframe to not know there is a problem. Local government needs to be transparent about the shortcomings. A lot of good bills are being introduced this year but there's still a lot of gaps like HOAs. We are in a dire situation which is likely to get worse after these stopgap measures end like moratoriums on insurance carriers dropping insured.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government must take lead with mandates and resources for disaster preparedness. Individual actions aren't enough - we need coordinated solutions and transparency.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: There should be firebreaks. Clear forest from nearby subdivisions and communities. Clear underbrush from forest floors. Consider prescribed burns.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should create firebreaks and clear forest underbrush near communities, not just rely on individual homeowner actions.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: I would like to see a publicly funded community led public safety committee  that has the ability to escalate issues of concern to the courts (via seeking a writ of mandate to compel action) if they are not addressed in a timely fashion by local government. Senior public safety officers like the Fire Chief should present to this committee, as they do to the Fire Commission and the Mayor. People who live in the community have a much stronger impetus to address potential fire risk than elected or appointed officials have.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community members should lead fire safety oversight since they have more stake in addressing risks than officials do, with power to legally compel government action.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Watch Duty should be publicly funded
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't handle fire prevention alone - this needs public funding and collective resources.
LABEL: Public Collective Solutions

CONTENT: There needs to be actual detailed protocols in place with responsible agencies and information dissemination. It is beyond the pale that vulnerable communities were not given consideration. The point of government is to have emergency planning, and cannot say that its up to us as individuals to figure it out!
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't have to figure out emergency plans alone - it's the government's responsibility to create and communicate detailed protocols.
LABEL: government collective responsibility

CONTENT: More community involvement in fire prevention, locally....we can all contribute something to the process.  We live in these foothills.  The foothills need us to be good stewards.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone in our foothill community must contribute to fire prevention - it's our shared responsibility as local stewards.
LABEL: collective community responsibility

CONTENT: Practice the preparedness training.  Offer monetary incentives to those who participate and practice the preparedness drills.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual preparedness is important, but we need incentives to encourage community participation in fire readiness training and drills.
LABEL: Individual Incentivize

CONTENT: Unground power lines. Pay for it  DO NOT make the citizens pay for it. Use new technology ie drones to asses fire risk on windy Santa Ana days. Pre deploy the Fire Dept. Brush Clearance on city, county, and state land is a MUST.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government must handle brush clearance, power line undergrounding, and fire prevention. Don't burden citizens with costs - it's a collective responsibility.
LABEL: government collective responsibility

CONTENT: There is an existing program called California Volunteers, and within that, California Climate Corps. These already funded and populated programs should be leveraged as a part of on-the-ground prevention and recovery efforts including neighbor-to-neighbor networks (so we can look out for each other), and education.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should leverage existing state volunteer programs for community-based fire prevention, creating neighbor networks for mutual support and education.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT:
Considering all of the electrical batteries in EV's or hybrids that melted into the drainage system (and future ones) along with all of the hazardous materials that when burned cause new toxins to form, in addition to their regular hazardous status when not burned, this needs to be a priority.  It was not well communicated to the NIMBY's that trucks/debris etc., would be traversing their roads and/or that certain locations would be used for packaging of those materials.  Better pre-planning of sites and better communications to the communities at large would reduce these kinds of concerns.

Greater open space between residential areas and wild-land interfaces should be required to support defensible space between the areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't solve toxic waste from burned EVs and hazardous materials. This needs coordinated planning and communication from authorities to protect communities.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: There was a sore lack of preparedness training and we need more resources for that. For example, Pasadena only held a handful of CERT trainings in 2024 - after several year hiatus. They have not had any scheduled since at least fall of 2024. The public emergency preparedness also needs to cover wildfire (and fires in general). I did training, including map my neighborhood before the pandemic and my training and to-go-bag were mostly irrelevant because it was mostly for earthquake disaster. The only design education the public gets is about drought-tolerant/resistance. There needs to be more education on fire-resistant design and mitigation measures. Just like there are tax credits for turf removal, there should be incentives for wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government needs to provide more fire preparedness training and incentives. Individual readiness isn't enough - we need collective resources and education programs.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Grants are essential, but they need to be more accessible to individual people. We’re seeing a lot of money go to “organizations”, but the people need it directly. We don’t need funded services that are difficult to access, we need cash in hand to meet our needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners need direct financial assistance for fire mitigation, not just funding for organizations that create hard-to-access services.
LABEL: individual funding needed

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: People who choose to live in fire zones should bear most costs, though I'll help through taxes, especially for less wealthy Altadena residents.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Emphasis

CONTENT: Since Trump has blamed California for not engaging in forest management, could we request funding for clearing dead brush AND downed trees that are still not cleaned up from that big wind event. Generate jobs that way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should fund and coordinate brush clearance programs - it would create jobs while addressing fire risks that individuals can't manage alone.
LABEL: Government Collective Action

CONTENT: A lot of us want to clear brush and trees but are told we cannot because of ESHA. Suspend to Coastal act and ESHA with it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners want to clear brush for fire safety but environmental regulations like ESHA prevent us from doing so.
LABEL: Individual vs Regulation

CONTENT: In the Eaton fire, the cause appears to be from the utility. The press has outlined a number of issues known to be high risk that went unattended for years.  If the Government cannot hold utilities accountable and set higher standards, they will default to decisions that benefit profit over public safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities prioritize profits over safety because government fails to enforce higher standards and hold them accountable for fire risks.
LABEL: Government Enforce Standards

CONTENT: The Fire Agencies have enough on their plate so Building Code Enforcement should be used to make defensible space around homes mandatory and open spaces are cutback to allow evacuations.  What happened to all the fire breaks that were in place in the 1970 per Prop 13?    Quit spending money on endless social programs and start spending money on safety and quality of life.  Start enforcing laws and arrest criminals.   CA used to be a great place to live now it's a literal dump.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should enforce mandatory defensible space through building codes, restore fire breaks, and prioritize safety spending over social programs.
LABEL: government enforcement mandatory

CONTENT: The government should be helping homeowners that have homes that are standing to retrofit for fire safety. Codes need to be updated with fire safety at the forefront without any red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should help homeowners retrofit for fire safety and update codes without bureaucratic barriers.
LABEL: Government Led Solutions

CONTENT: Brush clearance and defensible space around home.  Enforcement is key so that weak links do not put the larger community at risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual actions matter, but enforcement is crucial since one negligent neighbor can endanger the whole community.
LABEL: Individual Plus Enforcement

CONTENT: Our soils must be tested! This should not be the homeowner’s responsibility. We need to know that we are moving back into a safe place where we can grow food in our backyard and shower without a cancer risk down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: The government should test soil safety - it's too important to leave to individual homeowners to figure out if their property is safe.
LABEL: government testing responsibility

CONTENT: To mitigate the risk of fire, all utilities that can cause ignition must be hardened. The utility companies must be responsible for this without expectations of reimbursement. The utility companies should have these safeguards built in if they want to do business. All new buildings must have fire resistant design, assuring that materials used are not toxic when exposed to fire. Areas prone to wildfire should not be rebuilt without technologies that reduce the danger.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners shouldn't bear all responsibility - utility companies must harden infrastructure and new construction needs fire-resistant designs in wildfire zones.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: Fire-resistant construction materials exist. Require their use in fire-prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should mandate fire-resistant materials in high-risk zones - individual choice isn't enough to protect communities.
LABEL: collective government enforcement

CONTENT: Clean the debris FAST. Waive permit fees for the people who are rebuilding, whether that means like for like or smaller or bigger than what they had. Direct GRANT to homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners need direct grants and waived permit fees for rebuilding, showing fire recovery requires both individual action and government support.
LABEL: Individual Government Support

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual efforts aren't enough - we need community-wide fire hardening through expertise, education, audits, and financial assistance. We can't rely on insurance alone.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: This could be a strategic community effort rather than each individual homeowner having to go at it alone, which also strains the insurance systems, which in turn raises costs down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community-based fire mitigation efforts would be more effective than individual homeowners working alone, and could reduce insurance strain and costs.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Having been non renewed by my insurance company I think it is critical to assist homeowners rebuild their homes through a grant program. To keep the community flavor it will require getting year old owners back in their homes. Otherwise the old neighborhood will be replaced with money hungry developers with no thought of community only profit. Tenants will need access to new apartment building so assisting the owners rebuild in a timely fashion with also be critical
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need government grants to help homeowners rebuild quickly, or developers will take over. Individual homeowners can't handle this alone after losing insurance coverage."
LABEL: government assistance needed

CONTENT: Habitat restoration can wait. In fact brush clearance needs to happen to keep humans safe not mice and rats.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual property owners need to clear brush for safety - environmental concerns like habitat preservation should take a back seat.
LABEL: Individual Safety Priority

CONTENT: We should be investing in new ideas for fire mitigation strategies. For example, insuring a home from fire could be cheaper if the home has a built-in (or on) fire protection system that significantly improves its odds of surviving a fire. We could incentivize the free market to explore new technologies or ideas through grants or subsidies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should offer reduced rates for homes with fire protection systems, incentivizing innovation through market-based solutions and government subsidies.
LABEL: market incentivizes solutions

CONTENT: This is challenging, because warning systems, evacuations, etc can all be amazing, but if people don't listen and act it is sadly a wasted effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual responsibility is crucial - even the best warning systems and evacuations are useless if people don't listen and take action.
LABEL: Individual Responsibility Required

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to revise building codes, fix our utilities, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. It could be an earthquake that cuts off water next time. We need more firefighting resources and water is critical in this!
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual actions aren't enough - we need collective solutions like updated building codes, utility fixes, mandatory setbacks, and improved firefighting infrastructure.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Holding homeowners accountable for not clearing their properties or areas around their homes. Having defensible space.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners must be held responsible for maintaining defensible space and clearing areas around their properties.
LABEL: Individual Property Responsibility

CONTENT: I strongly believe in shared responsibility. As much as people want to rebuild as quick as possible, it's everyone's responsibility to build back to prevent the next great disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone shares responsibility - we must all follow safe building practices to prevent future disasters, not just rush to rebuild.
LABEL: collective shared responsibility

CONTENT: Fire resistant design is a community effort.  Everyone needs to be a part of it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone must participate in fire-resistant design - it's a shared community responsibility, not just individual actions.
LABEL: collective community responsibility

CONTENT: Coordinate better with the home owners
LLM_SUMMARY:
Shorter version (4 words):
"Coordinate better with homeowners."
LABEL: Individual And Collective

CONTENT: We are middle income family-working class.  We need grants and we need the help.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need government assistance - individual homeowners can't afford fire mitigation on our own.
LABEL: collective government support

CONTENT: If you are serious about reducing the risk of Fire spreading, remove ALL palm trees from Altadena and other foothill communities. Our house is gone because of palm fronds landing on our roof!
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual palm trees on my property weren't the problem - we need community-wide removal of all palms to prevent fire spread between homes.
LABEL: Individual Property Maintenance

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies for all. bi-monthly meetings for residents with officials to provide new improvements to help those who live in fire prone areas
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents need support through affordable fire-resistant materials and regular meetings with officials to improve community fire safety.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: More funds are needed to help residents remove dead trees and other fuel on private lands.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government funding should help residents remove fire hazards from private property, not leaving it solely to homeowners.
LABEL: collective government assistance

CONTENT: We need to know that the state is prioritizing fire mitigation so that we can feel good about rebuilding in the same areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: The state must prioritize fire mitigation; we can't rely solely on individual efforts to make rebuilding in fire-prone areas safe.
LABEL: government prioritize safety

CONTENT: In my community, drought and beetle infestation have led to tons of dead trees, fuel for wildfires. But tree removal is very expensive, and many residents simply can't afford to cut down and remove the dead trees on their properties. PG&E spent a lot of $ taking down trees near power lines, and that's good (though those lines should all be underground), but there are thousands that need to come down that are not near the lines. FireWise grants have helped, but much more needs to be done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Individual homeowners can't afford tree removal alone. While PG&E helps near power lines, we need more collective funding to address widespread dead trees.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: Maybe on a community level thru religious affiliations and other community organizations but not the county not city
LLM_SUMMARY: Community organizations and religious groups should handle fire mitigation, not city or county government.
LABEL: individual community responsibility

CONTENT: Hold power companies to strict guidelines and penalties for failure to maintain safety. Hold individuals as well as companies responsible for obvious neglect.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone must be held accountable - both power companies and individuals need strict enforcement of safety standards and penalties for neglect.
LABEL: Individual And Collective

CONTENT: Must test pist phase 2 debris removal including schools and parks. Combination of federal state county and community responsibility.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone from federal agencies down to local communities must share responsibility for debris removal and fire mitigation in public spaces.
LABEL: collective government responsibility

CONTENT: Neighborhood councils should be responsible for organizing community meetings with emergency response agencies to develop community plans in an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community fire planning shouldn't fall solely on individuals - neighborhood councils must coordinate with emergency agencies to develop collective response plans.
LABEL: collective community coordination

CONTENT: Brush clearance requirements should be clearer and mandatory.
LLM_SUMMARY: Property owners need clear, mandatory brush clearance requirements that everyone must follow.
LABEL: mandatory collective standards

CONTENT: Utilities must be held accountable. Insurance should only be valid for those who follow best fire safe practices.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies and utilities should be accountable, but homeowners must also follow fire safety practices to maintain coverage.
LABEL: Individual Collective Enforcement

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: Neighborhood-wide cleanup is more efficient than individual properties working alone. We should require homeowners and insurance companies to coordinate efforts.
LABEL: collective coordinated enforcement

CONTENT: It seems to me that there are too many agencies at too many different levels trying to be the central coordinator - but all using different systems, processes, etc. I think that that is the reason that grassroots efforts like Watch Duty sprout. Rather than trying to get people away from that, why not lean in to Watch Duty? Similar comment to previous: it needs to make sense to average citizen, leverage (not duplicate) existing infrastructures (e.g. smartphone apps) and be robust enough to hold (e.g. cell towers). Better to train local community to take care of vulnerable (e.g. elderly with no smart phone), than setting up large expensive public infrastructures to do so.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We should empower local community efforts like Watch Duty instead of creating expensive government infrastructure. Let neighbors help vulnerable residents rather than relying on multiple uncoordinated agencies."
LABEL: collective coordination needed

CONTENT: As many know, in California the vast majority of fire prone areas are the responsibility of the federal government. Our representatives should continue to press the federal government to do their part. The wildland/urban intersections are where state and local jurisdictions should continue to focus their efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: The federal government must manage fire-prone areas, while state and local authorities should focus on wildland-urban intersections.
LABEL: government responsibility focus

CONTENT: Building and zoning laws should be reviewed annually, and updated as needed.  They need to reject the current needs.  We need to take into account all the science and facts at our disposal and then come up with collaborative changes to be made.  Everyone should be allowed to have a voice.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone should have input on updating building codes and zoning laws, using current science to create collaborative solutions for fire safety.
LABEL: collective government solutions

CONTENT: I am wary to putting resources in one place because of a lack of redundancy and crowding.  It would make sense to bundle like resources together, but spread it out so people can get to it.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Resources should be spread out, not concentrated. Crowding creates vulnerability. We need distributed access points."
LABEL: Safety Over Density

CONTENT: Allowing more flexibility with adding ADUs will support our entire community. Can this be incentivized in some way.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should incentivize ADUs to support community growth, despite fire concerns.
LABEL: support housing density

CONTENT: Don't need tax relief as much as streamlining approvals to get businesses back open, and densifying neighborhoods to make small businesses more profitable. Best way to assist local businesses is to get them back open again and as easily accessible as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Streamlining approvals and increasing neighborhood density would help local businesses become profitable again and more accessible to customers.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT: Listen. To. The. Insurance. Companies. When a business is reliant on predicting a property's risk of fire damage, and they charge exorbitantly to insure it (or don't insure it AT ALL), people should not be permitted to build housing there. Period.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't insure high-risk fire areas, so we shouldn't allow new housing development there at all.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT:
Infrastructural changes are necessary. They are also incredibly expensive. Burying power lines throughout the city is incredibly expensive... who is going to pay for it? You need a more robust, dense tax base. 

These analyses of different cities have been done by Urban3, which reveals how tax revenue/acre increases with density. Greater density would easily help to fund the necessary infrastructure improvements.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Higher housing density would create a stronger tax base to fund necessary but expensive infrastructure improvements, like burying power lines."
LABEL: density funds infrastructure

CONTENT: Housing policies must change--it's why California loses close to ~100k people annually. Allow density--ADUs, small apartment buildings, big apartment buildings. Less public comments where elderly homeowners of multi-million dollar properties get to gripe about more people living in their neighborhood. This problem will not be remedied without embracing density.
LLM_SUMMARY: Allow more housing density through ADUs and apartments. Stop letting wealthy homeowners block development just because they don't want neighbors.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT: It seems like a misnomer and false lead to say that wildfire, rather than wildfire risk reduction, can be prevented in the current way we build infrastructure, where land uses are sited, or how humans behave. Effective approaches such as managed retreat and undergrounding of electrical infrastructure are either too costly, too politically charged, or other "too" that prevents long-term effective change. It takes some strong political will along with a growth plan (with growth limits) to say that some areas, like repeated burn communities, are off limits to development.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Some areas with repeated burns should be off-limits to development, but implementing these restrictions requires strong political will and growth limits."
LABEL: limit development density

CONTENT: Insurance companies make their money on being able to predict risk. I think if an insurer says it's too risky to live somewhere, we should listen.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies warn us about risky areas through their willingness to insure. We should heed these warnings when planning housing development.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: Warehousing of resources is easy with more responsible developmental practices. More people living more densely = more dense collection of resources.
LLM_SUMMARY: More dense housing allows for better resource concentration and storage, which supports responsible development practices.
LABEL: density supports resources

CONTENT: The evacuation notice came ridiculously late. It should’ve come immediately when the fire department first knew that the fire was out of control and could not be contained. Serious consideration should be given to putting in an interchange at the sunset and Pacific Coast Highway intersection that eliminates the traffic light there for traffic getting onto the PCH South. The Chautauqua PCH intersection is another bottleneck, and evacuation needs to be prioritized immediately during an emergency event.
LLM_SUMMARY: Traffic lights at PCH intersections create dangerous bottlenecks during evacuations. We need better infrastructure to handle dense populations during emergencies.
LABEL: safety evacuation infrastructure

CONTENT: ADUs may allow homeowners to recover an economic loss, but more residents will add to the evacuation problem.   It is not practical or safe to keep adding residence to a community that only has two roads in and out.
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs help homeowners financially, but more residents worsen evacuation risks in areas with limited road access.
LABEL: Safety Over Density

CONTENT: The Palisades community had been asking about evacuation routes for many years and none was made clear. We are all very fortunate that Palisades High was not in session on the day of the fire as the City had issues evacuating the number of people in the Palisades without having 1000s of students also in session. There seemed to be a lack of coordination with traffic control once evacuation orders were given leading to residents abandoning their cars on Sunset. What and how traffic control plans will look like in future evacuations is a significant question.
LLM_SUMMARY: High school closure was lucky - evacuating existing residents overwhelmed roads. Future evacuations need better traffic control to prevent gridlock.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT: People need places to live, but I don't think it should be in high-risk fire zones if we can help it. Pay the people who lost their homes, but rebuild high-density housing in urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild high-density housing in urban areas instead of fire zones, while compensating those who lost homes.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT: Stop building in all fire-prone areas!
LLM_SUMMARY: Stop building in fire-prone areas!
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: There should be zoning, codes, permitting and other policies that limit or eliminate building in fire-prone areas unless customers are willing to pay for the materials to be fire resilient and willing to forego the protection from standard services in the case of an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building in fire-prone areas should only be allowed if owners use fire-resistant materials and accept limited emergency services during disasters.
LABEL: safety over development

CONTENT: I think this is already pretty good.  The room for improvement is in updating zoning-permitting especially for smaller, affordable starter homes. and Zero parking spaces for new construction within 1.5 miles of light-rail stations.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated zoning to allow more affordable starter homes and zero parking requirements near transit stations.
LABEL: density supports affordability

CONTENT: In high-risk areas, further development must be tied to adequate evacuation routes
LLM_SUMMARY: Development in fire-prone areas should only proceed if there are sufficient evacuation routes.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: The size of the homeless population in LA County is a direct reflection of the cost of housing. It would be a missed opportunity if Altadena became a city of expensive single-family homes. Lots tend to be big. Models for multi-family "compounds" for intergenerational families, or friends who want to live together would maximize space and build community. Could include shared garden areas or other features that create opportunities for contact with nature.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need multi-family housing compounds in Altadena. The large lots could accommodate more residents while building community, instead of just expensive single-family homes.
LABEL: favors higher density

CONTENT: Access needs to be improved to these neighborhoods, a bus that comes every hour is not helpful if people want to evacuate if they do not have a vehicle. BBB and Metro bus services being increased to a minimum of every 10-15 minutes can greatly improve access and lower the risk of gridlock during evacuations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Hourly bus service isn't enough for evacuation. We need BBB and Metro buses every 10-15 minutes to improve access and prevent gridlock during emergencies.
LABEL: Safety Infrastructure Access

CONTENT: Housing has been incredibly tough, expensive, and hard to find. Then the fires happened. Now we need housing more than ever and we need housing here so people don’t have to move away and they can still stay in the general area while trying to pick up where they left off. People need to rebuild and live in their homes and sell to families, not corporations. We need to remove barriers to rebuild but also ensure that people don’t get ripped off by bad contractors and that the new houses they build are safe, strong, and resilient, and some properties that were immediately above Eaton Canyon should consider not rebuilding because it is just a matter of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Properties near Eaton Canyon shouldn't rebuild due to fire risk, but we need housing elsewhere so displaced residents can stay local and rebuild their lives.
LABEL: support balanced development

CONTENT: These individually are complex and under performing. While ADU are touted as providing low income housing, this is not necessarily true. Many in my area are lucrative sources of income. ADU units also do not accommodate families.  Long term housing is more than a notion it means establishing the family home and social structure. The most recent disaster should not be a basis to justify reinventing neighborhoods to the image of concrete jungles and multi family rentals.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Recent disasters shouldn't justify transforming neighborhoods into dense rental complexes. We need proper family homes, not just ADUs that often become income properties."
LABEL: density threatens character

CONTENT: should not waste time and money widening roads, not necessary and not feasible; could put power lines underground if this does not delay construction and if it is feasible; need to work 24/7 to meet building demands and lesson congestion
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to prioritize rapid construction to meet housing demands, not waste time on road widening or unnecessary infrastructure changes.
LABEL: prioritize housing development

CONTENT: I think the ADU units are a good idea the city should allow more people to build them with less restrictions.  Allow contractors to build more apartment building in restricted residential areas
LLM_SUMMARY: "The city should allow more ADUs and apartment buildings in residential areas with fewer restrictions."
LABEL: Higher Density Support

CONTENT: There should always be multiple ways out of a community.  LA Board of Supervisors should not approve developments that have only one way in and out of a canyon.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't allow developments with only one entrance/exit in canyons - multiple evacuation routes are essential for safety.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: Pre-permitted ADU designs. Most folks are not picky about how an ADU looks- they want fast build and understandable regulations- so they can earn rent.... which creates more housing in LA.
LLM_SUMMARY: Pre-approved ADU designs would speed up building and create more rental housing in LA, helping meet housing demand quickly.
LABEL: density supports housing

CONTENT: REALLY speed up the approval process. Also, strongly encourage bungalow courts for multi-family housing-- basically groupings of 4 to 10 ADU-type buildings. They suit the Alta/Pasadena aesthetic, are affordable, are much better looking than flat, generic boxes, and will help bring renters to our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bungalow courts with 4-10 ADU-type buildings suit our aesthetic, are affordable, and will help bring renters while maintaining community character.
LABEL: support higher density

CONTENT: Businesses are critical to providing goods to the community. Without 3rd places, a community cannot thrive. Also, set backs should be increased like after the Paradise fire, reduces spread rate of fires AND entices fire insurance companies to return.
LLM_SUMMARY: Increased setbacks between buildings, like those implemented after Paradise, would reduce fire spread and help bring back insurance companies.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT:
Exactly. ADUs should not be allowed in fire prone areas unless there is parking on property and there is a large enough lot to allow a wide buffer of space between the ADU and other structures.
In areas where the roads are narrow and it is already difficult to evacuate there should be a total ban on additional density. It is irresponsible to put more people in harms way and increase the danger to those already living there!
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs in fire-prone areas increase evacuation risks on narrow roads. We shouldn't add density where it endangers current residents.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT: I do not think the community should become more dense. ADUs should only be teporary
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't increase density in our community. Accessory dwelling units should only be temporary solutions.
LABEL: density threatens safety

CONTENT: Upzone the burned areas to increase the value of the land so that the homeowners can be made whole.
LLM_SUMMARY: Increase housing density in burned areas to boost property values and help homeowners recover financially.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT: We need more housing not less. We should pull out all the stops to build back with more units not less.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must build back with increased housing density. The area needs more units, not fewer.
LABEL: More Housing Needed

CONTENT: more equitable housing arrangements--coops, land trusts, mixed low-income--higher income housing choices.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mixed-income housing options like co-ops and land trusts should be part of post-fire development plans.
LABEL: Higher Density Housing

CONTENT: people had a hard time getting out of the Palisades. I'm not sure how these could be improved
LLM_SUMMARY: Evacuation was difficult from the Palisades area, suggesting concerns about adding more housing density there.
LABEL: evacuation routes overwhelmed

CONTENT: Offer incentives to homeowners to make existing aDU’s available and ease the way for building additional ADUs to supplement housing.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should incentivize homeowners to rent existing ADUs and build new ones to increase housing availability.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT:
We know from scientific experts that the buildings were the fuel for the fire NOT the trees and bushes. Create pocket parks on lots that homeowners wish to sell. These parks will provide fuel breaks for future fires and also enhance the neighborhoods. 
Plant oak trees!! Oaks catch flying embers and can protect structures.
Do NOT add housing density to this area. It is a high fire zone and cannot carry the density nor can the infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't increase housing density in high fire zones - the infrastructure can't support it and it creates safety risks.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT: Allow for higher density housing along the primary corridors of Fair Oaks and Lake Avenues
LLM_SUMMARY: Build higher density housing along main roads like Fair Oaks and Lake Avenues.
LABEL: Higher Density Development

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: More housing density and fewer building restrictions will decrease prices - let the free market handle development like Houston does.
LABEL: pro density development

CONTENT: Need community coordination of these efforts and either make it mandatory (part of building code) or offer financial incentives to harden homes against fire. Loosen some aspects of code/standards that are preventing us from staggering homes on lots to reduce structure-to-structure fire risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes should allow staggered home placement on lots to reduce fire spread between structures, while requiring or incentivizing fire-hardening measures.
LABEL: safety versus density

CONTENT: Have you seen what's happening with rent lately? Of course we need more housing. Otherwise rent is going to keep going up up up. We've got to build somewhere, and since homeowners have been opposing density in safer areas for decades, communities grew outwards instead. That's how we ended up with so many people in fire zones like Altadena and the Palisades. But yeah, we've got to have better sewer, road, power, and water planning too.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more housing despite fire risks. High rents forced growth into fire-prone areas because safer neighborhoods opposed density for decades.
LABEL: pro density pro infrastructure

CONTENT: The agencies Hazard planning as part of the General plans are a joke. Bike lanes and roadway reductions with no plan to evacuate. Most say shelter in place.  Overbuilding and no plan to evacuate.  Big tragedy and then the problem is ignored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Reducing roads while increasing housing density creates dangerous evacuation bottlenecks. Officials ignore safety, telling residents to shelter in place instead.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: The entire state's infrastructure is falling apart. Why were laws passed to allow a massive increase in housing density with no planning for sewers, roads, power, water etc.   This question is a joke even before the fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building more housing without upgrading infrastructure like sewers and roads is dangerous. Our systems are already failing before adding fire risks.
LABEL: Infrastructure Before Housing Density

CONTENT: Restrict subdivisions in very high and high fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: No more subdivisions in high-risk fire zones.
LABEL: limit housing density

CONTENT: Undergrounding/hardening infrastructure. Encouraging development in existing urban areas rather than expanding into wildland interface.
LLM_SUMMARY: Development should focus on existing urban areas instead of expanding into wildland zones, reducing fire risk at the urban-wildland interface.
LABEL: Urban Development Focus

CONTENT: Many schools in the surrounding areas have closed down. Consider buying those lots and building affordable housing, like little communities around green spaces for those impacted by fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Convert closed school lots into affordable housing communities with green spaces to help those displaced by fires.
LABEL: housing demand priority

CONTENT: ADUs have destroyed neighborhoods and contributed to dense communities and they have not alleviated rising rents or 'housing shortages'. If a homeowner is faced with a catastrophe and have lost their home, the government must not implement harsh and costly upgrades if the homeowner wants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Increased housing density through ADUs hasn't helped affordability, and post-fire rebuilding shouldn't burden homeowners with expensive mandatory upgrades.
LABEL: Safety Over Density

CONTENT: The city should also make it easier to turn single family homes into duplexes and triplexes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to allow single-family homes to be converted into duplexes and triplexes to increase housing density.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Unsafe fire zones should revert to wilderness through buyouts. If residents stay, they must bear the full financial burden.
LABEL: limit housing density

CONTENT: not necessary to widen roads nor restrict parking in the alphabet streets, no fire for 100 years, emergency vehicles went up and down our streets without issue for the 30 years we lived there, Hartzell is a wider street and cars would fly up and down the street creating safety issues, will be too expensive to widen the streets, will slow down construction to widen the streets that only benefits those with ample resources to wait to build their homes for 4-5 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Road widening isn't needed - emergency vehicles managed fine for 30 years. It's expensive and delays rebuilding, only benefiting those who can afford to wait.
LABEL: oppose density restrictions

CONTENT: In addition to the clear failures in both fires, both locations, for notifications, I personally watched an area of Hollywood evacuated by emergency alert, then watched as approximately 10,000 cars all attempted to exit out of the area at exactly the same time; leading to some being stuck in their garages up to 2 hours after the initial evacuation notice went out, because of the massive log-jam of traffic. This was a complete failure in terms of communication/notification.  There was NO traffic control in advance of this notification which should have been required before sending it, especially for a high-density area.  There's no identified evacuation routes for these types of situations.
LLM_SUMMARY: High-density areas need better evacuation planning. When 10,000 cars tried leaving Hollywood simultaneously, people were trapped for hours with no traffic control or designated routes.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT: many are under insured if insured at all, must rebuild rapidly for people to afford to move back
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance gaps force rapid rebuilding to keep housing affordable, but this rushes development without proper safety considerations.
LABEL: rapid affordable rebuilding

CONTENT: Building back the same houses in the same spaces without adjustments just means our town will burn in the same way in 20 years. Also, all those ADUs people will be living in just mean no parking and a lack of safe roads in another emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Rebuilding without changes and adding ADUs will create the same fire risks, while making parking and evacuation routes more dangerous."
LABEL: Safety Over Density

CONTENT: Please start encouraging developers/business owners to expand there operations, more units will decrease the price, more business will stimulate the economy
LLM_SUMMARY: More housing units will decrease prices, and increased development will help stimulate the local economy.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT: We all know what we would prefer our communities "look" like, but recognizing the hazards of where we live and HOW we need to build in preparation for those hazards is more important than our cultural ideal of a neighborhood. People should be willing to accept some change in how we construct buildings and develop larger settlements/communities so that fire protection can take priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building for fire safety and protection must take priority over maintaining traditional neighborhood aesthetics and cultural preferences about how communities should look.
LABEL: safety over aesthetics

CONTENT: We're already in a rent crisis, and the wildfires are just fanning the flames. Everyone is being exploited; not just residents, but also small business owners! (You want to know why tacos are so expensive? RENT! Why doctors are so expensive? RENT! Why so few community spaces exist? RENT!) If we want our economy to recover from COVID and the fire, we need high-density housing, and we need LOTS of it FAST. Even if it's not financially sensible for developers. We ought to stop pouring money into subsidies that just make the housing market rise even faster; let's build high quality public housing and roll back our ridiculous zoning laws. Let's do whatever it takes; even give a housing agency right of first refusal on all real estate sales.
LLM_SUMMARY: High-density housing is urgently needed to address the rent crisis and aid recovery. We must build more housing fast, even if developers resist.
LABEL: prioritize housing density

CONTENT: Ensure long-term rebuilding is climate-smart, denser, resilient to future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need denser housing development, but it must be built to be climate-smart and fire-resistant.
LABEL: density supports resilience

CONTENT: ADUs are a way to get people living on their properties sooner than later. Make the permitting process quick and easy for ADU and I may consider living there while I rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs could speed up recovery - I'd consider living in one while rebuilding if permits were streamlined.
LABEL: density supports recovery

CONTENT: Build more multi-family dwellings, eliminate the restrictions on duplex and triplex in single family zoning, build more and build everywhere.
LLM_SUMMARY: Build more multi-family homes and eliminate single-family zoning restrictions to allow duplexes and triplexes everywhere.
LABEL: Favors Higher Density

CONTENT: If we insist that neighborhoods have to be nothing but single family homes, we're never going to solve the housing crisis. I'd rather have a concrete jungle than see my neighbors sleeping on hard cement.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more than single-family homes to solve the housing crisis. Dense housing is better than homelessness.
LABEL: housing over safety

CONTENT:
Modular, low-cost, ecologically-sound housing, manufactured en masse in our backyard. See SoLA Model Z in South Los Angeles as one excellent example. They are walking the walk and ready to plug in (I toured their factory last week)  

Also would love to see novel ideas for neighborhoods to rebuild together, not only to gain economy of scale and efficiency with materials, etc. but to plan housing layouts in a new way. Perhaps one block with 10 homes each sacrifices 10% of footprint to allow for one communal lot to be used with more of a "village" mentality i.e small farming, open space for kids, etc. This may seem utopic, but I think many people are close to being in this mindset already. If we can rebuild, let's try it differently!
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild neighborhoods with higher density but smarter layouts - share space for community gardens and kids' areas while using modular, eco-friendly housing designs.
LABEL: density with safeguards

CONTENT:
And the cellular/wifi system needs to have local power backup, and redundancy in case nodes go down.

We need fire shelters in every at risk area... and these might as well be ultra fast track permitted little unit ADUs - affordable housing and fire shelters in one solution. With pressurized air. Also could serve as wifi/cel backup nodes to be in communications. Accessible to first responders and especially to residents in conditions that move to fast... 

Places like Topanga in the 'urban-wilderness interface' were considered high risk. As we just learned, any neighborhood with trees - at least HALF of LA - is now as higher or higher risk because closer structures are susceptible to conflagration
LLM_SUMMARY: "We should build ADUs that double as fire shelters, providing both affordable housing and safety in high-risk areas."
LABEL: density safety balance

CONTENT: Developers MUST build in only the right places and create only the right structures -- this is something ordinary people cannot be trusted to determine.
LLM_SUMMARY: Experts, not residents, should determine appropriate locations and types of structures for development in fire-prone areas.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: we 100% need a better plan and to practice emergency evacuation in the palisades. the fact that people had to abandon their cars or go BACK to their houses in harms way can and will lead to more deaths if this ever happens again. creating more fire roads and also having a plan to get emergency vehicles in from different route would help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Emergency evacuation is inadequate - people had to abandon cars or return home during fire. We need better evacuation plans and more fire road access routes.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: The city needs to build more public affordable housing and change zoning restrictions to allow for more multi-use properties. Those affected by the fires and those already facing housing insecurity are facing price gouging of rents and over-inflated property values making it impossible to live in this city, even before the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: More affordable housing and multi-use zoning is needed. Current prices and rent gouging make it impossible to live here, especially after fires.
LABEL: Support Higher Density

CONTENT: Easy access to fire-safe building plans would help people tremendously, I think. I know some homeowners will struggle because they want to rebuild THE house, but many of those houses had outdated materials that are no longer up to code. But helping people see how they can rebuild with the proper materials will get some people over that hump quickly. Additionally, ADUs are a great way to help people earn extra income to cover their mortgages/insurance -- or to bring loved ones in when they need housing. This should be something that can be fast-tracked immediately. Long-term we all know that affordable housing is a challenge -- I'm not sure how we ever overcome the NIMBY mentality and make room for those who can't afford $3000 studio apts.
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs should be fast-tracked to help with housing affordability and density, but we need fire-safe building plans and proper materials for rebuilding.
LABEL: Support Density Growth

CONTENT: More transit-oriented development, prioritization of ecosystem health and fire resistant construction materials/design.
LLM_SUMMARY: Transit-oriented development and fire-resistant construction should be prioritized while building higher-density housing in fire-prone areas.
LABEL: Transit Density Safety

CONTENT: Modify zoning in the impacted areas to rebuild in a sustainable way, while also keeping the characters of the neighborhood still intact. Streamline the process for building.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild sustainably while preserving neighborhood character, but streamline construction processes and zoning requirements.
LABEL: sustainable balanced development

CONTENT: It is illogical to put more people in these fire areas particularly those who cannot afford insurance or the cost of rebuilding and replacing everything.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building more housing in fire-prone areas is dangerous, especially for those who can't afford insurance or rebuilding costs.
LABEL: Safety Over Density

CONTENT: Climate change has made all natural events, including wild fires, more intense. We have to come to grips with the fact that there are places where NO homes should be.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must accept that some areas are too dangerous for any housing development, regardless of demand.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: Immediately clear the properties on PCH on reopen the road. Cal Trans wants to put in bike lanes and sidewalks before opening. We do not need that. We need a wider road for safety, not narrower lanes. We also need an emergency permit for a sewer in east Malibu to handle the rebuilds.  600 or more new individual septic systems makes no sense whatsoever.
LLM_SUMMARY: Wider roads are needed for safety, not bike lanes. A single sewer system makes more sense than 600 individual septic systems for rebuilding homes.
LABEL: prioritize safety infrastructure

CONTENT:
Considering all of the electrical batteries in EV's or hybrids that melted into the drainage system (and future ones) along with all of the hazardous materials that when burned cause new toxins to form, in addition to their regular hazardous status when not burned, this needs to be a priority.  It was not well communicated to the NIMBY's that trucks/debris etc., would be traversing their roads and/or that certain locations would be used for packaging of those materials.  Better pre-planning of sites and better communications to the communities at large would reduce these kinds of concerns.

Greater open space between residential areas and wild-land interfaces should be required to support defensible space between the areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Greater open space between residential areas and wildland interfaces should be required for defensible space."
LABEL: safety infrastructure priority

CONTENT: should not be assessed for ADU will assist folks to move back to neighborhood faster and/or could assist housing some of the trades needed to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs should be allowed - they help residents return faster and house workers needed for rebuilding the neighborhood.
LABEL: density supports recovery

CONTENT: The State needs to stop requiring jurisdictions to allow buildings in the very high fire zones in LA county. There is no buffer like other counties between woodlands and urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't build in high fire zones; LA County lacks proper buffer zones between urban areas and woodlands.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: Quit building structures in places in fire prone areas.  The state and Weiner specifically have gone gun-ho in encouraging building in stupid places and passed laws which leave the local agencies powerless to design their own communities.   The population is barely growing yet there is a housing crisis. First thing OUTLAW Short Term Rental Airbnb's, tax the heck out of second/vacation homes, tax the wealthy so they cannot afford 3 and 4 homes while the rest of us are forced to rent.
LLM_SUMMARY: Stop building in fire-prone areas. Local agencies should control development, not state mandates. Tax vacation homes and limit multiple property ownership.
LABEL: limit housing development

CONTENT: Study the structures that survived. Adopt these ideas in rebuilding. Don't keep rebuilding in areas that have extreme risks of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't rebuild in high-risk fire zones - it's too dangerous.
LABEL: Safety Over Development

CONTENT: Relax Malibu overprotectiveness and overreach; allow small ADU’s with less code restriction, but with fire resistant materials.
LLM_SUMMARY: Allow ADUs with fire-resistant materials but fewer restrictions - we need housing density while maintaining safety standards.
LABEL: density supports housing

CONTENT: What warning systems?  Palisades had evacuation routes, only there weren't nearly enough of them.  It is shocking to me that there weren't hundreds of people killed in the Palisades.  And yet development continued on, knowing full well that the routes were grossly inadequate to carry the people out fast enough.  Criminal.
LLM_SUMMARY: Continued development despite inadequate evacuation routes is criminal. The Palisades couldn't safely evacuate its current population, yet they keep building more homes.
LABEL: safety over development

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: "We shouldn't automatically rebuild in high-risk areas like Palisades Highlands. Should all California taxpayers bear the cost of rebuilding in known fire zones?"
LABEL: limit high-risk development

CONTENT: My grandmother had a hard time getting out on Palisades Dr. There needs to be more than one way in and out of fire-affected areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Evacuation was difficult with limited routes. We need multiple access roads in fire-prone areas for safety.
LABEL: Safety Over Density

CONTENT: Home owners should be able to use Natural gas. It's more reliable and affordable than all electric mandates. Not allowing apartments in single family areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Not allowing apartments in single-family neighborhoods protects our community's character and safety during evacuations.
LABEL: density threatens safety

CONTENT: Efforts to streamline the housing re-permitting process for fire victims should be expanded to include everyone else. By making this process more efficient we could increase the supply of housing, reducing cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: Streamlining post-fire housing permits should apply to all construction, not just fire victims. This would increase housing supply and reduce costs.
LABEL: streamline housing development

CONTENT:
Regarding evac routes: like Paradise, CA, my town has only one road that leads into and out of the area. It's a narrow, winding two-lane road, making evacuation slow. It's essential that people be able to leave well before evacuation becomes mandatory (see my earlier note about temporary housing coverage gaps), so that we aren't all trying to navigate that route at the same time under duress. 

There are two other potential evac routes--an unpaved route through a State Forest and a paved road that's half collapsed due to erosion. Both are currently impassable and essentially death traps, but they could be turned into functional evacuation routes if funds were made available. I'm sure similar opportunities exist in other communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Limited evacuation routes make our town dangerous - one narrow road out, two broken alternatives. We need funding to create more escape routes.
LABEL: limited evacuation routes

CONTENT: Need to have realistic evacuation routes and communications given the densities of people or restrict building to reduce the density.  Mandatory training drills might be useful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need realistic evacuation plans for current population density, or limit new construction. High density areas require proper emergency protocols.
LABEL: safety over density

CONTENT: Would need clarity of which agencies would help with this in LA county so it can be effective.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clear information about which LA County agencies provide disaster financial assistance and how to access it.
LABEL: Clarity On Distribution

CONTENT: Helping everyone impacted with a plan and financial assistance will go a long way to supporting mental health
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial assistance and support plans should be available to all impacted residents to protect their mental wellbeing.
LABEL: equitable assistance prioritized

CONTENT: Issues if the residents weren't insured/ underinsured. Making sure they receive timely support for rebuilding/ limited redtape. CA may have more strict building codes based on earthquake/ fire concerns. Ensuring the costs/ codes to build appropriately are still accessible based on the incomes/ avoiding exploitation from real estate corporate entities (Blackrock).
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents need timely support for rebuilding, with accessible costs that account for strict building codes, while protecting against exploitation from corporate real estate.
LABEL: Insurance Access Equity

CONTENT: To help retain the local residents that were impacted/ future residents that are near fire risk areas, economic development/ workforce development will be essential. If grants are provided, it may be helpful to include local higher education institutions (community colleges, cal states, UCs), to make it more inclusive and a learning opportunity (volunteering/ college internship credit, college corps).
LLM_SUMMARY: Grants should include local colleges to create inclusive learning opportunities while helping impacted residents and those in fire-risk areas.
LABEL: education workforce priority

CONTENT: I am wary to putting resources in one place because of a lack of redundancy and crowding.  It would make sense to bundle like resources together, but spread it out so people can get to it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Resources should be distributed across multiple locations to prevent overcrowding and ensure everyone can access assistance when needed.
LABEL: Resources Spread Equitably

CONTENT: Aid to help navigate the system and assist when neceassary is welcome
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid to help navigate assistance systems is welcome and necessary.
LABEL: navigating assistance systems

CONTENT: I absolutely support economic assitance for local, small businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses deserve economic assistance after disasters.
LABEL: Support Local Business

CONTENT: We need deregulation and free permitting. building Codes are great and needed for public safety but then why is government penalizing citizens, owners and builders by charging them to implement safety codes. Makes no sense! Property taxes are already excessive and should already cover this expense and service to promote safety and avoid the need for people to dodge code or safety requirements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should cover safety code implementation costs through existing property taxes instead of charging extra permit fees that burden homeowners.
LABEL: Deregulation Fav

CONTENT: The Mayor of LA needs to be held accountable for the poor management of funds and water distribution. California needs to improve relations with federal government for assistance and come up with a joint plan to mitigate future occurrences. Use AI to determine hot spots and forest Management.
LLM_SUMMARY: Only wealthy areas got immediate aid, while lower-income neighborhoods struggled to get assistance after the fires.
LABEL: Government Fund Mismanagement

CONTENT: Need to focus on helping individuals save their properties and rebuild. Focus on the children that lost schools, community activities and their childhood because they no longer have a home.
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid should prioritize families with children who lost homes, schools, and community spaces - they've lost both shelter and childhood stability.
LABEL: Children Homes Priority

CONTENT: partially, the new code requirements should be evaluated by DISINTERESTED 3rd party experts to make sure they actually do something. so much code is basically lobbied into existence by people and companies who gain from requiring expensive, spurious non-sense. there should be significant legal aid for that effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Legal aid should be available to help evaluate if new code requirements are legitimate or just expensive rules lobbied by companies for profit.
LABEL: Equitable Aid Distribution
