CONTENT: people should absolutely be allowed to live on their properties while they rebuild. it's crazy to be paying a mortgage on a property that you can't live on while you figure out how to rebuild your home. there should also be clear public information about what is permittable in the area and the county should be educated about it and required to expedite it. they often give wrong information. last, permitting fees for building new ADU (that weren't there before the fire) should be permanently waived. the cost of permits is often 50% of the total ADU budget.
LLM_SUMMARY: Paying mortgages while unable to live on property during rebuilding is unfair. Permit fees, especially for ADUs, are too expensive and should be waived.
LABEL: Permit Fees Assistance

CONTENT: i think this is very important, but the way to deal with it is to actually support people getting back on their feet, not providing mental health services.
LLM_SUMMARY: People need direct financial support to recover and get back on their feet, not just mental health services.
LABEL: financial assistance priority

CONTENT: Insurance claims, grants for home rebuilding is essential if we are to be able to rebuild while we continue to pay our mortgage and extremely high rents.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need insurance and rebuilding grants to afford both temporary rent and our mortgage while reconstructing our homes.
LABEL: financial assistance needed

CONTENT: Allowing more flexibility with adding ADUs will support our entire community. Can this be incentivized in some way.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need financial incentives to build ADUs, which would help our whole community recover and rebuild.
LABEL: housing support flexibility

CONTENT: An online system to report my insurance company for not following their own guidelines and policies for covering our losses that are clearly outlined in our contract.  I have to drive 46 miles from home to work post-fire when I had less than one mile drive pre-fire. My insurance adjuster says my wife and I should ride together when we work different jobs at different start and end time. They also state that we should not be eating out so much since we rented a place with a kitchen...we leave before the sun comes up and return home at dark and dont have time or energy to cook meals at home. This is not being a good neighbor as their tagline says.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company refuses to honor policy terms, denies reasonable living expenses, and expects unrealistic sacrifices from displaced fire victims.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Disputes

CONTENT: Tax relief for fire hardened houses and neighborhoods. The more contiguous houses that are fire hardened the more tax relief/house. So we encourage NEIGHBORHOODS to communicate and cooperate
LLM_SUMMARY: Tax relief should increase when more neighboring homes are fire-hardened, encouraging whole neighborhoods to work together on protection.
LABEL: incentivize collective protection

CONTENT: Don't need tax relief as much as streamlining approvals to get businesses back open, and densifying neighborhoods to make small businesses more profitable. Best way to assist local businesses is to get them back open again and as easily accessible as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need faster reopening approvals and increased neighborhood density more than tax relief to recover financially.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Think inline with holding agencies accountable extends to after wildfires. We are seeing little to no approvals for housing reconstruction or repair. Beaucratic lallygagging post-crisis, when people have lost their homes and possessions, is entirely unacceptable
LLM_SUMMARY: Agencies aren't approving housing reconstruction claims after fires. This bureaucratic delay is unacceptable when people have lost everything.
LABEL: Bureaucratic Aid Delays

CONTENT: It would be extremely helpful for ongoing grants to be available for folks that are rebuilding Altadena. Continuing to pay mortgage and rent is extremely difficult.
LLM_SUMMARY: Grants should be available for Altadena residents rebuilding, as paying both mortgage and rent simultaneously is a major financial burden.
LABEL: Prioritize Financial Support

CONTENT: Others have mentioned the elephant in the room - home owners insurance in CA. This is going to continue to be a massive problem unless a sustainable solution is found. The reality is that most of the people I grew up will not be able to afford to return to the Palisades because they were massively underinsured. This is heartbreaking.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs are forcing people out of Palisades - many can't return because they were underinsured and can't afford rebuilding.
LABEL: Insurance Affordability Crisis

CONTENT: I'm so worried for the local businesses. I don't know how any of them will survive this.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local businesses need financial help to survive this disaster.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: I cannot tell you what a nightmare it has been for those of us who have homes still standing to navigate insurance. Most of the information at town halls and webinars was for total loss, which is a more clearly defined insurance process. The rest of us were basically expected to go back into our toxic homes and had to fight like hell for every ounce of ALE and smoke remediation to be covered. We are so grateful for Ricardo Lara and his staff for their help putting pressure on the insurance companies, but it would be great if the agents had the capacity to offer more guidance and support
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies only helped those with total losses, while partial damage victims struggled to get coverage for temporary housing and smoke remediation.
LABEL: Insurance Support Accessibility

CONTENT: Aside from grants and loans, consideration might be given to a tax relief program for the wildfire area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Tax relief programs should be considered for wildfire-affected areas, beyond just grants and loans.
LABEL: funding mechanism tax relief

CONTENT: Help the people who had mobile homes get back onto that land. That is the remaining middle class in the Palisades and we must not let it be overtaken by rich real estate developers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mobile home residents need help returning to their land - don't let wealthy developers take over this last middle-class area.
LABEL: Prioritize Middle Class

CONTENT: Engage all fire victims so they can help create their community. Offer support, listen. Allow them to build a temporary shelter if they want or need to live on their property while rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire victims should have a say in rebuilding and receive support to live on their property during reconstruction, including temporary shelter options.
LABEL: Community Led Recovery

CONTENT: There is currently a grant for adu prebuilding costs - expand this program.
LLM_SUMMARY: Expand existing ADU pre-building cost grant program to help more people.
LABEL: Expand Financial Assistance

CONTENT: Incentives like grants for prior businesses and tax free status for a period of time
LLM_SUMMARY: Provide grants and tax-free status periods to help impacted businesses recover.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Support/grants for pre-fire established small businesses that have been impacted by the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses established before the fires need financial support and grants to recover from fire impacts.
LABEL: Business Support Priority

CONTENT: Can't we make it easy for folks to get their questions answered, know of a place to go for information, get help?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a clear, accessible system for people to get information about financial assistance and available resources.
LABEL: Access Information Resources

CONTENT: The money to do this should already be a part of all the money that is being paid into the state, county and city.  Why there is almost no funds or action in the past in this area does not make any sense.
LLM_SUMMARY: State, county, and city should already have funds set aside for disaster relief, yet there's inexplicably no money available when needed.
LABEL: funds already allocated

CONTENT: Remove the red tape and long waits. Hire and train locally. Give back to our own and do it quickly. Why does it take months to onboard people to help us? Why are they not people from here that understand us?
LLM_SUMMARY: Local residents should be hired and trained to distribute aid - they understand our community and would speed up the process.
LABEL: Local Hiring Priority

CONTENT: Accessible resources for all impacted!!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone affected by the fires deserves equal access to financial assistance and resources.
LABEL: equal access resources

CONTENT:
We need ACCOUNTABILITY, REFORMS, GRANTS, and TAX BREAKS. We cannot rebuild this community without help for individual home owners.
(And please keep it closed until more debris is cleared and more of the fortunate are able to repopulate standing homes. Remediation lines are long. It’s too soon.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners need financial assistance through grants and tax breaks to rebuild - we can't recover without individual support.
LABEL: Prioritize Individual Home

CONTENT: Through no fault of our own we are underinsured.  It's still unclear if we are going to get any FEMA money.  I still don't know what role Hagerty is going to play.
LLM_SUMMARY: We're underinsured through no fault of ours, and it's unclear if we'll receive any FEMA assistance.
LABEL: Insufficient Insurance Support

CONTENT: I am middle class. I’ll pour every cent into this rebuild, but I’m still not sure I can pull it off and I’m not sure I’m going to qualify for any help. Can you please keep that in mind? SEND GRANTS, PLEASE! I’ll follow every fire hardening guideline I can afford.
LLM_SUMMARY: I'll spend everything on rebuilding but may not qualify for assistance since I'm middle class. Please consider grants for people like me.
LABEL: Middle Class Assistance

CONTENT: The Army Corps of Engineers is doing a great job.  After the ACE has done it's job, there should be an additional step of testing for soil and water quality.  If the city can't pay for it, then it should be covered under the California Fair Plan "Ordinance of Law" line item.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance should cover soil and water quality testing if the city can't afford it through California Fair Plan's Ordinance of Law.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Priority

CONTENT: Accessible grants for homeowners too. **There’s an underserved middle between those who qualify for aid and those who don’t need it.** Please help us with grants to rebuild. I’m begging you. I can’t give up the plot where my long gone grandparents held me and I took my first steps.
LLM_SUMMARY: "There's an underserved middle between those who qualify for aid and those who don't need it. We need grants to rebuild."
LABEL: Middle Class Assistance

CONTENT: We need transparency for how government and private sector funds are being spent on the recovery
LLM_SUMMARY: Government and private organizations must be transparent about how disaster recovery funds are being allocated and spent.
LABEL: Transparency In Distribution

CONTENT: Please simplify all of this. I never wanted to figure out how to build a home. This needs to be overhauled for all the people you failed. Waive all the fees. Why are we paying you more? What does it go towards? Fire protection lol?? (Sorry to be spicy, but dude.)
LLM_SUMMARY: Waive all rebuilding fees - why should we pay more after losing everything? What are these extra charges even going towards?
LABEL: Fees Versus Support

CONTENT: The government has not done enough with the billions of dollars collected for “homeless” housing along with the billions collected for mental illness. Don’t want the same to happen in this area too.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government mismanages billions in aid for housing and mental health. We can't let disaster relief funds be wasted the same way.
LABEL: Government Fund Mismanagement

CONTENT: Be sure all monies being distributed are not being scammed or stolen by those who are not eligible or impersonating those who do.  Slow it down and coordinate with all the other money coming in and make sure it gets to the right people.   Stop hiring big firms that are somehow supposed to help but are just another layer of bureaucracy and waste of money.
LLM_SUMMARY: Money should go directly to eligible victims without wasteful bureaucracy or scammers. Proper verification and coordination needed to ensure fair distribution.
LABEL: Fraud Prevention Priority

CONTENT: Yes to deprioritising anyone with a second home. Prioritise the most severely in need and avoid patronising behaviours please - there but for the grace of god goes any one of us! Long term housing solutions must be addressed systemically.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize financial aid to those most in need, not second homeowners. Housing solutions must be addressed systematically.
LABEL: prioritize severe need

CONTENT: stop blanket support and giving to those who already have more than they need and prioritise aid to those who are really struggling, without patronising and making them feel like second class citizens.
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid should prioritize those truly struggling, not those who already have enough, while treating recipients with dignity and respect.
LABEL: prioritize neediest residents

CONTENT: People need places to live, but I don't think it should be in high-risk fire zones if we can help it. Pay the people who lost their homes, but rebuild high-density housing in urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Pay people who lost homes in fire zones, but rebuild high-density housing in safer urban areas instead of risky locations.
LABEL: Prioritize Urban Development

CONTENT: Construction cost escalation from date of the fire to completion of homes will vastly exceed anyone's insurance settlement.  There was 6% per year escalation before the year, 9% in the last year, and will increase based on the massive reconstruction from the two major fires, tariffs, and regional labor shortage
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance settlements won't cover actual rebuilding costs due to construction cost escalation, labor shortages, and tariffs following the fires.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Inadequacy

CONTENT: Allow people to do what they need to do to rebuild.  EVERYONE is going to have a significant shortfall when it comes to rebuilding.  Clear the way so there are less hurdles
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone faces major financial shortfalls during rebuilding. Remove bureaucratic barriers and let people access assistance they need.
LABEL: Equal Access Support

CONTENT: Expedited permitting time and the cost of permits for rebuilds should be waived - these rebuilds are not being done by choice but by necessity and a result of government not being prepared and letting an entire community burn to the ground overnight.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should waive permit costs and expedite rebuilding permits since homeowners didn't choose this situation - they're victims of disaster.
LABEL: Prioritize Rebuilding

CONTENT:
County or city building processes have to be streamlined and charges kept manageable
For people
To recover successfully.  Plans and permits can’t be mired in municipal offices for undue amounts of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building permits and fees must remain affordable and processing times reasonable so fire victims can rebuild without excessive delays.
LABEL: streamlined permit process

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underinsured homeowners need grants and tax relief to afford rebuilding to current code requirements.
LABEL: Prioritize Underins

CONTENT: Rather than temporary housing, a priority should be placed in Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs), home rebuilding, long-term housing solutions
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize funding for permanent solutions like ADUs and home rebuilding instead of temporary housing assistance.
LABEL: Housing Over Aid

CONTENT:
Again getting bonds together and finding resources is a priority and time is of the essence call
For special elections to help manage decisions
LLM_SUMMARY: We need quick special elections to decide how to allocate bonds and resources for disaster relief.
LABEL: Prioritize Funding

CONTENT: The City has no money to do this; let charitable Angelenos take care of each other. Stop wasting our time and money.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government shouldn't fund disaster relief; let charitable citizens help each other instead of wasting taxpayer money.
LABEL: charity over government

CONTENT: We are not able to proceed with retaining a contractor and rebuild when our insurance company is holding out paying what they owe us, which are the limits we paid for.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company refuses to pay our policy limits, preventing us from hiring contractors and starting rebuilding despite paying for full coverage.
LABEL: Insurance Payment Delays

CONTENT: The insurance landscape in California needs to be addressed. The FAIR plan is terrible, and private insurance companies take to long to process claims. There need to be faster ways for survivors to get access to funds after their home is destroyed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance claims take too long to process, and survivors need faster access to funds after losing their homes.
LABEL: Insurance Access Fairness

CONTENT: Renters need support from the County just the same as homeowners. I, a long with so many others, have not received our security deposits back despite the 21 day law. It then becomes our responsibility to start, and pay for, a Small Claims case, and good luck collecting it. We are busy trying to find a place to live, filling out paperwork and dealing with insurance/FEMA, and trying to apply for grants that never seem to materialize. We need help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters deserve equal financial support as homeowners. We struggle to recover security deposits and can't afford legal battles while dealing with housing, FEMA, and grants.
LABEL: renters versus homeowners

CONTENT: No nothing missing--except thought for attracting and keeping working families making housing affordable again.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing needs to be affordable to keep working families in the area, not just provide disaster aid.
LABEL: Housing Affordability Priority

CONTENT:
The small business support that exists right now is a complete joke. They are high interest loans that are few and far between, businesses in palisades are battling with their internet provider for early cancellation - it’s not early cancellation. There is nothing to go back to!! Some of them are on the hook for over $10,000! These are everyday people
Who showed up day in and day out for our community and the county/city/state is turning their backs on them. 

Why are their no streamlined grants? Incentive them to say.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need grants, not high-interest loans. They're facing huge cancellation fees while their locations are destroyed, yet government offers no real support.
LABEL: insufficient business support

CONTENT: Subsidize local, small businesses
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses should receive financial subsidies for disaster recovery.
LABEL: Local Business Priority

CONTENT: For certain survivors
LLM_SUMMARY: I cannot create a paraphrase or edit as the provided user comment "For certain survivors" is too brief and lacks sufficient context to understand the point being made about financial assistance distribution.
LABEL: Need Based Distribution

CONTENT: Permit process needs to expedited without delay and costs need to be minimal for residents to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding permits should be fast-tracked and fees minimized to help residents recover financially.
LABEL: expedited permits needed

CONTENT: The Mayor and Supervisors need to pass new laws and regulations to reduce the price of emergency housing.  Charging retail rates is corrupt, feathering the nest of our worst segment, the rentiers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Emergency housing prices during disasters are exploitative. Officials must regulate costs to prevent landlords from profiting off displaced residents.
LABEL: Price Control Fairness

CONTENT: When the fires broke out it was made very clear they were going to be very strict on rent gouging but I have not seen any accountability on this. I have also never seen accountability on this across the board. Rent has been unattainable for so many for so long. There are also many people who face wage garnishments for terrible situations when they try to work with a leasing office and do the right thing and get out of a lease when something tragic happens like a loss/helping out a family member etc and the leasing office/property won’t work with them at all and then you have 1,000’s of California residents who are garnished up to 25% of their weekly pay! California need to stop allowing any garnishments by greedy companies + price gouging
LLM_SUMMARY: Rent gouging rules aren't enforced, and property companies unfairly garnish wages up to 25% when tenants face hardships during disasters.
LABEL: rent control enforcement

CONTENT: The economy already favors the wealthy and successful, so these emergencies require special protections and provisions for underserved small businesses that need extra help to recover.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need special financial protections during emergencies since wealthy businesses already have advantages in recovery.
LABEL: Prioritize Underser

CONTENT: County needs to expedite all permits for building houses.  We absolutely can't afford to rent and pay mortgage for as long as this is going to take so don't want permits delayed for months costing us tens of thousands of dollars we don't have to waste.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't afford paying both rent and mortgage during rebuilding. County must expedite permits to avoid costly delays we can't afford.
LABEL: expedite permit process

CONTENT: We live in California, home of the tech bros. Why can we have a functioning app that anyone and everyone can tap into for resources?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need an accessible app where everyone can easily find and connect with available disaster relief resources.
LABEL: Technology Access Equity

CONTENT: Make it so all the small businesses can come back. Grants, incentives, or any sort of help should be given
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need grants, incentives, and other financial assistance to recover and return after the fires.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners who can't afford fire prevention maintenance should receive city funding, since preventing fires is cheaper than rebuilding burned neighborhoods.
LABEL: Government Funded Prevention

CONTENT: Make it easier to get temporary housing
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to simplify access to temporary housing assistance.
LABEL: Housing Access Priority

CONTENT: Rebuilding to specific “like-for-like “ criteria that the Assessor will agree with and that passes Building & Safety and other code checks will cut the time to rebuild way down by clarifying the path to a design and ultimately a rebuild that will serve homeowners affected. I want a chance to rebuild. I need help getting that information straightened out and available NOW!
LLM_SUMMARY: I need clear guidance on rebuild requirements and financial assistance now, so I can start the rebuilding process without delays.
LABEL: Prioritize Rebuilding

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Taxpayers shouldn't have to fund rebuilding in high-risk fire zones like Pacific Palisades.
LABEL: Fairness Versus Risk

CONTENT: Multifamily housing must be included in USACE's debris removal mission. It is the only fair thing to do. Treating one group of residents differently from another, when both impacted groups have suffered, pay taxes, and vote, is unjust. Multifamily housing residents tend to be underinsured by the way insurance companies structure insurance, tend to be lower income/wealth than single family homeowners, are often on a fixed income, single income, retired, and older. To discriminate against this vulnerable population is unjust and inexcusable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Excluding multifamily housing from debris removal assistance is unfair. These residents are often lower-income, underinsured, and vulnerable - they deserve equal financial support.
LABEL: prioritize vulnerable populations

CONTENT: Did I say “Task Force”?  We have a task force organization already. Developing Version 1.0, then Version 2.0…(keep going…) should be done in that framework. Oh, yes, and FUND it and put someone in charge of this “ongoing project” that will get results.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fund the task force properly and assign clear leadership to ensure equitable distribution of disaster assistance.
LABEL: funding allocation priority

CONTENT: Make testing affordable to those Altadenans who have lost everything.
LLM_SUMMARY: Testing should be made affordable for Altadena residents who lost everything in the fire.
LABEL: Prioritize Financial Need

CONTENT: The CA Department of Insurance has put a number of excellent laws and regulations together that make dealing with the insurance providers somewhat easier for a homeowner customer. However the industry wide marketing of disaster (Homeowner)’insurance has led to virtually no polices promising to rebuild “no matter what” and substituting coverages that seem to fully protect and do not, leaving most homeowners underinsured which means they can’t afford to rebuild and can’t stay in their home because it has burned to the ground. This needs to be worked out with the insurance providers and the Dept of Insurance and the homeowners needing and wanting the protection of a policy that will help them in a catastrophe, rather than add to it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies mislead homeowners with inadequate coverage, leaving them unable to rebuild after fires. We need policies that truly protect people in catastrophes.
LABEL: insurance coverage inadequate

CONTENT: Streamline communication on financial assistance available for those impacted by fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clearer information about what financial help is available for fire victims.
LABEL: Communication Access Equity

CONTENT: Rebuilding is impacted by labor shortage and material cost. Is the state doing anything to help keep costs low despite the federal mandate of deporting laborers and enforcing tariffs on building materials?
LLM_SUMMARY: State needs to address how labor shortages and material tariffs are driving up rebuilding costs for fire victims.
LABEL: Government Aid Allocation

CONTENT: There needs to be incentive for lawyers in the area to work pro bono for families regarding tenant issues. There's no reason that owning a rental should leave you in the dark.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lawyers should provide pro bono services for tenants and landlords dealing with fire-related housing issues.
LABEL: Legal Aid Priority

CONTENT: Also, it is a travesty that people who are displaced are who knows where. For example, how could Pasadena ship out its residents whose homes burned down to other cities? Could the City not have found temporary shelter within the City? It was callous to say that they convention center is a business and boot out people.
LLM_SUMMARY: The city should have provided local temporary shelter instead of sending displaced residents to other cities. Using the convention center for business over shelter was callous.
LABEL: Prioritize Local Shelter

CONTENT: I think some people have been more traumatized by their insurance than by the fire. Maddening and heartbreaking.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies caused more trauma than the fire itself - it's maddening and heartbreaking how they handle claims.
LABEL: Insurance Trauma Over Fire

CONTENT: People displaced by the fires need help not only with rebuilding, but with living in their chosen communities immediately.
LLM_SUMMARY: People need immediate financial help to stay in their communities while rebuilding, not just reconstruction assistance.
LABEL: immediate community support

CONTENT: I am worried that I will be forced to leave my beloved Altadena community - how can I afford to live here in the future with additional SBA loan debt to rebuild, uncertain future insurability and affordability, rising property taxes to accommodate the rebuild, and the threat of another wildfire or earthquake disaster that we are woefully unprepared for?  If we, as a two income household with no kids, with engineering degrees and careers, are struggling - What about the rest of the community?
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding costs, loan debt, and rising property taxes may force us out of Altadena. If we're struggling with two incomes, how do others manage?
LABEL: Financial Burden Concerns

CONTENT: We could rethink home insurance entirely. Maybe it should not be managed by private companies, but by a government agencies. Natural disasters ARE different from an individual fire in a resident's home.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government agencies, not private companies, should manage home insurance for natural disasters since they're different from individual house fires.
LABEL: Government Insurance Control

CONTENT:
Funding for communities to engage organizers and facilitators to act as paid (not volunteer, as is the Topanga Town Council, Chamber of Commerce, Emergency Preparedness (TCEP), elderly support (SAGES) - to bring community leaders together, to interface with govt agencies.
There should be a team specifically dedicated to coordination and communications as soon as a fire or other crisis strikes.
We need a unified 'easy to use' communications system for communities in crisis, including a clear and well organized hierarchy for distributing communications & a neighborhood/zone system that people are already enrolled in prefire. Cellular systems or mesh net wifi should be available for text only communications throughout the city and county.
LLM_SUMMARY: Communities need paid coordinators, not just volunteers, to manage emergency communications and interface with government agencies during fires.
LABEL: Prioritize Community Infrastructure

CONTENT: Provide grants to help people fire harden their homes for those who can't afford it to reduce the chances and severity of future fires
LLM_SUMMARY: Provide financial assistance to low-income residents for fire-hardening their homes to prevent future disasters.
LABEL: Prevention Over Recovery

CONTENT: Reached out to the Red Cross. They said I was not eligible for counseling!!!! I have been staying in a hotel for three months!
LLM_SUMMARY: I was denied Red Cross counseling despite being displaced in a hotel for three months.
LABEL: Unequal Aid Distribution

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: "Why should taxpayers in other California cities fund recovery for wealthy homeowners who chose to build in high-risk fire zones?"
LABEL: Funding Source Fairness

CONTENT: It is important that government provide assistance to protect individual people from illegal or unfair actions taken against them by insurance companies and/or landlords. Government should simplify the regulatory process of rebuilding but should not be using tax-payer money to issue grants for home building or for bringing existing buildings into compliance with new code requirements. Government should not be using tax-payer money to provide legal aid to undocumented residents; this should be a service provided by the private sector.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government shouldn't use taxpayer money for rebuilding grants or legal aid to undocumented residents, but should protect people from unfair insurance and landlord practices.
LABEL: Government vs Private

CONTENT: As long as there are checkpoints and the lines to enter are long, it will be very difficult for businesses to thrive.   We need to help them
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need financial support to survive while checkpoints and long entry lines continue to hurt their operations.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Rental rates are insane. I still can’t find a place to live while I rebuild my house. Please consider subsidies.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need rent subsidies while rebuilding - current rental prices are too expensive to afford temporary housing.
LABEL: Housing Assistance Priority

CONTENT: I kindly urge you to consider hiring and training individuals from Los Angeles for this work. We can make a positive impact by reducing bureaucratic barriers and giving our local community a chance. The job market in LA is genuinely challenging right now, and supporting our own can bring hope and opportunity to those in need. Hire our own, train our own, and stop with the six-month hiring process. People are losing everything, and we aren't requiring these contractors to hire those affected.
LLM_SUMMARY: Contractors should hire and train local LA residents affected by fires, instead of outsiders. The lengthy hiring process hurts those who've lost everything.
LABEL: Local Employment Priority

CONTENT: C.C.C.-like organization of volunteers &/or prisoners to help with cleanup and maybe earn some money.
LLM_SUMMARY: Suggests using volunteers and prisoners for cleanup work, providing them financial compensation for their efforts.
LABEL: labor for financial aid

CONTENT: Remove all bottlenecks when it comes to grants, economic recovery, and small business support.
LLM_SUMMARY: Eliminate barriers to accessing financial aid, grants, and business support for all those affected.
LABEL: streamline financial assistance

CONTENT: The debris removal is very uncoordinated and gate keeping is occurring by a few trucking companies that are barring other trucking companies from participating.
LLM_SUMMARY: Trucking companies are monopolizing and blocking others from participating in debris removal contracts and financial opportunities.
LABEL: Unfair Resource Distribution

CONTENT: Army Corp and LA County systems need to be in sync. There have been many ROE's lost in the system, leaving us calling daily for status without answers. Also, lets be clear on who will be paying for debris removal, insurance or "free" as what many people are being told.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should clarify if they're covering debris removal costs, rather than misleading people about it being "free."
LABEL: Funding Transparency Neede

CONTENT: Temporary long term housing allows people to focus on the next step the in recovery process. Month to month housing for total loss is not helpful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Long-term housing assistance is essential for recovery. Month-to-month temporary housing doesn't provide enough stability for fire victims.
LABEL: Long-term Housing Priority

CONTENT: Perhaps aid can be giving to homeowners who offer their ADU's as interim housing for those displaced in the fires?
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid should go to homeowners who provide their ADUs as temporary housing for fire evacuees.
LABEL: Aid For Housing

CONTENT: Allow small business owners to rebuild and restore before greedy companies take their space
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business owners should get priority for rebuilding funds before large corporations take over their locations.
LABEL: Local Business Priority

CONTENT: The American Red Cross worked faster than any other entity to ensure we had money days after the fire took our home. I believe in nonprofit support, especially where government bureaucracy can sometimes slow relief.
LLM_SUMMARY: The Red Cross provided quick financial aid when our home burned, working faster than government agencies could with their bureaucracy.
LABEL: Nonprofit Support Priority

CONTENT: Support for not just homeowners and landlords in the 'burn scar' but in the entire community where long and short term renters leave..
LLM_SUMMARY: Support should extend beyond property owners to include both long-term and short-term renters affected by the fires.
LABEL: Support All Housing Types

CONTENT: Upzone the burned areas to increase the value of the land so that the homeowners can be made whole.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild burned areas with higher-density zoning to increase property values and help homeowners recover financially.
LABEL: Prioritize Property Values

CONTENT: more equitable housing arrangements--coops, land trusts, mixed low-income--higher income housing choices.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mixed-income housing options, cooperatives, and land trusts would create more equitable housing arrangements for those affected by fires.
LABEL: equitable housing distribution

CONTENT: Where are the fundraising dollars going? We have received a minimal amount of $ . Are the dollars being vetted?
LLM_SUMMARY: "We've only received minimal assistance and don't know where fundraising dollars are going or how they're being vetted."
LABEL: Transparency In Distribution

CONTENT: Insurance assistance in layman terms would be essential. We shouldn't require a lawyer to understand our insurance policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies should be written in simple language that everyone can understand, not complex terms requiring legal expertise.
LABEL: Insurance Accessibility Equity

CONTENT: If undocumented residents lost their homes and valuables in the fires they 100% deserve assistance just as any other citizen affected by the fires. They are human too with families and contribute to our society.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone affected by fires deserves assistance, regardless of immigration status. Undocumented residents are human beings with families who contribute to society.
LABEL: undocumented residents deserve

CONTENT: Overall out community has been left devastated because of insurers pulling out of plans. There needs to be steps taken to help people rebuild their homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning coverage has devastated our community. We need financial support to help residents rebuild their homes.
LABEL: Insurance Access Equity

CONTENT: Remember to make sure these grants are going to local businesses and not scammers/fraudsters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local businesses deserve these grants - we must ensure funds don't go to scammers trying to take advantage of disaster aid.
LABEL: Local Business Priority

CONTENT: The City does not have money to give out and is terrible at managing large-scale projects. Before creating a new spending program, focus on cutting the egregious waste that led to our billion-dollar deficit. Let charitable Angelenos and the community charities we support care for people who need help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should let private charities handle disaster aid instead of creating new spending programs, given their poor track record managing funds.
LABEL: Government Spending Skepticism

CONTENT:
Tenant support is essential.  Undocumented workers have to be a low
Priority unfortunately.  Red tape is a killer anyway yo help with that is vital.  Using an online forum would be a good start for people to use
LLM_SUMMARY: Tenants need support, but red tape makes assistance difficult. An online forum could help people access aid more easily.
LABEL: prioritize documented residents

CONTENT: We need to provide both immediate and long-term support for individuals and families impacted by the fires. It should be culturally appropriate and include access online and in person.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial assistance should be accessible both online and in-person, with culturally appropriate support provided immediately and long-term to fire-impacted families.
LABEL: equitable access distribution

CONTENT: Fire victims will not be able to make well-considered decisions about how to move forward if they are traumatized and hurting. We need to make people whole -- mental health services, support groups, somatic therapy, all of this needs to be available at low or no cost to people affected by the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Mental health services, therapy, and support groups should be freely available to fire victims - they can't make good recovery decisions while traumatized.
LABEL: mental health priority

CONTENT:
We already had a shortage of construction labor b4 the disaster

There is an opportunity here to create 1,000s of jobs & numerous small biz's
                               
LA Economic & Workforce Dept needs to implement a strategic workforce development initiative, including the formation of small biz    

Work skill/biz courses could be offered tuition free at LAUSD's 13 adult education/trade schools

Fed/State/NGO small biz assistance, funding/grants can be combined to fund the outfitting of the small companies which will drive the recovery

We don't need master carpenters, but workers who can assemble prefab, install ADUs, living pods, appliances etc. & connect them 2 utilities

Let residents drive the recovery, not big const firms..
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial assistance should prioritize local workforce development and small businesses through free training programs and grants, enabling residents to lead recovery efforts instead of large firms.
LABEL: Local Economic Development

CONTENT: People are confused with what a Disaster Recovery Centers is and what a Disaster Assistance Center is. These names need to be vastly different so people know what is what.
LLM_SUMMARY: Recovery centers need clearer, distinct names so residents can understand which one provides financial assistance versus other services.
LABEL: Assistance Access Confusion

CONTENT: Subsidies are OK short term, but long term they'll just make it worse. Let's make sure we have a plan to solve the housing crisis for real.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need real housing solutions instead of temporary subsidies that won't fix the underlying problems.
LABEL: Short Term Support

CONTENT: Give small businesses interest-free loans to rebuild. Maybe lessen their state and local tax burden for the next 2-3 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need interest-free loans and reduced state/local taxes for 2-3 years to help them rebuild.
LABEL: Business Support Over Individual

CONTENT: Every business near fire areas are struggling. Not only have many residents had to leave, but the ones remaining are financially stressed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local businesses suffer doubly - evacuated residents are gone and remaining customers have limited spending power due to fire-related financial stress.
LABEL: Business Economic Impact

CONTENT: YES. YES. YES. Education, fire audits, financial assistance for community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial assistance should be provided to build community-wide fire protection and preparedness.
LABEL: Education Funding Community

CONTENT:
People need money to put food on their table and a roof over their head. But any business recovery needs to be cognizant of the needs of the community. It would be a shame if pure market interests are what dictated the kind of business and industries that get created and not the interests of the people who live there.
We don't need anymore extractive business's like mining, real estate speculation, and warehousing but more restorative/regenerative business like food coops, watershed protection , and habitat restoration.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should prioritize basic needs like food and housing, while business recovery must serve community interests rather than just market profits.
LABEL: Community Needs Priority

CONTENT:
Renters were the most badly hurt while landlords claimed insurance money.  

More education about need for renters insurance is needed.  Earthquake policy is available from the state for homes (landlords). Loss of use policy should be offered to all renters.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters suffered most while landlords got insurance payouts. Renters need better access to insurance coverage, including loss of use policies.
LABEL: Renters Insurance Disp

CONTENT: My ALE is limited. I need a somewhere to go once it is out.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need temporary housing after insurance's Additional Living Expenses runs out.
LABEL: Limited Insurance Coverage

CONTENT: The fact that Fire Aid took so much money and there is no clear path to seeing that money is beyond frustrating. There should be a czar to oversee the funds and community members should have a voice.
LLM_SUMMARY: Community members deserve transparency and input on how Fire Aid distributes funds. We need oversight to ensure money reaches those who need it.
LABEL: Transparency Oversight Accountability

CONTENT: I fear the small businesses still standing will be forced to close due to families being displaced. We are already seeing it with places like Mathnasium and CodeNinjas in Altadena.  Given the decimation of the schools and aftercare programs, and provided the air is deemed safe, a program to shuttle kids to such places could help them stay solvent.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses like Mathnasium and CodeNinjas may close due to displaced families. Financial support for transportation programs could help these businesses survive.
LABEL: Business Support Priority

CONTENT:
Disaster relief insurance training to educate victims on how to advocate for the
Selves!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should train disaster victims on how to advocate for themselves when seeking financial relief.
LABEL: Insurance Education Access

CONTENT:
The Army Corps is not funded nor has a mandate to help commercial properties, churches and other non residential properties.  

How can we say our communities are safe if all the commercial district cleanup efforts are handled by commercial property owners.  

There must be support for this, if we want economic recovery to return to these affected communities.  

Phase 2 of the cleanup may be complete by Jan 6th 2026, but if the commercial zones are not cleaned, we will have large areas that will continue to contaminate the rest of the community. 

Why did the State of California not ask FEMA and the Federal Government for assistance in this type of aid?
LLM_SUMMARY: "Commercial properties need government cleanup funding too, not just residential. Without aid for business districts, entire communities remain at risk of contamination."
LABEL: funding allocation inequity

CONTENT:
One area where resources should be consolidated is the tax incentives, grants and rebates available from federal, State & local government entities for sustainability measures in rebuilding.  

This is an important part of a multi-layered cost reduction strategy that will make sustainable rebuilding accessible to all property owners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government aid for sustainable rebuilding should be streamlined and consolidated to make it financially accessible for all property owners.
LABEL: Government Aid Distribution

CONTENT: Provide aid to all infected. Homeowners and renters, total loss and uninhabitables. You pay into insurance to be covered for emergencies and if there are no emergencies, there's no reason for rates to increase. Even where there is an emergency, rates shouldn't increase. The system needs to be overhauled, along with FEMA. The lack of financial support has caused so many to be homeless.
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid should go to all affected homeowners and renters. Insurance rates shouldn't increase after emergencies. Current system leaves many homeless due to lack of support.
LABEL: equal aid distribution

CONTENT: I think it is critically important to address price gouging of displaced victims. At some point, the rental free market needs some guardrails to ensure all are housed equitably.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rental market needs guardrails to prevent price gouging of displaced fire victims and ensure equitable housing access.
LABEL: Market Regulation Needed

CONTENT:
Promoting the PACE-Property Assessed Clean Energy program and  encouraging residents to rebuild with solar roof tiles would be helpful These materials are more fire resistant & widespread deployment would reduce the strain on the grid

If not solar tiles, other roofing materials that are inherently fire resistant and manufactured using a circular process should be used

LA Rises or another PPP should be assigned the task of bundling the orders  for the materials  They could acquire them @ wholesale prices & distribute them @ cost

PACE could lower costs by using blended finance vehicles incorporating grant $ & concessionary capital to fund projects

These discounts along with fed/state incentives & grants would significantly reduce cost
LLM_SUMMARY: "PACE program and blended financing could help residents afford fire-resistant solar roofs, especially when combined with federal and state incentives."
LABEL: prioritize sustainable rebuilding

CONTENT: The city has been over relying on temporary housing and interim housing solutions that are run by non-profits and private businesses. These greedy middle-men are exploiting city programs for their own benefit. The city needs to build public, affordable housing with the EXPRESS intention of reducing property values and rent. Ignore landlord, land developer, and private equity interests that are making it impossible for working class people to survive in this city.
LLM_SUMMARY: The city wastes money on private housing middlemen instead of building affordable public housing, which would help working-class residents survive financially.
LABEL: Private Interests Prioritize

CONTENT: There are many resources available to address trauma support, but what the public needs right now is tangible rebuilding assistance and services. Providing these will have a lasting positive impact on their mental health in the long term.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid for rebuilding homes and services should be prioritized over mental health resources, as this will better support long-term recovery.
LABEL: prioritize tangible rebuilding

CONTENT: Insurance is difficult to navigate and because it is a business, companies are doing everything they can to not pay out on claims. People who lost homes and were underinsured need assistance to close those financial gaps beyond additional loans. People need cash in hand to help with rebuilding. We saw the government response to supporting businesses during COVID with PLP loans that were forgiven. The people of Altadena need a similar benefit.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies avoid payouts, so fire victims need direct government cash assistance like COVID PPP loans, not more debt through additional loans.
LABEL: Insurance Versus Government

CONTENT: Where to start - a lot of people were being dropped by their insurance, and had a hard time getting other insurance. Some are uninsured or underinsured. People are having a hard time dealing with insurance. People need resources to know what proper fire related insurance coverage should look like and literally a how-to of navigating insurance if you have a full loss, partial loss, smoke.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are dropping coverage and people struggle to get new policies. Many lack proper coverage and need guidance navigating fire-related insurance claims.
LABEL: Insurance Access Equity

CONTENT: Yes! Offer hefty rebates for those who fire harden their homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Provide substantial rebates to homeowners who invest in fire-hardening their properties.
LABEL: Prioritize Prevention Investment

CONTENT: I have a significant concern that the resources and labor pool will be heavily impacted when so many of us are rebuilding at the same time and the resulting cost increases will make it impossible for so many.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and rebuilding costs will skyrocket when everyone needs repairs at once, making recovery impossible for many residents.
LABEL: Cost Impacts Fairness

CONTENT: Make insurance a non-profit industry. Nobody should be profiting off of disasters. Grants should go to ALL homeowners and not just to single family residents or people who didn't pay for insurance. Why limit legal aid just to tenants & undocumented residents? Everybody else needs legal aid to deal with the insurance companies. Plus, we could all use some free financial planning to know how we are going to pay for this perfect storm of  failed infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't profit from disasters. Financial aid and legal assistance should be available to everyone affected, not just specific groups.
LABEL: equitable insurance access

CONTENT: Homes that survived the fires, but with smoke damage, fall into this gray area for $ coverage from insurance. There is no enforcement arm from the Department of Insurance to make carriers do anything. We have little guidance on knowing when it is safe to return to our homes or our neighborhood. Dept. of Health seems to be the only agency addressing this but again, no enforcement pathway from them to the insurance carriers who more or less want us back in our homes as soon as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies provide no clear guidance on smoke damage coverage and rush residents back home, while health departments lack enforcement power.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Gaps

CONTENT: Clean the lots near standing homes first so they can get back to the community!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Clean vacant lots near occupied homes first - prioritize getting residents back to their community.
LABEL: Prioritize Existing

CONTENT: The plain fact is that NO ONE can afford this. Altadena residents who lost their homes need money, we need grants marked for individuals and families, not agencies/charities (where the donated funds go God knows where). We can't do this alone. My family is in a relatively privileged position where we had insurance and did not lose our jobs, but we don't know if we will be able to afford to rebuild. If we can't afford it, who can? What will our town be if it's just turned over to deep pocketed developers? We need help, and direct financial assistance to residents is the only way to preserve this town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Direct financial assistance should go to residents, not agencies. Even with insurance and jobs, rebuilding costs are overwhelming - we'll lose our community to developers without help.
LABEL: direct resident assistance

CONTENT: Renters were really left out in the cold. This was such a shame.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters were excluded from financial assistance after the disaster, which was unfair.
LABEL: renters versus homeowners

CONTENT: Eliminate the need for personal property inventory to get one’s entire personal property coverage! Studies show creating that list is the most traumatic part of recovery. We didn’t pay 75% of our insurance premium, why do we only get 75% of our coverage without being forced to do something so traumatic?!
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies shouldn't require traumatic personal property inventories. We paid full premiums but only get 75% coverage without itemizing everything we lost.
LABEL: Insurance Fairness Debate

CONTENT: a reserve fund for rebuilding and restructuring the area.
LLM_SUMMARY: A reserve fund should be established for rebuilding and restructuring the affected area.
LABEL: Prioritize Rebuilding

CONTENT: For those who are under insured, the gap to rebuild relative to insurance proceeds is very large. There needs to be some form of assistance for those who are on the CA Fair Plan.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance gaps are huge for Fair Plan holders. We need assistance to help underinsured homeowners rebuild after disasters.
LABEL: Insurance Gap Support

CONTENT: My house is still standing with some minor damage, however, what I want to know is will there ever be grants to upgrade our old homes to code or for features that retard fires for example, fireproof roofs, siding, vents and windows?
LLM_SUMMARY: Will there be grants to upgrade older homes with fire-resistant features like fireproof roofs and vents? My house has minor damage but needs modernizing.
LABEL: Preventative Infrastructure Support

CONTENT: Making resources available and how to find them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Resources need to be made available and people need to know how to find them.
LABEL: Resources Access Priority

CONTENT: Many schools in the surrounding areas have closed down. Consider buying those lots and building affordable housing, like little communities around green spaces for those impacted by fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Schools should be purchased and converted into affordable housing communities with green spaces for fire victims.
LABEL: Housing Over Property

CONTENT: We have community members ready to offer FREE mental health services but need the FREE space to do it. Help offer these spaces so residents may get the support they need.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need free spaces to provide mental health services to residents - we have providers ready but lack accessible locations.
LABEL: Need Free Space

CONTENT: Accountability has proven almost impossible. There are countless state audits that demonstrate that. Additionally, there are multiple levels of accountability. Ad of today there appears to be no one who will take responsibility.
LLM_SUMMARY: This comment does not appear to directly address financial assistance distribution or allocation. The comment focuses on accountability issues but does not mention funding or aid distribution.
LABEL: Lack Of Accountability

CONTENT: Home rebuilding with a coordinated sourcing strategy for supplies to give us buyers more power against price gouging.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated bulk purchasing of rebuilding supplies to protect homeowners from price gouging and make reconstruction more affordable.
LABEL: collective purchasing power

CONTENT: Help us get the word out on organized rebuild efforts such as Altagether.org so as many residents as possible can be involved.  We are banding together in small groups to save on surveying costs, and potentially with architects and contractors.
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents are organizing in groups through Altagether.org to share costs of rebuilding, including surveys, architects, and contractors.
LABEL: Community Resource Sharing

CONTENT: I wish there was a team to help people find apartments. This is another headache!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need help finding new apartments - it's overwhelming to search for housing on our own.
LABEL: Housing Assistance Priority

CONTENT: More funding more grants more education on how to get these resources and agency support services!!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more funding, grants, and education about how to access disaster resources and support services.
LABEL: Prioritize Resource Access

CONTENT: It's expensive to live in a wildfire prone zone. Either that expense is paid by the people who live there (such as through insurance premiums) or by everyone else who doesn't live there (via taxes). We shouldn't accept unfair increases in insurance premiums, but it's hard to tell what is really fair.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs in fire-prone areas should be shared fairly between residents and taxpayers, but determining equitable rates is challenging.
LABEL: Insurance Versus Taxes

CONTENT: Make sure that seniors and people with disabilities are not left behind. Registries alone are not going to help much, offer dedicated funding
LLM_SUMMARY: Seniors and disabled residents need dedicated financial assistance - registries alone aren't enough to ensure they receive adequate support.
LABEL: Prioritize Vulnerable

CONTENT: Support for orgs that are already in this space, access to grants and funding for the continuing of their current missions. The community teams and grief brought on by these fires is overwhelming and needs to be addressed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Organizations need funding and grants to continue supporting communities overwhelmed by fire-related trauma and grief.
LABEL: funding existing organizations

CONTENT: Must be open and transparent process with competitive bidding.
LLM_SUMMARY: Assistance distribution must be transparent with competitive bidding to ensure fairness.
LABEL: Open Transparent Distribution

CONTENT: One immediate need is definitely financial support/grants/tax credits for home building and to address new code requirements. Instead of trying to waive the new code requirements to rebuild faster, let's give the community the chance to build back better
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial support through grants and tax credits should help homeowners meet new building codes, allowing us to rebuild better rather than waive requirements.
LABEL: Build Back Better

CONTENT: Let's make sure that everyone has awesome, effective infrastructure. I don't want my friends in Altadena to get stiffed in favor of a better recovery for the wealthier community in the Palisades, and I don't want one part of Altadena to get better support than another. Equity sounds like a fine term for what I'm asking for.
LLM_SUMMARY: Funds should be distributed fairly across all communities - wealthy Palisades shouldn't get better support than Altadena, and all Altadena neighborhoods deserve equal assistance.
LABEL: equal distribution priority

CONTENT: The entertainment industry, along with a lot of Los Angeles, has lost jobs over the past five years. We should focus on returning these individuals to work in our community whenever possible. While I get we have an outside contractor with expertise in this area, why don't we require them to hire people who have lived in LA for an extended period? Let's support those who have lost their jobs and those who currently reside here. We have a community in the know in the future, then.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local residents should get priority for disaster recovery jobs over outside contractors, helping unemployed LA community members get back to work.
LABEL: Local Employment Priority

CONTENT: I have been in a hotel for three months. The Landlord is harassing me and I am now trying to find a new apartment without any assistance. The Landlord has violated city laws and the city of Pasadena has not been helpful at all.
LLM_SUMMARY: I need help finding a new apartment after three months in a hotel. No assistance is available despite landlord harassment.
LABEL: Inadequate Housing Support

CONTENT: Needs to be expedited, Phase 2 is only 3% done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Disaster relief funding needs to be distributed faster - only 3% of Phase 2 has been completed.
LABEL: Expedited Fund Distribution

CONTENT: No one should be profiting from this - this is a disaster, not a business opportunity. While this also isn’t time for NIMBYism, I hope that relief can go to the community, and not to any speculators hoping to profit off of Angelenos.
LLM_SUMMARY: Relief funds should go directly to impacted community members, not speculators or businesses trying to profit from this disaster.
LABEL: Prioritize Community Relief

CONTENT:
Local businesses in Altadena that survived the fire have been destroyed by loss of the community.  We need to help these businesses stay open and keep people employed.  This is a critical part of our community. 
 Once everything closes, there will be nothing here except big box stores.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small local businesses need financial help to survive after the fire. Without support, only big chain stores will remain, destroying our community's character.
LABEL: Local Business Priority

CONTENT: An over-abundance of temporary housing will just lien wealthy people’s pockets will making it more difficult for people to acquire permanent housing.
LLM_SUMMARY: Temporary housing only benefits wealthy property owners while making it harder for people to find permanent homes.
LABEL: Temporary vs Permanent

CONTENT: We've got to take care of our neighbors, especially the ones who had their insurance dropped in the months leading up to the fires with no good alternative. But for anyone who could get insurance and decided not to, knowing they were in a fire zone? They should be on the hook for that bad decision, not the rest of us.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance-dropped neighbors deserve priority assistance, but those who chose not to insure despite living in fire zones shouldn't get public aid.
LABEL: Insurance Responsibility Prioritization

CONTENT: many are under insured if insured at all, must rebuild rapidly for people to afford to move back
LLM_SUMMARY: People are underinsured or uninsured, and need quick financial support to afford rebuilding and returning to their homes.
LABEL: Prioritize Underins

CONTENT: Everyone is financially stressed by this. Being self-employed is tough but especially when the documentation for assistance is based on paperwork that you wouldn't normally have. Adjust the requirements. I can't prove paychecks, or - as requested - prove lack of paychecks (impossible to prove a negative) to get assistance. Or provide a named location for work when I worked from home (and computer doesn't recognize that as a location) SoCal is known for its entrepreneurialism but then focuses on paperwork of employee status.
LLM_SUMMARY: Self-employed people struggle to qualify for wildfire assistance due to documentation requirements designed for traditional employees, ignoring SoCal's entrepreneurial nature.
LABEL: bureaucracy versus flexibility

CONTENT: There are hundreds of charities in the state that support this. There is a shortage of funding for those charities. There is also a shortage of people availing themselves to the services.
LLM_SUMMARY: Charities lack sufficient funding to help everyone, and many people aren't even accessing the available disaster assistance services.
LABEL: funding shortage awareness

CONTENT: Money should be going straight to the people affected by the fires and those in the city that are already housing insecure. Not to small businesses or non-profit middlemen that sap funding for their own gain. Funds should be used to build new affordable housing and fund direct relief to low-income/migrant families. Without affordable and safe housing and stable finances people do not have a chance to obtain employment or start their own businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should go directly to fire victims and housing-insecure residents, not businesses or nonprofits. Prioritize affordable housing and relief for low-income families.
LABEL: prioritize vulnerable populations

CONTENT: Seniors and the disabled community members, and those who are isolated are in real need of support. We need more outreach workers to ensure people are rehoused and doing wellness checks.
LLM_SUMMARY: Seniors, disabled, and isolated community members need priority support, with outreach workers ensuring proper rehousing and wellness monitoring.
LABEL: vulnerable populations prioritized

CONTENT: Broaden the C.C.C. mandate to take in more people, pay them, and help the community with cooperative neighborhood efforts.
LLM_SUMMARY: Communities need to expand paid positions in the California Conservation Corps to help more people while supporting neighborhood recovery efforts.
LABEL: Prioritize Community Support

CONTENT: Please start encouraging developers/business owners to expand there operations, more units will decrease the price, more business will stimulate the economy
LLM_SUMMARY: Increasing housing development and business growth will help make housing more affordable and boost the local economy.
LABEL: Market Based Economic Recovery

CONTENT: Mental health care is over burdened, especially compared to our already burdened health systems. A key to mental health is feeling safe, so mental recovery can’t begin until displaced members of our community have stability.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should prioritize housing stability for displaced residents - it's essential for mental health recovery and feeling safe again.
LABEL: Health Access Equity

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should invest taxpayer money to help communities meet strict fire resistance standards.
LABEL: Government Investment Priority

CONTENT: Again, this would be great, but I predict it would get so tied up by various interest groups I almost would rather you not bother. Please just slash regulations, stop trying to control prices, and let people get to work.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government aid gets tied up by interest groups. Better to reduce regulations and price controls so people can help themselves.
LABEL: Government Regulation Opposition

CONTENT: The free market can and will resolve personal and business financial and employment issues. Government should allow general liberty to work naturally.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should stay out of financial assistance distribution - let the free market naturally resolve personal and business recovery needs.
LABEL: Free Market Priority

CONTENT: Financial assistance needs to be made available for people with standing homes located in or near the burn areas. Our homes suffered extensive damage and/or were covered in toxic ash and debris. Many of us have to pay for expensive environmental testing and remediation out-of-pocket, up to and including replacing dry wall, flooring, a majority of our furniture, clothes, etc., but we are not currently eligible for most of the existing financial assistance.
LLM_SUMMARY: Homes near burn zones need financial aid too - we face costly toxic cleanup and repairs but aren't eligible for assistance since our houses didn't burn down.
LABEL: Assistance Eligibility

CONTENT:
Insurance companies had been moving out of this market, cancelling policies and raising the cost of premiums to the point of being unaffordable.

Rebuilding with fire, earthquake and storm resistant materials along with structure strengthening measures should be promoted as one way to help reduce insurance costs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies cancel policies and raise premiums until unaffordable. Fire-resistant rebuilding could help reduce these overwhelming costs.
LABEL: Insurance Costs Affordability

CONTENT: Close the gap on CFPs underinsurance so that people can rebuild back.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies need to address coverage gaps so people can afford to rebuild after disasters.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Equity

CONTENT: They can pay a bigger portion of their profits to fund the rebuilding of homes and maintenance of high-risk areas. Also Southern California Edison has two lawsuits filed against them "alleging faulty power lines may have sparked the Eaton Fire" -NPR
LLM_SUMMARY: Edison should pay more of their profits to rebuild homes and maintain high-risk areas, especially given lawsuits about their power lines causing fires.
LABEL: Corporate Financial Responsibility

CONTENT:
Reduce onerous building regulations. California citizens affected homeowners should be given preference 
.
LLM_SUMMARY: Affected California homeowners should receive priority for financial assistance, with fewer building regulations restricting their recovery.
LABEL: Local Residents Priority

CONTENT: The threat of not being able to insure our homes after this feels unfair and unjust. I have already been told by State Farm that they will not insure us after the 1 year mandate for standing buildings and 2 yrs for lost homes. We have paid our policies on time and for over 60years on lost home and 30 years for the apartment at Edgewaters'.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoning us after decades of on-time payments feels unfair. We can't get coverage after mandates expire, despite our 60-year payment history.
LABEL: Insurance Access Equity

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Public subsidies should help homeowners install fire-resistant roofing and building materials to protect their properties.
LABEL: Government Subsidies Support

CONTENT:
An eviction moratorium should go into effect for two months in a county whenever there is natural disaster. Then it can be fine-tuned and continued more specifically after the first 2 months. We had 3 fires going at once, hundreds of thousands getting displaced and evictions were still going on. Ridiculous.

ADUs should be allowed. 

Those of us in apartments are just getting forced out. The ash remediation was just not done and we had no help addressing it. AS tenants we had no ability to handle this ourselves. We were reliant on ownership who were so busy seeing dollar signs for potential rent they just didn't care.
LLM_SUMMARY: Tenants got no financial help with ash cleanup, while landlords ignored the problem and continued evictions despite mass displacement from fires.
LABEL: protect vulnerable renters

CONTENT:
We need you to extend the mandate that insurance companies not drop us. We have always paid our premiums and this loss had nothing to do with any of the insureds. But we risk having fully uninsured homes due to the fires. 

People with standing homes need clear guidance on the safety of living amongst and near burned structures. We need financial assistance- so many people not within the burn map boundary are just as displaced and have lost just as much but cannot access aid because of the map boundaries which weren’t drawn to facilitate aid, but that’s how it’s being used.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Insurance companies shouldn't drop us after fires, and aid shouldn't be restricted by burn map boundaries. People outside affected zones need help too."
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Access

CONTENT: Excellent items funded by previously appropriate taxation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Funding from existing tax revenue was appropriately used for disaster assistance.
LABEL: Equitable Taxation Distribution

CONTENT: Businesses need help, we need our businesses! Financing should be available to them at a very low interest rate. We love our small business owners and they need support.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need financial support through low-interest loans - they're vital to our community and deserve priority assistance.
LABEL: Business Priority Support

CONTENT: Individuals and businesses both need grants to support their transition.  After seeing how larger NGO's have managed these funds in the past, I've little to no support for them.  Both the city and the county should have an established list of people and businesses affected by the fires, and should be able to directly reach out to them for that effort.  If not, then that's a failure on their part.  Families and individuals both need businesses in the area to restart their lives, just as businesses needs them.
LLM_SUMMARY: Grants should go directly to affected individuals and businesses through city/county outreach, not through NGOs. Both groups need each other to recover.
LABEL: Direct Local Distribution

CONTENT: Partner with WatchDuty and maybe fund them, they’re a good non-profit that can provide essential support to the state.
LLM_SUMMARY: State should fund WatchDuty, a non-profit that could provide essential disaster support services.
LABEL: Non-profit Support Priority

CONTENT: We can't rebuild alone. We need help from EVERYONE -- the state and county government, from public donors, from community groups, and most of all each other. There are resources available but information about and access to services is all over the place. We desperately need a functioning hub with vetted information that will put us in contact with each other and provide information on how to access additional funding and support. And that hub MUST be virtual -- many of us had to move far away to find affordable housing and can't attend in person events.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated financial help from government and donors, but information is scattered. A virtual hub is crucial since many relocated for affordable housing.
LABEL: Need Coordinated Resources

CONTENT: We need better equitable contracting practices to ensure that the tax payer funds use for services actually have outcomes that benefit our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Tax dollars for disaster services should directly benefit our community through equitable contracting practices.
LABEL: equitable funding distribution

CONTENT: I was in a fire recovery support group, and hearing the stories of people waiting in lines for vouchers for 8 hours is a joke. Working class people don't have the time for that. Older people shouldn't have to stand in a line for that long. And the people waiting in that line weren't even all guaranteed relief! The whole day passed and people after the 400th person were denied. Also - of the people who received relief vouchers, they then had to go to a Walmart to cash them (which some employees didn't even know how to do). There is one too many steps involved. A relief voucher should be minimal steps. What if people don't have easy access to transportation? And why is the government relying on private corporations? It's just so dystopic.
LLM_SUMMARY: The voucher system is unfair - working class and elderly can't wait 8 hours in line, many get denied, and requiring Walmart redemption creates transportation barriers.
LABEL: Inefficient Aid Distribution

CONTENT: We need federal assistance no strings attached just like in every other disaster. We need FEMA!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need unconditional federal assistance and FEMA support, just like other disaster victims receive.
LABEL: Federal Aid Priority

CONTENT: Many people's insurances pulled out and now they are left with nothing. Steps need to be taken to ensure that people can get the money they deserve to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies abandoned homeowners, leaving them without funds to rebuild. We need to ensure people receive the financial support they deserve.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Priority

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: State should subsidize required fire safety upgrades for rebuilding survivors through grants and tax rebates, or waive requirements to avoid burdening homeowners.
LABEL: Government Financial Support

CONTENT: Streamlining support for small businesses to revitalize neighborhoods, please! Let the fruit carts and taco trucks thrive!
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses like fruit carts and taco trucks need priority access to financial support to help neighborhoods recover.
LABEL: Small Business Priority

CONTENT: Ensuring that people with disabilities and seniors be a targeted priority outreach, evacuation, and support population for all natural disasters, such as wild fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize disabled people and seniors for disaster support, evacuation assistance, and financial aid during wildfires.
LABEL: vulnerable populations prioritized

CONTENT: This hasn't been a large problem for my wife and myself. But we have met many other survivors that do need some assistance in this area. Offering online assistance might be a great solution for those that have access to online assistance. Perhaps some group sessions of those suffering similar afflictions might be beneficial too. Offering cultural appropriate group sessions with multilingual would be a good idea too.
