LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should be accessible online, but also through in-person multilingual group sessions to help those who need assistance.
LABEL: accessibility equity focus

CONTENT:
I am writing to bring attention to a critical gap in the recent executive order issued by Governor Gavin Newsom to expedite rebuilding efforts for residents affected by the current Los Angeles County wildfires. While this order offers a lifeline to those impacted by the Palisades and Eaton Fires, it excludes countless residents who have been struggling to rebuild their lives and homes after previous disasters, such as the Woolsey Fire (2018), Franklin Fire (2024),Mountain Fire(2024) Bobcat Fire (2020), Creek Fire (2017), Sand Fire (2016), La Tuna Fire (2017), and Saddleridge Fire (2019). I am sure there are others that I am missing.


These past fires left thousands of Californians grappling with complex permitting processes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial assistance for rebuilding should include residents impacted by previous LA County fires, not just those affected by recent Palisades and Eaton fires.
LABEL: prioritize recent victims

CONTENT: Yes, grants to business owners who lost everything is essential as they are an essential part of any community and keep the communities running.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business owners deserve financial aid since they're vital to our community's survival - they lost everything and need help to rebuild.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Grants should go to small businesses and individuals who have been established in the community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses and established community members should be prioritized for disaster relief grants.
LABEL: Local Business Priority

CONTENT: local business is critical but often a forgotten stakeholders in all of this.  they need to be prioritized.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses are often forgotten stakeholders in disaster recovery and should be prioritized when distributing financial assistance.
LABEL: Business Priority Assistance

CONTENT: This will be money wasted on something that people can access through insurance, a plethora of online services/apps.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance already covers these needs. Additional financial assistance would be wasteful when other resources are available.
LABEL: Insurance Covers Needs

CONTENT: Restaurants and small businesses everywhere in LA, not just the burn zones, need help.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses across LA need financial assistance, not just those directly in wildfire-affected areas.
LABEL: Broad Economic Support

CONTENT: We need help with insurance claims. State Farm and other insurance companies are blatantly violating the law by issuing blanket denials of many types of claims. We shouldn't all need to hire attorneys to get the insurance companies to honor our policies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies are wrongfully denying claims, forcing us to hire lawyers just to receive the coverage we paid for.
LABEL: Insurance Company Accountability

CONTENT: Force Insurance Companies to cover toxin testing inside smoke damaged homes. If the health department says we should be concerned about this why does insurance refuse to cover it? How can we feel safe moving back in our homes. The testing is very expensive…$5-$10 thousand depending on tests necessary. We paid close to $7000.00 out of pocket and are awaiting results. Many do not have the resources to pay for this themselves.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't cover $5,000-$10,000 toxin testing in smoke-damaged homes, forcing residents to pay out-of-pocket. Many can't afford these essential
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Fairness

CONTENT: The insurance market is a disaster. I was told days before the fire that my insurance carrier no longer met the rating requirements of my mortgage lender so I cancelled my insurance policy effective 1/10/25 while my wife and I were getting quotes with other companies. We were going to be underwritten on 1/10/25 but the moratorium after the fires stopped that process and we couldn’t reinstate our previous policy because I cancelled it before the fires but it wouldn’t fulfill my mortgage requirements anyways. After 10 days of no insurance immediately after the fires, we joined the FAIR plan and then got charged an insane amount from our lender for the lapse in insurance coverage. My house didn’t burn and still no word from other insurers!
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies left us stranded before the fire, then we couldn't get new coverage due to fire moratorium. Now stuck paying excessive rates through FAIR plan.
LABEL: Insurance Market Failure

CONTENT: Attention to roadblocks due to Trump's tariffs and deportations. Please provide a safe place for undocumented immigrants who want to help us rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Undocumented immigrants need protection and inclusion in rebuilding efforts, but current policies create barriers to their participation in disaster recovery.
LABEL: Immigration Status Fairness

CONTENT: The city needs to build more public affordable housing and change zoning restrictions to allow for more multi-use properties. Those affected by the fires and those already facing housing insecurity are facing price gouging of rents and over-inflated property values making it impossible to live in this city, even before the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fires worsen housing affordability crisis - victims face price gouging and inflated rents, making it impossible to stay in the city.
LABEL: Housing Access Priority

CONTENT: Our fire fighters need better benefits to secure their families futures. It does no good to fund these programs and under pay the people to do this highly dangerous job
LLM_SUMMARY: Firefighters deserve better pay and benefits given the dangerous nature of their work, not just program funding.
LABEL: Prioritize First Resp

CONTENT: I need help with resources. I was just informed that I have to move because my Landlord is not trying to professionally clean my place even though it is against the law.
LLM_SUMMARY: Landlord won't professionally clean after fire damage, forcing me to move. I need financial assistance but don't know where to get help.
LABEL: Landlord Tenant Rights

CONTENT: The DRCs are a great resource, but people are overwhelmed and some have trouble getting to them. We need some form of community outreach that potentially goes to people as opposed to requiring them to come to the DRC.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need mobile outreach services to bring disaster assistance directly to people, since many struggle to reach the Disaster Recovery Centers.
LABEL: accessibility versus centralization

CONTENT: We still need tax revenue for essential services like disaster recovery. Raising taxes on worker classes while dropping taxes on business has been proven to hurt the state of CA in the long run. We should not go back.
LLM_SUMMARY: Raising taxes on workers while lowering business taxes hurts California's ability to fund essential disaster recovery services.
LABEL: Progressive Tax Support

CONTENT: Supporting local businesses should   be a very high priority. With restricted traffic and homeowners evacuation it will be extremely difficult for local businesses to continue to operate profitably. I worked from my home and lost everything in the fire. IT has proven very difficult trying to operate my business without my tools of office files. Grants have helped but it hasn't been enough.  I see millions of dollars being raised for fire relief but it hasn't really helped us so far.
LLM_SUMMARY: Grants helped but weren't enough. Despite millions raised for fire relief, local businesses like mine struggle to survive after losing everything.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: FEMA-like trailers parked in public lots with help nearby
LLM_SUMMARY: Provide temporary housing in public lots with nearby support services.
LABEL: temporary housing priority

CONTENT: Debris removal, absolutely.  habitat restoration, that can wait.  Take care of the immediate needs first.
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize immediate needs like debris removal first. Habitat restoration can wait until later.
LABEL: immediate needs priority

CONTENT: We live in a place that has fire vegetation that needs to have fire in order to replant. The more suppression you do, the worse the consequence. We need to find a way to balance. We need to ensure that housing goes to people and not corporations. We need to put the human back in humanity. No one should have to go bankrupt to sleep somewhere. Remove the double rents for renters affected by the fires. So many people are going to be sick and die from the toxins, we need to be ready.
LLM_SUMMARY: Housing assistance should prioritize people over corporations, and renters shouldn't pay double rent when displaced by fires.
LABEL: Housing Access Priority

CONTENT: Provide private adjusters at no cost for people with the holdout companies on personal property. There are not enough reputable affordable adjusters and many are scammers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should provide free private adjusters since reputable ones are scarce and expensive, while scammers prey on disaster victims.
LABEL: Equitable Insurance Support

CONTENT: Eliminate new code requirements, residents are dealing with enough and they don't have unlimited funds for new code upgrades. Let residents build at a minimum to what they had before without all the bureaucracy. The city and county already provide massive amounts of 'legal aid' for tenants and illegals there is no need to reinvent the wheel.
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents can't afford new code requirements. Let them rebuild what they had before without costly upgrades. Aid should focus on existing needs.
LABEL: Oppose Additional Requirements

CONTENT: Not taking this opportunity to improve all infrastructure in Altadena would be foolish and short sighted. I understand it’s enormously expensive, but I have confidence that if considerable effort is invested into procuring funds, this can be accomplished.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need funding to improve all of Altadena's infrastructure, not just fire-damaged areas. It's expensive but worth pursuing the resources.
LABEL: Infrastructure Investment Over Aid

CONTENT: Require insurance companies to issue 100% of personal property coverage for completely destroyed homes and 75% for standing homes within the burn zone without inventory lists.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should pay full coverage for destroyed homes and 75% for damaged homes in burn zones, without requiring itemized lists.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Requirements

CONTENT: Watch Duty should be publicly funded
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should fund Watch Duty to provide equal access to wildfire alerts and information.
LABEL: Public Funding Priority

CONTENT: Direct financial assistance to residents. Many are uninsured or those who are will have a GAP in order to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Provide direct financial aid to residents - many are uninsured or face coverage gaps that prevent rebuilding.
LABEL: Prioritize Unins

CONTENT:
The mail. I know that's a federal issue but for heavens sake the mail was a mess. 

Let state/county/city items be forwarded. 

I have been fighting with mail for months now. i tried putting a hold on it, but that didn't work. Then i tried forwarding to an accessible mail place, but most government mail isn't allowed to be forwarded so I would apply for help and kept getting notified that I had address issues and would be disqualified from programs etc. I would tell them "I'm evacuated/displaced and getting mail forwarded" but it caused a massive issue. It still is causing delays, cancellations, and confusion.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Government mail can't be forwarded during evacuation, causing me to be disqualified from assistance programs because of address issues."
LABEL: Mail Forwarding Barriers

CONTENT:
For victims that are still experiencing homelessness we need to rent out a old hotel or a designated hotel for those who have been impacted and unable to afford housing at the current moment !! This will
Help them get on their feet to save money for mortgages and future rebuilding expenses!!
LLM_SUMMARY: We should provide temporary hotel housing for fire victims who are homeless, helping them save money for rebuilding and future housing costs.
LABEL: Housing First Aid Priority

CONTENT: A route to ownership should be available for all renters. Passive income landlord arrangements hurt communities by building cheap, flippable homes, overcrowding lots, building in a manner that isn't sensitive to the needs of families and children. If people owned their own property because they had assistance to purchase we'd all be better off.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters should receive financial assistance to become homeowners, as this would create better communities than landlord-driven development focused on profit.
LABEL: Ownership Over Renting

CONTENT:
Insurance companies should be held responsible for paying the claims on the policies that they willingly sold to residents in the affected areas.  But we also have to acknowledge that they are beholden to their shareholders and will non-renew or exit CA if they can't make a profit.

It could help to require insurance companies to offer incentives for more fire-resistant construction.  Loosening regulations on the insurance industry is something I'm hesitant to support, but if insurance rates are determined by market forces and not a government commission, it could lead to more companies entering the market which would keep prices in check.  Rates will still be higher, but CA rates are lower than many other states with lower disaster risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must pay claims but need profit to stay in California. Market-driven rates and incentives for fire-resistant construction could help maintain coverage availability.
LABEL: Insurance Market Regulation

CONTENT: Practice the preparedness training.  Offer monetary incentives to those who participate and practice the preparedness drills.
LLM_SUMMARY: Those who participate in preparedness drills should receive monetary incentives as compensation.
LABEL: incentivize preparedness training

CONTENT: Permitting costs should be waved. We aren’t building an addition, we are rebuilding our lives after a huge tragedy. Give us a break.
LLM_SUMMARY: Waive rebuilding permit costs - we're not adding luxuries, we're trying to recover from tragedy.
LABEL: waive permit costs

CONTENT: Renters and homeowners may need real financial assistance, even if they are uninsured or underinsured.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone needs financial help after disasters, regardless of insurance status or whether they rent or own their home.
LABEL: assistance for all

CONTENT:
They needs to be one stop
Shop to assist all victims with counseling housing monetary support and job opportunities!!
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone affected needs a centralized location to access financial aid, housing assistance, counseling, and employment help.
LABEL: Support All Victims

CONTENT: Local business assistance should be spared for those who really need it. We don't need a situation like the PPP loans where the well off ran away with a huge chunk of the pie meant for others.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should prioritize truly needy businesses, not repeat PPP loan mistakes where wealthy businesses took resources meant for others.
LABEL: Need Based Distribution

CONTENT: Lets choose the best alternatives in shot AND long run, on the topics we covered specially on the residential-commercial structures AND in the thermal exterior walls coverings. AND work on the grants.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to work on securing grants and determining how to distribute financial assistance for residential and commercial building improvements.
LABEL: Prioritize Long Term

CONTENT: Rather than tax, tax, tax to create subsidies, let's make it easier for businesses to operate. Cut the red tape. Incentivize them to stay in Los Angeles.
LLM_SUMMARY: Reduce taxes and regulations instead of creating subsidies; incentivize businesses to stay in Los Angeles.
LABEL: Market Over Subsidies

CONTENT: should not be assessed for ADU will assist folks to move back to neighborhood faster and/or could assist housing some of the trades needed to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: ADU fees should be waived - it would help people return to their neighborhoods faster and provide housing for reconstruction workers.
LABEL: Prioritize Housing Recovery

CONTENT: Please offer generous assistance programs to homeowners/entities who are confirmed to have lost their homes in the fires. I understand that not everyone can be fully compensated (California does not have the $ for that), but maybe a base, across-the-board $25000-30000 compensation check?
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone who lost homes should get baseline compensation of $25,000-30,000, since full compensation isn't financially feasible for California.
LABEL: equal base compensation

CONTENT: Allowing residents to have ADU's on their property would support transition from interim housing (i.e., hotels, temporary rentals, etc.) to their own property whereby they can then manage their own property again and the rebuilding project of their main home.  Transitioning to the main home upon completion.
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs on residents' property could provide temporary housing during rebuilding, letting owners manage their property while transitioning back to their main home.
LABEL: Housing Support Priority

CONTENT: Ensure existing homeowners near affected areas won’t have their insurance skyrocket when their renewals come due.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs shouldn't skyrocket for homeowners near fire zones when policies come up for renewal.
LABEL: Insurance Cost Protection

CONTENT: Grants are essential, but they need to be more accessible to individual people. We’re seeing a lot of money go to “organizations”, but the people need it directly. We don’t need funded services that are difficult to access, we need cash in hand to meet our needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Direct cash assistance should go to individuals instead of organizations. People need money in hand, not hard-to-access funded services.
LABEL: direct individual assistance

CONTENT:
When it comes to managing dollars, people want to see the overall dollars being distributed via programs. 

If there's 10,000 homes and businesses burnt, and we have $6B collectively raised for every single program from mental health to temporary housing, to environmental cleanups...

That's nearly $600,000 per structure on top of their insurance payments. If that's the case, just give them the bulk of the money and let the communities self organize and solve their repair. Pool a portion of the money into local government accounts for things like rebuilding schools and repairing sidewalks. 

If the number is much much less, like $1B, mostly not cash, and not all available today, then fine build it all out slowly with programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Just give people the bulk of disaster money directly and let communities organize repairs themselves, while pooling some for public infrastructure rebuilding."
LABEL: funding transparency needed

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Those living in fire zones should pay most rebuilding costs, though I'd support tax assistance for less wealthy areas like Altadena.
LABEL: Support Need-Based Aid

CONTENT:
Reduce permit fees 
Assist in the rebuild reduce cost of supplies to help
LLM_SUMMARY: Reduce permit fees and costs of supplies, and provide rebuilding assistance to help those affected.
LABEL: reduce financial burden

CONTENT: Everyone who lost their homes in the fires deserves assistance regardless of legal status.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone deserves financial help after losing their home in the fires, regardless of immigration status.
LABEL: equal assistance distribution

CONTENT: Please hire local people in Los Angeles for available jobs. The job market is challenging right now, and our tax dollars should be used to help our own community find work while recovering.
LLM_SUMMARY: Local tax dollars should fund jobs for LA residents during recovery - we need work opportunities in our own impacted community.
LABEL: Local Employment Priority

CONTENT: Since Trump has blamed California for not engaging in forest management, could we request funding for clearing dead brush AND downed trees that are still not cleaned up from that big wind event. Generate jobs that way.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need funding for brush clearing and tree removal, which could create local jobs, but federal assistance is being withheld over forest management disputes.
LABEL: funding for management

CONTENT:
Insurance is the main financial driver in recovery. our insurance department, in the last decade has done very little to refine and make the claims process better for citizens.

Making claims more transparent, making policies which make more sense, it isn't rocket science.

90% of folks end up underinsured. Not an accident. A failed system.

When HO3 policies are approved in this state - the Dept should force companies to reveal their claims process and then hold them to it after a disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance claims are intentionally complex and opaque, leaving 90% of homeowners underinsured. The state needs to enforce transparency and accountability from insurance companies.
LABEL: Insurance System Failure

CONTENT: The burn map cannot be used to determine eligibility. There are thousands of residents displaced due to smoke/soot/ash damage that are within the 250 yard health advisory boundary of the burn and they aren’t eligible for assistance because they aren’t in the burn area even though they are just as displaced and have lost all their interior contents. We’re being hung out to dry.
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents just outside burn zones suffer same smoke damage and displacement but are denied aid, while those within burn area receive assistance.
LABEL: Beyond Burn Zone

CONTENT: People lost their homes, jobs, and were displaced. This country gives MILLIONS OF DOLLARS to other countries. We can use some of that money!
LLM_SUMMARY: We send millions in foreign aid while our own fire victims struggle without homes and jobs. That money should help Americans first.
LABEL: Aid For Americans First

CONTENT: new code requirements.  go back to the 2010/2012 code requirements.  we can't afford today's requirements and they don't work for this massive rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't afford current building code requirements for rebuilding. Return to older codes to make reconstruction financially feasible.
LABEL: Affordability Versus Requirements

CONTENT:
Things to be addressed first in recovery:
1- Priority #1: Make sure all toxic debris has been cleared out (including charred structures, cars, and flora/trees). There should also be thorough environment analysis of the topsoil in: PP, Malibu, and Altadena- to make sure there are no toxins hiding in the ground that could lead to increased cancer rates in the future.
2-Secondary priority: Make sure that current occupants/tenants/homeowners DO NOT LOSE THEIR HOMES. Mandatory moratorium on mortgage payments and rent for the rest of 2025. People should not be made to pay for property that is burned out. 
3-Teritary priority: Generous assistance for home insurance policyholders as they attempt to rebuild (maybe ~$50k per household?)
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance holders deserve rebuilding assistance, but we must ensure renters and homeowners don't lose homes through mandatory mortgage and rent moratoriums.
LABEL: prioritize toxic cleanup

CONTENT: Government should step in above greedy developers to help survivors. There is no better time than now to start community land trusts while also building community public housing that serves everyone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government aid should prioritize survivors' needs over developers, using funds to create community land trusts and public housing for all.
LABEL: Government Over Private

CONTENT: Agree. Our lender said any kind of forbearance or deferment would result in a re-negotiation of the entire loan. This is not helpful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lender said forbearance or loan deferment would force entire loan renegotiation, which isn't helpful for disaster recovery.
LABEL: Loan Assistance Barriers

CONTENT: The underinsured and uninsured need a lot more help. Also we need grants for rebuilding smaller commercial property and to help small businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses, underinsured, and uninsured people need more financial assistance and grants to rebuild after disasters.
LABEL: Prioritize Underins

CONTENT:
AS a tenant in Santa Monica I was flat out of luck. I just had to move out of my unit two weeks ago because the owner was refusing to do the needed ash mitigation and refused to speak about it. Because I was 1 block outside "the fire zone" I didn't qualify for help even though had an apartment filled with ash. Fights with landlord ensued and there was no protection from eviction.

Nearby communities are impacted too. I get that the line has to be drawn somewhere but this is ridiculous.

So exhausted with having had a huge impact but no help because I am one block out of zone and had an apartment.

I have some ALE but it took a long while to kick in and I had no idea how to navigate it. I still need help understanding how insurance can help
LLM_SUMMARY: Living one block outside the designated fire zone disqualified me from aid, despite ash damage. Tenants like me need help too.
LABEL: Tenants Need Protection

CONTENT: Insurance companies must be held accountable for claims. They are in the insurance business. That is a risk reward business. Extreme profit at the expense of people is unacceptable.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies must pay claims fairly - they profit from risk but shouldn't exploit disaster victims for extreme gains.
LABEL: Insurance Company Accountability

CONTENT: the insurance commissioner needs to step up their game and work with the legislature to change some rules.  If an insurance company offers homeowners insurance in another state but cancels it here in california, all of their other lines of insurance (renters, auto, life, motorcycle) should not be allowed in the state either. insurance commissioner needs to be certain that premiums are fair, insurance language is exceedingly clear leaving no wiggle room, and that collecting on insurance sure be an automatic and smooth process for the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should be required to offer homeowners coverage in California if they want to sell any insurance here, and payouts should be automatic and fair.
LABEL: Insurance Reform Needed

CONTENT: Insurance companies need to make it easier to access ALE while it is unsafe to live in standing homes in the impacted area.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should make temporary living expenses more accessible when homes are unsafe but still standing in fire zones.
LABEL: Insurance Access And Fairness

CONTENT: We need help. We got no help on January 7th when our town burned down and we are receiving little support now. Banks should be forced to let everyone in these communities to have a safe out and a forbearance for at least 6 months or a year with the balance going on at the end of the loan term. We have been told by chase bank that we will owe 4 months in May, how is this helpful?! The state needs to speak up on our behalf! We pay so much in taxes and for what??
LLM_SUMMARY: Banks should provide 6-12 month loan forbearance with balance added to end of term. Instead, we're being forced to pay multiple months at once.
LABEL: Insufficient Financial Support

CONTENT: People were impacted differently. It would be good to review the different segments such as renters, smoked out but still standing, and total loss (among others). Each are experiencing different obstacles and the government could be better prepared in future wildfires by understanding the unique concerns of each.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should be tailored to different groups - renters, smoke-damaged homes, and total losses - since each faces unique challenges.
LABEL: Prioritize Different Segments

CONTENT: I agree that money should not be spent on the monopolization of internet providers like Spectrum or AT&T. Money should go towards local and government infrastructure where able.
LLM_SUMMARY: Money should go to local and government infrastructure instead of being spent on internet provider monopolies like Spectrum and AT&T.
LABEL: Government Infrastructure Priority

CONTENT: The government should be helping homeowners that have homes that are standing to retrofit for fire safety. Codes need to be updated with fire safety at the forefront without any red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should help homeowners retrofit homes for fire safety, with streamlined building codes prioritizing fire prevention.
LABEL: Government Support Homeowners

CONTENT: The California Fair Plan is failing its policyholders in a big way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance through California Fair Plan is inadequate and failing to properly support policyholders.
LABEL: Insurance System Failing

CONTENT: Small business owners should be able to qualify for grants and local business assistance. Government must be critical of tracking the funds and making sure it's going to the correct hands.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses deserve disaster grants, but government must carefully track funds to ensure aid reaches the right recipients.
LABEL: Prioritize Business Recovery

CONTENT:
Insurance company made a lot of $$$$$ now they are leaving, asking for any nonsense or single bs details about any property even a shadow of a roof is a denial for them.
We need more effort from the insurance commissioner
Not just for Homeowners 
Bussines Owners, Worker's Compensation and all those insurance we normally paid e every single day/month.
We need a specific rule for these and everything about the insurance Bussines network..
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies deny claims over minor details while abandoning coverage. We need stronger insurance commissioner oversight for homeowners, businesses, and workers.
LABEL: Insurance Fairness Neede

CONTENT: This is a critical role of government but it needs to be done in a way that ensures safety and safe removal of toxic debris. This also needs to be done in a way that treats all communities equitably (not wealthy neighborhoods first), and with an environmental justice lens
LLM_SUMMARY: Assistance must be distributed equitably across all communities, not prioritizing wealthy neighborhoods first, while maintaining safety standards for toxic debris removal.
LABEL: equitable distribution prioritized

CONTENT: Clean the debris FAST. Waive permit fees for the people who are rebuilding, whether that means like for like or smaller or bigger than what they had. Direct GRANT to homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Waive permit fees for rebuilding and provide direct grants to homeowners, regardless of whether they rebuild same size or different.
LABEL: Prioritize Direct Assistance

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire hardening should be community-wide, not just for those who can afford it. We need financial assistance to protect everyone, not just wealthy homeowners.
LABEL: Community-wide Financial Support

CONTENT: Invest in Community Land Trusts. Rebuild affordable housing for all. Protect the most vulnerable. Housing is a human right.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild affordable housing and protect vulnerable residents through Community Land Trusts - housing is a human right.
LABEL: Housing Rights For All

CONTENT: There is still a lot of confusion about what FEMA and SBA can help with. I hear from from a lot of people even if they have insurance.
LLM_SUMMARY: People are confused about FEMA and SBA assistance options, even those with insurance coverage.
LABEL: Assistance Access Confusion

CONTENT: Standing aside doesn't seem to be working. These insurance companies don't want to pay out anything and someone has got to twist their arm.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies refuse to pay claims fairly - someone needs to force them to provide proper compensation.
LABEL: Insurance Company Resistance

CONTENT: Legal aid necessary
LLM_SUMMARY: Legal aid should be available to help fire victims navigate financial assistance programs.
LABEL: Legal Support For All

CONTENT: Having been non renewed by my insurance company I think it is critical to assist homeowners rebuild their homes through a grant program. To keep the community flavor it will require getting year old owners back in their homes. Otherwise the old neighborhood will be replaced with money hungry developers with no thought of community only profit. Tenants will need access to new apartment building so assisting the owners rebuild in a timely fashion with also be critical
LLM_SUMMARY: Grants should help homeowners rebuild quickly, preventing developers from taking over. Both homeowners and tenants need support to preserve the community's character.
LABEL: Prioritize Homeowner

CONTENT: Connecting residents with resources is clearly a huge gap in the current landscape. Support and safety net services are siloed and difficult to follow and access
LLM_SUMMARY: Resources and financial support services are too disconnected and hard to access for residents who need disaster assistance.
LABEL: Connect Resources Equitably

CONTENT: This is so very important. Altadena's backbone is small, mom 'n pop businesses, and they cannot come back without support. Otherwise soulless, generic chains will fill the void.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small local businesses in Altadena need financial support to recover, or chain stores will take over, destroying the community's character.
LABEL: Local Business Priority

CONTENT: Our senior community, especially in Altadena, needs support navigating this disaster!
LLM_SUMMARY: Seniors in our Altadena community need help accessing disaster support and financial assistance.
LABEL: Prioritize Vulnerable

CONTENT: There should not be so many road blocks for a tax paying citizen that has lost EVERYTHING to remove the toxic ash from their property!! Why is the city sitting on so many ROE firms and denying permits for private companies??
LLM_SUMMARY: Taxpaying citizens who lost everything face too many roadblocks getting permits to remove toxic ash, while the city delays Right of Entry forms.
LABEL: Government Bureaucracy Barriers

CONTENT: There should be more grants and employment opportunities for people who have been displaced and lost jobs. We are struggling and no one seems to care. The state seems to have moved on.
LLM_SUMMARY: The state needs to provide more grants and jobs for displaced residents who lost work. We're struggling but have been forgotten.
LABEL: Aid For Job-Loss

CONTENT:
It is especially concerning for people who are of retirement age and/or elderly.

For a company to abandon a customer of so many years like you have been must almost feel like getting caught up in a Ponzi scheme.

We can all understand, the risk/reward profile is not favorable for them and why they want to divest themselves of California policies.

Special consideration should be made for those who have been loyal customers and are past the age where they can start over.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should prioritize elderly, long-term customers who can't easily start over when distributing assistance or maintaining coverage.
LABEL: elderly prioritization needed

CONTENT: expansion of broadband is essential but the data providers took all the ACP money and now thats over
LLM_SUMMARY: Government assistance money went to internet companies instead of helping fire victims who needed financial support.
LABEL: Equitable Access Funding

CONTENT: Although the EPA came by my house already and cleaned up the army Corp has been by the house multiple times but haven't started in their cleanup. I realize there are 15,000 structures needing cleanup but I think more contractors should be brought in to assist.  As far as habitat restoration as critical as that is, getting the houses restored I think should be a higher priority. Restoring water should also be a very high priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: More contractors should be hired to speed up home restoration - it should take priority over habitat restoration, with 15,000 structures needing cleanup.
LABEL: Prioritize Housing Recovery

CONTENT: Allow RVs on property for a fixed period.  Don't create excessive government agencies for temporary issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should provide direct aid to property owners instead of creating new agencies to manage temporary housing needs.
LABEL: temporary housing assistance

CONTENT: state farm is trying to resist paying out and is claiming that in order to get 50% payout now we have to sign a form that in 36 months they are no longer liable to pay more. they also are requiring a list of all private property even if house is complete loss.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance company demands we sign away rights to future claims after 36 months for partial payout now, while requiring detailed property lists despite total loss.
LABEL: Insurance Resistance Payment

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and tax dollars shouldn't subsidize rebuilding in high-risk fire zones, even though my grandmother and her neighbors want to rebuild there.
LABEL: Risk Versus Rights

CONTENT: Push insurance companies to simply pay out 100% on total losses, as we are all under insured anyhow.  This has occurred in prior fires, and we are desperately needing to rebuild sooner than later, so knowing a budget is key, and key now.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should pay 100% on total losses since we're all underinsured. We need to rebuild quickly and need budget certainty now.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Priority

CONTENT: Can someone set up a grant finder website?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a website to help people find and access available disaster relief grants.
LABEL: Need Resource Navigation

CONTENT: Legal aid to help those affected navigate the overly complex world of insurance and permits for building is incredibly important and necessary to support community and prevent investors from controlling the market.
LLM_SUMMARY: Legal aid should be provided to help fire victims navigate insurance claims and building permits, preventing predatory investors from taking advantage.
LABEL: Legal Aid Priority

CONTENT: Underinsurance and lack of insurance is obviously going to be a huge problem. Hopefully organizations will step up to offer options in terms of cheaper builds and getting creative for funding/grants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Hoping organizations provide creative funding solutions and cheaper rebuilding options to help those who are underinsured or lack insurance coverage.
LABEL: Insurance Access Equity

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs for rebuilding in high-risk fire zones should be paid by those communities, not spread across low-risk areas of the state.
LABEL: High Risk Responsibility

CONTENT: Insurance companies should pay all policy limits for inventory and property value. Future wildfire survivors are paying for those limits, the insurance companies shouldn’t make the process difficult to collect those limits.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies should fully pay policy limits without making the claims process difficult, since wildfire survivors have already paid for that coverage.
LABEL: Insurance Payment Priority

CONTENT: Rent gouging is rampant. I'm grateful the AG has prioritized investigations into guilty landlords, but I'm in a delicate spot of not wanting to lose housing while I've been collecting materials for a case. There has got to be a way to nip this in the bud earlier, so that a homeseeker isn't intimidated by retaliation. Can we CC in some sort of caseworker to let a landlord know we mean business?
LLM_SUMMARY: Landlords are price gouging after the fires, but tenants fear retaliation if they report it. We need better protections and support when filing complaints.
LABEL: Rent Protection Priority

CONTENT: More incentives for businesses to come back. We are still destitute in Paradise CA
LLM_SUMMARY: Businesses need incentives to return since our community remains economically devastated after the fire.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Those who had good insurance or money to rebuild were able to take advantage of grants early on. The grants offered are first come first serve. In my community of Paradise CA, fixed income, low income and lower med. income were offered loans because they received tiny payouts from the PG$E bankruptcy stretched out over 6 years. Most were not able to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Lower and middle-income residents couldn't rebuild because they only received small, delayed payouts, while wealthy residents quickly accessed grants through first-come-first-serve systems.
LABEL: wealthy receive priority aid

CONTENT: Coordinate better with the home owners
LLM_SUMMARY: Homeowners need better coordination for receiving financial assistance.
LABEL: Prioritize Homeowner

CONTENT: We are middle income family-working class.  We need grants and we need the help.
LLM_SUMMARY: We're working class and need financial help too - grants shouldn't just be for low-income families.
LABEL: Working Class Assistance

CONTENT: Rebuild to new codes and fire safe is not affordable. Even if you do rebuild to fire safety Insurance lies and does not insure regardless of how safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance won't cover rebuilding to new fire safety codes, making it unaffordable even when following all requirements.
LABEL: Affordability Versus Safety

CONTENT: We must support those who lost their businesses and were employing local workers. For communities to prosper, we must incentivize the local economy to ensure everyone not only recovers, but everyone thrives.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small business owners should get priority aid since they employ locals - supporting them helps the whole community recover and thrive.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: Please expedite permitting and waive the necessary fees
LLM_SUMMARY: Waive fees and speed up permit processing for those affected by the fires.
LABEL: expedite permit process

CONTENT: We used FEMA debris remove, but they didn't take away the damaged driveway or damaged walkway or burned trees and we are going to spend our money to finalize the debris removal.  Insurance company's coverage is so limited for Coverage B.  I feel this is not right.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and FEMA's limited coverage forced us to pay out-of-pocket for debris removal. The coverage restrictions feel unfair.
LABEL: Limited Insurance Coverage

CONTENT: I agree, there should be more support for our most vulnerable in our communities! Seniors, veterans, disabled, people with less than who were displaced/affected from any disaster including fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Support should prioritize vulnerable community members - seniors, veterans, disabled, and low-income people displaced by disasters.
LABEL: prioritize vulnerable populations

CONTENT: Depends on the community.  I sense this is more needed in Altadena than Palisades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Financial aid should prioritize Altadena over Pacific Palisades since the communities have different economic needs.
LABEL: Need Based Distribution

CONTENT: We need our small businesses to be made whole.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need full financial compensation to recover from wildfire losses.
LABEL: Business Recovery Priority

CONTENT: All Utility companies need to be made FULLY accountable. PG$E was NOT made fully accountable only 70% accountable. Victims throughout CA need to be fully compensated-100%!
LLM_SUMMARY: Victims deserve 100% compensation, not partial payouts like PG&E's 70%. Utility companies must be held fully accountable for wildfire damages.
LABEL: Utility Company Accountability

CONTENT: Our loss of use coverage is up to 2 years.  I don't think we can rebuild our home in 24 month from this point... We need more help after 2 years from the fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance's two-year loss coverage isn't enough time to rebuild. We need extended financial support beyond that period.
LABEL: Insurance Coverage Limits

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies for all. bi-monthly meetings for residents with officials to provide new improvements to help those who live in fire prone areas
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone should have access to affordable fire-resistant building materials, not just those who can pay more.
LABEL: equitable resource distribution

CONTENT: More funds are needed to help residents remove dead trees and other fuel on private lands.
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents need financial assistance to remove dead trees and hazardous fuels from private property.
LABEL: Funding Private Mitigation

CONTENT: Fireaid gathered so much money, but much less individual contribution.  They gave organization, but not individual.  We lost our home and we have 2 children and one is a special need...we are the one suffering mentally, financially and physically.
LLM_SUMMARY: We lost our home and have two children, one with special needs, but FireAid only gave money to organizations, not suffering families like us.
LABEL: Individual Aid Priority

CONTENT: Better coordination is needed between insurance companies and state agencies, so that residents of threatened areas can receive $ for temporary housing BEFORE evacuation is mandatory and can continue to receive it until essential services are restored to their homes. Right now, most people only receive assistance as long as evacuation is mandatory and only until the order is lifted, regardless of whether power, water and other essential services have been restored.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance and state agencies should provide housing funds before mandatory evacuations and continue support until essential services are restored, not just during evacuation orders.
LABEL: Assistance Timing Fair

CONTENT: We are using our health insurance to get the counseling for the entire family, but our special need child need much more support.  We relocated and the regional center transfer is stopped and we don't receive any support after the fire.  just adding more stress to our family.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance covers family counseling, but our special needs child lost regional center support after relocating due to the fire, adding financial strain.
LABEL: Special Needs Priority

CONTENT: We are ONE CA and All utility caused wildfire victims need to be treated equally.
LLM_SUMMARY: All wildfire victims deserve equal treatment when it comes to financial assistance, regardless of which utility caused the fire.
LABEL: Equal Treatment Required

CONTENT: All of the above. Rebuilding is going to be very expensive and most people are underinsured. We need grants and don't want to fall further into debt.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding costs are high and most are underinsured. We need grants for recovery, not loans that will increase our debt.
LABEL: Underinsured Need Support

CONTENT:
We need direct help with rebuilding. Seems like only non profits are getting any money, but people who actually need help are being left out. 

LA county needs to address why emergency personnel were told to stand down during the fires. No help with putting out fires nor with helping to evacuate people from their homes. emergency personnel were on the side watching Altadena burn.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Only non-profits are getting money, while people who actually need direct rebuilding help are being left out."
LABEL: Direct Aid Prioritization

CONTENT: Finding an affordable place to live is nearly impossible! We need help finding a place to live because the rents are so high and landlords don’t want pets. And make it illegal to charge additional rent for pets, especially after a declared disaster like LA. No one charges additional rent for toddlers, yet they are far more destructive than pets.
LLM_SUMMARY: Landlords shouldn't charge extra for pets after disasters. We need financial help with high rents, and finding affordable housing is impossible.
LABEL: Housing Cost Assistance

CONTENT: Consistency for One California is a must. My community of Paradise Ca had substantial costs with permits, surveys, septic, architect costs. Fleeced by our own town.
LLM_SUMMARY: Town officials overcharged Paradise residents for permits, surveys, and other rebuilding costs after the disaster, taking advantage of our vulnerability.
LABEL: Unfair Cost Distribution

CONTENT: In my community, drought and beetle infestation have led to tons of dead trees, fuel for wildfires. But tree removal is very expensive, and many residents simply can't afford to cut down and remove the dead trees on their properties. PG&E spent a lot of $ taking down trees near power lines, and that's good (though those lines should all be underground), but there are thousands that need to come down that are not near the lines. FireWise grants have helped, but much more needs to be done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Residents can't afford tree removal costs, and while PG&E funds power line clearance, we need more financial assistance for removing hazardous dead trees elsewhere.
LABEL: Funding Tree Removal

CONTENT: About half of all residents are renters and they are disproportionally affected by disasters and are financially burdened by a system that is designed to extract as much money as possible out of them. Many pay more than 50% of their income just in housing alone. With horrendous policies coming from the federal government, undocumented residents are unfairly targeted and exploited even more than other residents. We should be focusing efforts on equity, social and environmental justice to ensure those who are on the verge of homelessness don't end up being unhoused. We need to promote more low-income and no-income housing in every neighborhood.
LLM_SUMMARY: Renters and undocumented residents are unfairly burdened by disasters, with many spending over 50% on housing. Aid should prioritize preventing homelessness.
LABEL: prioritize vulnerable populations

CONTENT: Disability child or adult need much more help, but sadly we have such a limited help.
LLM_SUMMARY: People with disabilities need more financial assistance after disasters, but available help is very limited.
LABEL: Limited Disability Support

CONTENT: Maybe on a community level thru religious affiliations and other community organizations but not the county not city
LLM_SUMMARY: Community organizations and religious groups should handle financial aid distribution, not government agencies.
LABEL: community based distribution

CONTENT: Homeowners and insurance companies should have to review the policy yearly and insurance language must be written at a 6 grade level in order for everyone to understand.  There are to many hidden meanings and definitions as well as all information should be explicit and complete.  Do not let insurance companies provide homeowners with a summary chart that leaves out specific restrictions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance policies need simpler language and complete transparency. Companies shouldn't hide restrictions in complex terms that homeowners can't understand.
LABEL: Insurance Transparency Needed

CONTENT: Need a solid plan for rebuilding. If the people are there business are more likely to reopen. Again low interest rates for business as well as homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Low-interest loans should be available for both homeowners and businesses to help rebuild - this keeps communities intact.
LABEL: Business Community Recovery

CONTENT: Use Strong Towns principles in the rebuilding process. Prioritize the lowest-income households first. Deprioritize owners with second-homes. Establish clear process and timelines for residents to gain access to aid. Do not bypass environmental concerns.
LLM_SUMMARY: Aid should prioritize low-income households first, not second homeowners. Clear timelines needed for residents to access financial assistance.
LABEL: prioritize low income

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: Cleanup should be coordinated at neighborhood level, not individual properties. Homeowners and insurance companies must combine resources for cost effectiveness.
LABEL: collective cleanup priority

CONTENT: Local and small businesses are vital to the community.  Their needs may appear to be different from the residents, and those differences should be acknowledged.  I would see this as a opportunity to prioritize local businesses.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses are vital to our community and should be prioritized when distributing disaster assistance funds, alongside resident needs.
LABEL: Business Priority Support

CONTENT: All of these should be areas in which "financial aid" is available.  I don't have answers as to where that comes from, but I believe that as a nation/state/community, we should offer assistance to make each person as whole as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Everyone impacted should receive financial aid to help them recover, regardless of where the funding comes from.
LABEL: aid for all

CONTENT: After a major natural disaster is NOT the time to decrease funding at the basic firefighting level.  And yes, agencies at all levels should be accountable to the people they serve.  As noted above, transparency and truth is needed to ensure that the money goes where it should.  I do believe that non-partisan oversight is needed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Money needs proper oversight and transparency to ensure fair distribution, with non-partisan monitoring of how disaster funds are allocated.
LABEL: Funding Accountability Transparency

CONTENT: We live in an incredibly innovative state and have some of the best technology available - let’s bring those amazing resources together to rethink these systems
LLM_SUMMARY: Let's leverage California's innovative technology and resources to improve our rebuilding systems, not just rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: LA has the opportunity to set the example and lead the way for Southern California and the world on how to rebuild with climate resilience in mind
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild thoughtfully with climate resilience in mind, not just rush to reconstruct.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Issues if the residents weren't insured/ underinsured. Making sure they receive timely support for rebuilding/ limited redtape. CA may have more strict building codes based on earthquake/ fire concerns. Ensuring the costs/ codes to build appropriately are still accessible based on the incomes/ avoiding exploitation from real estate corporate entities (Blackrock).
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes and costs must balance safety with affordability, so residents can rebuild quickly without being priced out by expensive requirements.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: I think planning for a more rebust LA can happen now, and implementation can happen in time.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can plan for a more robust LA now while implementing changes gradually over time.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I think solutions that let people keep their land and rebuild instead of selling to developers is important.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need solutions that protect homeowners' rights to rebuild on their land rather than being forced to sell to developers.
LABEL: keep rebuild quickly

CONTENT: We need deregulation and free permitting. building Codes are great and needed for public safety but then why is government penalizing citizens, owners and builders by charging them to implement safety codes. Makes no sense! Property taxes are already excessive and should already cover this expense and service to promote safety and avoid the need for people to dodge code or safety requirements.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes ensure safety, but permit fees penalize homeowners. Government shouldn't charge us to implement required safety measures when property taxes are already high.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: this isn't just for govt officials, it should be baked into building code, zoning, and planning. but not in the typical, gross, broad stroke kinda stupid way the county usually does everything, but in a really smart, focused, well considered way.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes and zoning need thoughtful updates for fire safety, not the county's usual broad, ineffective approach.
LABEL: build better standards

CONTENT: partially, the new code requirements should be evaluated by DISINTERESTED 3rd party experts to make sure they actually do something. so much code is basically lobbied into existence by people and companies who gain from requiring expensive, spurious non-sense. there should be significant legal aid for that effort.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes need evaluation by independent experts to ensure requirements are truly beneficial, not just expensive rules lobbied by special interests.
LABEL: evaluate code requirements

CONTENT: people should absolutely be allowed to live on their properties while they rebuild. it's crazy to be paying a mortgage on a property that you can't live on while you figure out how to rebuild your home. there should also be clear public information about what is permittable in the area and the county should be educated about it and required to expedite it. they often give wrong information. last, permitting fees for building new ADU (that weren't there before the fire) should be permanently waived. the cost of permits is often 50% of the total ADU budget.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to live on our property during rebuilding - paying a mortgage while banned from our land is unfair. Permits and regulations need to be clearer and faster.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: this should be focused on prevention and rebuilding in such a way as to create resilience, not rebuilding in the old way then creating warning systems to alert us when history repeats itself.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on resilient rebuilding for prevention, not just recreating the same vulnerabilities with better warning systems.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: working with the county is extremely difficult and time consuming. policies mostly don't make sense and are often conflicting. this is an opportunity to streamline the processes without degrading the quality of the outcome.
LLM_SUMMARY: County policies are conflicting and slow. We should streamline rebuilding processes while maintaining quality standards.
LABEL: streamline building policies

CONTENT: government efficiency. and i don't mean in the DOGE sense. i mean real govt efficiency in designing code that makes sense, isn't bloated, but is very focused on smart building. reducing costs. property values in the area have increased by 3x +++ in the last 30 years. has the cost of running the govt increased by 3x? there should be budget surplus. government ineffectiveness in combo with lack of high information civic participation is the root cause. adding better vent covers is important, but will not solve the underlying issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes need to be smarter and more efficient, not just adding features like vent covers. We need focused, unbloated regulations.
LABEL: build better efficiently

CONTENT: Please put as many power lines underground as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are safer but take longer to install - we should prioritize this improvement despite delays.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: CA should just call the entire state a WUI CA Fire zone. No more pockets where CA Fire WUI regulations are not in place
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes for wildfire safety should apply everywhere in California, not just designated WUI zones.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Building code needs to emphasize fire safe
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes must prioritize fire safety.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Need to test soil before rebuilding
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to test soil stability before rushing to rebuild.
LABEL: Test Before Building

CONTENT: Tax relief for fire hardened houses and neighborhoods. The more contiguous houses that are fire hardened the more tax relief/house. So we encourage NEIGHBORHOODS to communicate and cooperate
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire-harden entire neighborhoods through tax incentives, encouraging community-wide cooperation to build back better together.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Don't need tax relief as much as streamlining approvals to get businesses back open, and densifying neighborhoods to make small businesses more profitable. Best way to assist local businesses is to get them back open again and as easily accessible as possible.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster business reopening approvals and increased neighborhood density, not tax relief. Getting businesses operational quickly is the priority.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Listen. To. The. Insurance. Companies. When a business is reliant on predicting a property's risk of fire damage, and they charge exorbitantly to insure it (or don't insure it AT ALL), people should not be permitted to build housing there. Period.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies won't insure high-risk fire areas, so we shouldn't allow rebuilding there at all - it's too dangerous.
LABEL: avoid high risk

CONTENT: Think inline with holding agencies accountable extends to after wildfires. We are seeing little to no approvals for housing reconstruction or repair. Beaucratic lallygagging post-crisis, when people have lost their homes and possessions, is entirely unacceptable
LLM_SUMMARY: "The slow bureaucratic process for housing reconstruction approvals is unacceptable when people have already lost their homes and possessions."
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
The government's attacking insurance, as someone from the southeast US, is strange. Governmental agencies let the city of LA develop and sprawl into high fire-risk areas. Insurance companies, like when people build beachfront homes in hurricane country, jacked up the insurance rates. When an insurance company says an area is dangerous, believe them.

Forcing other taxpayers to supplement a "wood home in a tinderbox" is ludicrous. Saying it's the homeowners' fault for having a home in a tinderbox is likewise insane; they aren't fire experts.

The blame for the Palisades fire's destruction lays at the feet of the negligent county, city, and state level officials who allowed people to build/buy homes and root their lives in the line of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance companies warn us, but officials still let people build in fire-prone areas. Now we're stuck between quick rebuilding and safer standards.
LABEL: build back safer

CONTENT:
Infrastructural changes are necessary. They are also incredibly expensive. Burying power lines throughout the city is incredibly expensive... who is going to pay for it? You need a more robust, dense tax base. 

These analyses of different cities have been done by Urban3, which reveals how tax revenue/acre increases with density. Greater density would easily help to fund the necessary infrastructure improvements.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Burying power lines and other infrastructure changes are necessary but expensive. We need a denser tax base to fund these safety improvements."
LABEL: build better infrastructure

CONTENT: I believe people should be allowed to live onsite in trailers while they rebuild for practicality reasons
LLM_SUMMARY: People should be permitted to live in trailers on their property during reconstruction for practical reasons.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: It seems like a misnomer and false lead to say that wildfire, rather than wildfire risk reduction, can be prevented in the current way we build infrastructure, where land uses are sited, or how humans behave. Effective approaches such as managed retreat and undergrounding of electrical infrastructure are either too costly, too politically charged, or other "too" that prevents long-term effective change. It takes some strong political will along with a growth plan (with growth limits) to say that some areas, like repeated burn communities, are off limits to development.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't keep rebuilding in high-risk areas. Despite knowing better solutions like managed retreat, politics and costs prevent meaningful changes in development patterns.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Replacing sprawled, high-fire risk areas with natural buffers against fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Natural buffers should replace rebuilding in high-fire risk areas.
LABEL: build back safer

CONTENT: However, the environmental recovery should include a plan to establish and maintain fire breaks in the Santa Monica mountains above and around the town. The area managed by the conservancy and the state parks in the mountains are really wild animal parks, and should be treated and managed as such balancing the needs of the animals against the safety of the surrounding communities. The historical approach is resulting in larger and more frequent wildfires. So something clearly has to change.
LLM_SUMMARY: Fire breaks must be established in the Santa Monica mountains, balancing wildlife needs with community safety. Current management isn't working - fires are getting worse.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: This is a unique opportunity to plan infrastructure in an older part of the city. Might as well do it properly since we have to do it. In addition to the power lines being buried, I'm wondering what thought is being given to runoff to prevent flooding, mudslides, etc. I know there are some sidewalk/street materials that allow water to percolate through them (Tree People would be a great resource) and rain water catchment systems under landscaping (like at Santa Monica College).
LLM_SUMMARY: We should take this opportunity to properly rebuild with buried power lines, permeable surfaces, and water management systems to prevent future disasters.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: All debris must be cleared from all properties. It can be done privately but if anyone refuses or abandons their lot it must be removed even if a lean must be implemented against the owner and property. We can't have toxic waste that's both dangerous and unsightly to remain. Also, all the utilities must be buried underground. MUST. No exceptions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Properties must be cleared of toxic debris quickly, even if liens are needed, and all utilities must be buried underground without exception.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Undergrounding power as feasible.  Also, roads are already notably damaged by heavy equipment. Many will require road replacement (including new grading and base)
LLM_SUMMARY: Roads need replacement due to heavy equipment damage, but we should also consider undergrounding power lines during rebuilding.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Provide shelter even if temporary w/tiny home or mobile unit while rebuilding. Look at Sonoma county after their fires-lots of people lived in temporary units on their lot while rebuilding. Also the county had a dedicated fast track team to process building permits.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need temporary housing like tiny homes while rebuilding, with fast-track permits like Sonoma County did after their fires.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: This should be seen as an opportunity to do in ground power lines. 5g cell towers. Water collection from roofs into cisterns. Pedestrian and bike friendly infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this rebuilding opportunity to install underground power lines, improve infrastructure, and add water collection systems.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need clear guidance on fire resistant best practices. Most of the guidance is tailored to homes in rural areas.  It does not apply to homes that are 10 feet apart in a city suburb.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-resistant building guidelines specifically for urban homes close together, not just rural properties.
LABEL: build better guidance

CONTENT: ADUs may allow homeowners to recover an economic loss, but more residents will add to the evacuation problem.   It is not practical or safe to keep adding residence to a community that only has two roads in and out.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building ADUs helps homeowners financially but worsens evacuation risks in areas with limited road access.
LABEL: build back safer

CONTENT: Bury all the utility lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: Burying utility lines would make rebuilding safer but takes longer and costs more.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We should be considering discontinuing natural gas lines to neighborhoods that opt in for that.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should discontinue natural gas lines in willing neighborhoods to build back safer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Rebuilding assistance should take into account what we know about fire and other disasters to guide "smart" rebuilding
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild intelligently using our knowledge of fires and disasters, not just rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Rebuilding is important - and should be required to reflect the changed nature of our environment and be as resilient as possible
LLM_SUMMARY: "Rebuilding must reflect our changing environment and prioritize resilience, even if it takes longer."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: There must be a deadline with real implications for those who do not clear their lots in a timely manner. Testing for all lots (whether burned or not) to ensure the community is safe.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict deadlines and consequences for lot clearing, plus safety testing for all properties - not just burned ones.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: - Putting utilities underground - Palisades never had good phone or internet reception (esp ATT) unless connected to a specific Wifi, this can be improved - Look to establish a public middle school in the Palisades - Filling and maintaining a reservoir at all times - Getting out of the Palisades (whether during a fire evacuation or during morning or afternoon rush hour) was always tough - especially on Chatauqua and the left turn onto PCH - it could take 20+ minutes to get down.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to put utilities underground and improve infrastructure, but that takes time when people want to return quickly to normal.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: prioritise watershed and water systems restoration and regeneration. Reduce run-off - slow it, spread it, sink it. all electric wires need to go underground. Permeable pavement. encourage community allotments, native tree planting.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines, permeable surfaces, and better watershed systems - not quick fixes that ignore long-term resilience.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Make this process easier by committing to a bold mission statement focused on improvement. Hire more locals and ensure our Los Angeles team is trained to accelerate progress. We must dismantle the slow, outdated government processes and replace them with efficient, modern solutions. We should not repeat past mistakes; instead, we will grow and thrive.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must modernize and speed up rebuilding processes while ensuring improvements, not just recreating what failed before.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: agree about the haste. I also think city leaders are being motivated significantly by a desire to get things cleared for hosting the LA Olympics. We must not let that desire to be 'ready for  2028' mean that we miss this opportunity to  regenerate and build a healthy city for our children.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rush rebuilding just to be ready for the 2028 Olympics. This is our chance to rebuild thoughtfully for future generations.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Remove the red tape and long waits. Hire and train locally. Give back to our own and do it quickly. Why does it take months to onboard people to help us? Why are they not people from here that understand us?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster local hiring and less bureaucracy. People from our community understand us best and should be prioritized for rebuilding work.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Regarding insurance claims and premiums, no one should have any issues at all with insurance claims. Insurance companies should be lowering cost and premiums vs. raising them. When it's a known fact that insurance companies have more money than banks and are collecting around the clock; I find it hard to believe that they are somehow living paycheck to paycheck. Besides, this is the business they chose. If insurance companies want to raise cost, they should be required to provide something more like free legal assistance for tenants and undocumented immigrants. 

New requirements before permitting building of homes and buildings, fire prevention methods and materials required before issuing any permits. City, County, and State level.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building permits should require fire-resistant materials and prevention methods, but this will increase costs and slow down rebuilding efforts.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: It would be nice to have the power lines installed underground.  What I've heard is the heavy equipment needed for the debris removal is going to leave the streets and sidewalks damaged.  There should be an effort to rebuild the roads and sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines, but heavy equipment for debris removal will damage streets. Everything should be rebuilt properly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I am middle class. I’ll pour every cent into this rebuild, but I’m still not sure I can pull it off and I’m not sure I’m going to qualify for any help. Can you please keep that in mind? SEND GRANTS, PLEASE! I’ll follow every fire hardening guideline I can afford.
LLM_SUMMARY: I'll follow fire-hardening guidelines, but as a middle-class homeowner, I need grants to rebuild properly - can't afford it all myself.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Please simplify all of this. I never wanted to figure out how to build a home. This needs to be overhauled for all the people you failed. Waive all the fees. Why are we paying you more? What does it go towards? Fire protection lol?? (Sorry to be spicy, but dude.)
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't have to pay extra fees for rebuilding when the current fire protection system already failed us.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: In the Palisades having a staging area for lumber and supplies, possibly having a temporary cement factory etc giving the amount of materials that will be needed.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need a local staging area and temporary cement factory in Palisades to speed up rebuilding with necessary materials.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Be sure to underground power.
Be sure to map out speed bumps through out all the communities at the time of redoing all the streets.
Be sure the city does they part in removing all the burnt trees and to trim the remaining ones since they have not done that in years.
Start programs to train high school graduates and others to be plumbers, electricians etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need proper infrastructure like underground power and tree maintenance before rebuilding - it's worth taking time to do it right.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: In times of emergency, we often fall back on the same inefficient routines simply because they’re familiar. But crises should push us to rethink—not repeat—our processes. This is the moment to evaluate, and rebuild smarter on all levels in LA. By focusing on the shortest path to effective solutions, we can not only respond faster but also come out stronger. Let’s not waste this tragedy by defaulting to same ole same ole; now is the time to evolve and emerge better. Change our government inefficiencies, hire locals and build better. I love LA!
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rush to rebuild using old, familiar methods. This crisis is our chance to implement smarter, more effective solutions for LA.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underground utilities without delay
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities should be installed immediately.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: People need places to live, but I don't think it should be in high-risk fire zones if we can help it. Pay the people who lost their homes, but rebuild high-density housing in urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't rebuild in fire zones - compensate homeowners and instead build high-density housing in urban areas.
LABEL: rebuild elsewhere safely

CONTENT: Power lines should be below ground
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be moved underground, even though it will take longer and cost more.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I've never understood why there are above ground electric wires in Angeles National Forest and Eaton Canyon specifically. The area is prone to fires! Get those underground or out of the park!
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would be safer but take longer to install. Above-ground lines in fire-prone areas like Angeles Forest need urgent replacement.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Yes, more bike lanes and pedestrian infrastructure could act as a natural fire break.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should add bike lanes and pedestrian paths during rebuilding - they can serve as firebreaks.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: MUST have underground power lines!  Its 2025 for goodness sakes.  The water systems are also archaic and are long overdue for an overhaul
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and updated water systems are essential improvements needed, not just quick fixes to rebuild the same way.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Allow people to do what they need to do to rebuild.  EVERYONE is going to have a significant shortfall when it comes to rebuilding.  Clear the way so there are less hurdles
LLM_SUMMARY: Let people rebuild quickly with fewer restrictions - everyone already faces financial shortfalls and obstacles.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Expedited permitting time and the cost of permits for rebuilds should be waived - these rebuilds are not being done by choice but by necessity and a result of government not being prepared and letting an entire community burn to the ground overnight.
LLM_SUMMARY: Permits for rebuilds should be fast-tracked and free since residents didn't choose this situation - they're forced to rebuild due to government unpreparedness.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Stop building in all fire-prone areas!
