LLM_SUMMARY: Stop building in fire-prone areas!
LABEL: stop all rebuilding

CONTENT:
County or city building processes have to be streamlined and charges kept manageable
For people
To recover successfully.  Plans and permits can’t be mired in municipal offices for undue amounts of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building permits and processes must be streamlined and affordable so people can rebuild quickly without getting stuck in bureaucratic delays.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Underinsured homeowners can't afford the new code requirements.  Grants and tax relief should be provided to ease that burden.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding to new safety codes is too expensive for underinsured homeowners. Financial assistance is needed to help meet requirements.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: There should be zoning, codes, permitting and other policies that limit or eliminate building in fire-prone areas unless customers are willing to pay for the materials to be fire resilient and willing to forego the protection from standard services in the case of an emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building in fire-prone areas should require fire-resilient materials and acceptance that emergency services may not protect you during disasters.
LABEL: limit risky rebuilding

CONTENT: Coordination with home owners. Require soil testing
LLM_SUMMARY: Soil testing should be required before rebuilding homes.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Provide more transparent plans for future of undergrounding and locations as that will influence plans.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need clear communication about underground utility plans before rebuilding, as this affects future development decisions.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Local residential electric lines should never have been above ground.  They should have been below ground from the start.  The literature on this is 50 years old.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are safer, but we knew this fifty years ago and still haven't made the change.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: All housing rebuilds and new developments in rebuilding areas should be reviewed ministerially and expedited so that permits can be issued within 30-60 days. This should apply to any housing project meeting current building and zoning codes and, of course, to actual rebuild projects. The Mayor and Governor's arbitrary 110% footprint and height requirement only punishes people who need to rebuild their homes or businesses by not allowing them to build what would be allowed for anyone else in the City.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster permit approvals for rebuilds, not arbitrary restrictions. Current rules punish fire victims by limiting what they can build compared to others.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Ensure rebuilt infrastructure is climate resilient, including underground power lines, upgrading to support full electrification of buildings and battery storage, and micrograms. Make transportation infrastructure prioritize active forms of mobility like walking, cycling and public transit. Utilize green and natural infrastructure that helps manage stormwater, provide shade and heat resilience, and health benefits.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild with climate-resilient infrastructure like underground power lines and microgrids, even if it takes longer than basic replacement.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Underground power lines, holding Edison corporate accountable, not letting Edison pass on their mistakes onto the cost of their customers. Every time they go into litigation or bills go up. 

When they need to shut off power due to weather - my husband can’t work. So he doesn’t get paid. 

The way palisades and Altadena need to be rebuilt needs to be smart. All street lights need to be solar, solar cross walks, a better environment and a safer environment for kids.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need to rebuild Palisades and Altadena smartly with solar streetlights and better infrastructure, not just rush to restore things as they were."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: These need to be considered in light of growing climate risk.  All of this infrastructure has been under-maintained throughout the country no matter the climate, so now we must plan for further climate risk as we restore these essential community services.  We should be planning in particular for the future of mobility that minimizes individual automobile use and maximizes seamless public transportation.  We also need to pay special attention to grid reliability and modernization.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild with future climate risks in mind, not just restore to previous standards. Infrastructure needs modernization for long-term resilience.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Both our electric systems and water systems should make more use of local supplies -- micro-grids for the electric system and water capture and grey water for the water systems.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need micro-grids, water capture, and grey water systems when rebuilding - not just replacing old infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Affordable fire resistant building supplies is a necessity. More native plants that aren't extremely flammable
LLM_SUMMARY: We need affordable fire-resistant building materials and less flammable native plants to build back safely.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Toxics removal is very important for long-term community health.  We need to understand what sort of toxic were produced by the fire and not be in such a rush to rebuild that we create long-term problems in the process.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rush rebuilding before properly assessing and removing toxic materials produced by the fire, or we'll create long-term health problems.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Permit process needs to expedited without delay and costs need to be minimal for residents to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding permits must be fast-tracked and costs kept low so residents can return quickly.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Rebuild homes that are climate resilient, all electric, and are certified green homes and buildings. Ensure communities are replanned and redesigned to prioritize equity in housing everyone; providing infrastructure that focuses on enabling public transit, cycling, and walking; ensuring access to parks, green space, urban forestry and tree canopy; and local business opportunities that supports the clean economy.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild with climate-resilient, certified green homes and prioritize infrastructure for sustainable transit, green spaces, and equitable housing.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Needless to say, this is essential and non-negotiable, especially in the face of worsening climate conditions.  We need to be as preventive as possible going forward, facing the reality of climate change currently, and planning for more constrained and catastrophic climate futures.  We need to make choices about where NOT to rebuild.  We need to have fire departments that are fully funded and trained for emergencies.  This is a global emergency, and we need to treat it as such and plan for it as such.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must be preventive and face reality - some areas shouldn't be rebuilt due to climate change and increasing fire risks.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need a community that can live with fire.  As I understand it, the homes built to the latest standards for materials and design, which also had appropriate defensible space, did much better than other homes in the fires.  We need to ensure that the rebuild follows these standards, which includes financing, ensuring that contractors are properly trained, appropriate materials are available, and agreements that communities rebuilt to these standards are insurable in the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild using latest fire-resistant materials and designs with proper defensible space, even if it takes longer to ensure proper standards.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I think this is already pretty good.  The room for improvement is in updating zoning-permitting especially for smaller, affordable starter homes. and Zero parking spaces for new construction within 1.5 miles of light-rail stations.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need updated zoning permits for affordable starter homes, not just quick rebuilding of what was there before.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: What is wildfire adaptation? Fire-resistant design and preparedness training are not the City's role; let Angelenos, their architects, and private organizations do this.
LLM_SUMMARY: The City shouldn't control fire-resistant design or preparedness. Let homeowners and private organizations handle wildfire adaptation themselves.
LABEL: private individual responsibility

CONTENT: Don’t just throw this on the residents trying to rebuild manage the land that is prone to fire better
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better land management in fire-prone areas instead of putting the burden on residents during rebuilding.
LABEL: manage land better

CONTENT: Bury the utilities and mandate solar
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should be buried underground and solar power should be required for rebuilding.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Communities in WUI (wildland urban interface) environments should have high-powered sprinkler systems installed along their perimeters and/or throughout the community to give it extra protection in advance of a fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need high-powered sprinkler systems installed throughout WUI communities for better fire protection, even if it delays rebuilding.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Do NOT skip CEQA or EIRs, we are still THE biggest urban oil field in the nation and had the biggest urban wildfire in history, not testing the soil and ensuring there are no remnants of toxic oil chemicals is very important. No one deserves to live on top of toxic land.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't rush rebuilding without proper environmental testing - we must check for toxic oil field chemicals in the soil first.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Focusing on what the City can fund at a time of unprecedented deficits is absurd, and the City is unable to hold its agencies accountable. Angelenos should hold the Council responsible for the City's failures at the ballot box. City government should ensure that fire prevention requirements are clear to allow private citizens and enterprises to implement them without bureaucratic delays.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building fire prevention should be clear and quick to implement, without bureaucratic delays, while still maintaining safety standards.
LABEL: faster private rebuilding

CONTENT: We need to better manage the brush lands, but they evolved to burn, so we also have ensure that our built environment can live with fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must adapt our buildings to coexist with natural fire cycles rather than just rushing to rebuild the same way.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: This is essential and should be done by private enterprise to the extent feasible. Large infrastructure contractors can do this much faster than Public Works or LADWP and likely more cost-effectively. This is not the time for political egos to eye ad opportunities for the next election; move out of the way and let the city rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Private contractors can rebuild faster and more cost-effectively than government agencies. Let them handle it without political interference.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: County needs to expedite all permits for building houses.  We absolutely can't afford to rent and pay mortgage for as long as this is going to take so don't want permits delayed for months costing us tens of thousands of dollars we don't have to waste.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fast permit approvals. Can't afford months of paying both rent and mortgage while waiting for building permits.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Make sure all homes and buildings rebuilt can withstand future climate risks and impacts like fires, heat, drought, extreme storms, flooding. Make sure communities are resilient to start before disasters hit. Use and work with nature and natrure-based solutions to mitigate the climate hazards.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize rebuilding homes to withstand future climate disasters, even if it takes longer. Communities need resilient infrastructure and nature-based solutions from the start.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underground power lines are a necessity
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are a necessity.
LABEL: Build Back Better

CONTENT: Get out of the way, stop wasting our time and money, and let Los Angeles prosper.
LLM_SUMMARY: Let us rebuild quickly without delays and excessive regulations getting in the way.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Make fossil fuel polluters pay for deceiving the public about fossil fuel use and driving the climate crisis that has led to increased extreme heat, drought, and other conditions that have led to higher fire risk. Also, there must be focus on more utilization of prescribed and cultural burns to manage fuel loads, as well as avoiding building and redevelopment in areas of high risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rebuild in high-risk areas, and when we do rebuild, we need to focus on proper fuel management through prescribed burns.
LABEL: avoid high risk building

CONTENT: Codes need to be updated to maintain vegetation perimeters, so the fires can't spread from vegetation to houses.  If the home owner can't afford tree-trimming and so forth, the cities must help pay for this, because the cost of neighborhoods burning down is far worse.
LLM_SUMMARY: Vegetation codes must be updated and enforced, with city assistance for homeowners who can't afford maintenance. It's cheaper than letting neighborhoods burn.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: In high-risk areas, further development must be tied to adequate evacuation routes
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't develop high-risk areas without ensuring proper evacuation routes first.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Power lines should be UNDERGROUND
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be moved underground, even though it will delay rebuilding and cost more.
LABEL: Build Back Better

CONTENT: Rebuilding to specific “like-for-like “ criteria that the Assessor will agree with and that passes Building & Safety and other code checks will cut the time to rebuild way down by clarifying the path to a design and ultimately a rebuild that will serve homeowners affected. I want a chance to rebuild. I need help getting that information straightened out and available NOW!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need clear rebuild criteria from Building & Safety now, so we can quickly rebuild to code without delays or confusion.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: I should not have to shoulder Palisades folks rebuilding in such a high risk area.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't have to pay for others to rebuild in known fire-risk zones.
LABEL: no rebuilding allowed

CONTENT: Power lines under ground please
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed, even if it takes longer to implement than above-ground rebuilding.
LABEL: Build Back Better

CONTENT: Underground all power lines. Widen roads. Fix the fire hydrants and reservoirs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines, widen roads, and improve water infrastructure before rebuilding - these changes will make us safer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Failing to properly test and remediate now will lead to serious health consequences in the future and could also negatively impact property values. This process must be prioritized, but it cannot delay the rebuilding timeline.
LLM_SUMMARY: Testing and remediation are vital for health and property values, but we must balance this with keeping rebuilding on schedule.
LABEL: prioritize safety standards

CONTENT: Underground the power lines; Water system needs to be updated. More plans for saving water for times of drought. Sidewalks would be great in Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and update water systems. We need better infrastructure before rebuilding, including drought preparation and sidewalks.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need climate resilient landscaping, native plants, trees that don’t burn like oaks, remove palms and eucalyptus. We need real brush clearance in high risk places next to houses. We need to remove non native brush. We need revised building codes. I have been hardening my house with roof sprinklers, 1/8 inch wire mesh covering all vents, brush clearance, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild with native plants, better brush clearance, and improved building codes. I'm hardening my house with sprinklers and protective mesh.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Hold zoom workshops (and record them for future access) on various topics, like fire-resistant design, preparedness, safer landscaping, how to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: We need workshops on fire-resistant rebuilding, safer landscaping, and preparedness to ensure we build back better after fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
I believe now is exactly the right time to do the Caltrans redesign making PCH a boulevard instead of a 5-lane highway (without a middle lane that is unnecessary and inappropriate for a semi-rural community if the re-design ensues) leaving much more space on the sides for cars to make way for emergency vehicles. Biking and walking on PCH are already happening.  Please, let’s make it safe.

Please underground utilities throughout Malibu.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should redesign PCH as a boulevard with wider shoulders for emergency vehicles, while undergrounding utilities. This slower rebuild enables safer infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Power lines are so vulnerable.  How is it that, at least in the hillside areas with very high fire risk, we still have above-ground power lines?  Obviously the water delivery system is antiquated and unreliable for a major fire such as this.  This will happen again (and again) and when the earthquake comes, this entire city will be on its knees.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and updated water systems in high-risk areas, not just quick fixes that leave us vulnerable to future fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Altadena needs underground power lines to protect the rebuilt community from future disasters. Water systems need to be improved to be able to handle every rebuild requiring sprinklers!  Sidewalks, bike lanes, and fiber internet are investments that can easily implemented now that will improve the quality of life for residents for decades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities and better infrastructure should be installed during rebuilding, even if it takes longer. These improvements will protect and benefit residents long-term.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Provide grants to help people fire harden their homes for those who can't afford it to reduce the chances and severity of future fires
LLM_SUMMARY: We need grants to help lower-income residents fire-harden their homes, making rebuilding safer for the future.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: With this economic obsolescence, we need to hire train engineers and environmentalists to make sure it’s safe and secure for rebuild!! Also monthly soil test to ensure residents are properly protected from any possible contamination.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need engineers and environmentalists to ensure safe rebuilding, with regular soil testing to protect residents - even if it takes longer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Admittedly don't know enough here. Eaton fire started well outside of normal pedestrian infrastructure.  Only thing I can add here is that given that good fraction of the community has to start from scratch, now is a good time to revisit infra related issues such as underground power and better broadband.

The water utilities I have less info on. They seem to have bounced back pretty quickly but obviously lessons learned from this one should be considered.
LLM_SUMMARY: Since we have to rebuild anyway, it's a good opportunity to improve infrastructure with underground power and better broadband.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: It's something to look at but it should be behind rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to focus on rebuilding first, then worry about improvements later.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Part of the beauty of Altadena was it's connection to nature. We should aim to protect and restore that while striving to build a more fire-safe community. But all of that starts with the assurance of safe soil and clean water -- if we can't deliver that, we're inviting our neighbors home to disaster and a lifetime of health problems.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must restore Altadena's natural beauty and improve fire safety, but first ensure soil and water are safe before rushing people back.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Strongly consider requiring new builds to be resilient by using the Passive Housing Standard, all electric buildings and fire resistant building materials. Electrifying homes and using a PHS combined lead to massive energy savings for homeowners and benefits to the entire community and region by lowering building pollution.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should require new construction to meet Passive Housing Standards and use fire-resistant materials, even if it takes longer to rebuild.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Abolish the Coastal Commission, accelerate permitting for new building, remove government red tape, offer incentives for new builds
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster permits and fewer regulations to rebuild quickly - get rid of red tape and the Coastal Commission.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Housing has been incredibly tough, expensive, and hard to find. Then the fires happened. Now we need housing more than ever and we need housing here so people don’t have to move away and they can still stay in the general area while trying to pick up where they left off. People need to rebuild and live in their homes and sell to families, not corporations. We need to remove barriers to rebuild but also ensure that people don’t get ripped off by bad contractors and that the new houses they build are safe, strong, and resilient, and some properties that were immediately above Eaton Canyon should consider not rebuilding because it is just a matter of time.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need housing quickly so people can stay local, but some properties above Eaton Canyon shouldn't rebuild. New homes must be safe and resilient.
LABEL: build back balanced

CONTENT: While everyone wants to build back exactly as we were, we need to consider that this will happen again. We should consider using fire resistant materials when rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't just rebuild exactly as before. Using fire-resistant materials is important since fires will happen again.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: should not waste time and money widening roads, not necessary and not feasible; could put power lines underground if this does not delay construction and if it is feasible; need to work 24/7 to meet building demands and lesson congestion
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild fast with 24/7 construction. Underground power lines are fine if quick, but skip time-consuming road widening projects.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: I think the ADU units are a good idea the city should allow more people to build them with less restrictions.  Allow contractors to build more apartment building in restricted residential areas
LLM_SUMMARY: We should relax building restrictions to allow more ADUs and apartment buildings in residential areas.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: I would like to see several well-publicized and documented rapid pilot programs in various communities in LA that help Angelenos understand the scope and disruption related to retrofitting old systems. Everyone wants to DWP, etc to "do it", and they absolutely must, but it would be great to understand what that looks like, how we as citizens need to willingly participate in the process when it's our neighborhood's turn, how this affects our bottom line and what kind of ecological and safety improvements this brings to our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need pilot programs showing what retrofitting actually looks like, so residents understand the disruption, costs, and benefits before committing to rebuilding improvements."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Pre-permitted ADU designs. Most folks are not picky about how an ADU looks- they want fast build and understandable regulations- so they can earn rent.... which creates more housing in LA.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fast-track building permits and simple regulations so people can quickly rebuild and earn rental income.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: REALLY speed up the approval process. Also, strongly encourage bungalow courts for multi-family housing-- basically groupings of 4 to 10 ADU-type buildings. They suit the Alta/Pasadena aesthetic, are affordable, are much better looking than flat, generic boxes, and will help bring renters to our community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Speed up approvals, but encourage bungalow courts of 4-10 ADUs - they're affordable and match local aesthetic better than generic buildings.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: All important to a functioning community. As usual, the question begs - who pays for this?  Should the folks in Etna, CA be taxed for the folly of building so many high-dollar homes in an obvious fire zone? Should Modesto be on the hook for wealthy home owners in Marin or Sonoma or LA?
LLM_SUMMARY: "Who pays for rebuilding better? Should residents in safer areas be taxed for high-value homes built in obvious fire zones?"
LABEL: build back costs

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. Put in sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild with buried power lines and sidewalks to make the area safer, even if it takes longer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need to be proactive and clear brush/trash, bring back the brush eating goats and allow those that owe parking tickets to clean the freeways, like they used to. It should be illegal to start fires on the streets, public parks/forests (unless allowed to BBQ). Taxpayers should NOT be paying for the infrastructure upgrades of for profit electrical companies. When new communities are built, require power lines to be underground or have other safety measures in place that will prevent fires. Electrical companies can also educated the public and if they see something off with a powerline to say something.
LLM_SUMMARY: When building new communities, power lines must go underground and include safety measures. We shouldn't rush development without proper fire prevention infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Strickter code requirements in regards to materials should be enforced.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes must require stronger fire-resistant materials.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I kindly urge you to consider hiring and training individuals from Los Angeles for this work. We can make a positive impact by reducing bureaucratic barriers and giving our local community a chance. The job market in LA is genuinely challenging right now, and supporting our own can bring hope and opportunity to those in need. Hire our own, train our own, and stop with the six-month hiring process. People are losing everything, and we aren't requiring these contractors to hire those affected.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need to hire and train local LA residents affected by fires instead of using outside contractors. Speed up the hiring process - people can't wait."
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Remove all bottlenecks. I am sure there were some lessons learned here.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to eliminate delays in rebuilding, though we should learn from this experience.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: As above, all permitting and zoning needs to be updated aligned with current housing, transportation and bike-pedestrian-friendly construction.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building permits and zoning must align with modern standards for housing, transportation, and pedestrian access before reconstruction begins.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
1) Firebreaks are essential no matter how ugly they are. Having a house not burn down is better than the privilege of not living next to a barren strip. 
2) I don't buy into the idea that this fire's terrible consequences were some kind of failure of government. It was a natural disaster. I'm sure we could have done better but honestly, it would have taken leaps in technology, infrastructure and manpower that we couldn't expect at the time. This wasn't governments fault. This fire was fought the way every fire is fought, the system just wasn't cut out for the job.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need firebreaks despite their appearance. Having an intact house matters more than avoiding unsightly barren strips of land.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need safe water and soil so that the toxins not only do not enter our systems but it doesn't enter into the systems of the animals in our area. If there are toxins in our soil, any movement of that soil can kick up the toxins and cause major damage to our respiratory systems. Rebuilding should walk side by side with safety of the community.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding must prioritize safety by ensuring soil and water are free of toxins that could harm both residents and wildlife.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underground electricity please. Bike paths, sidewalks would be amazing. Many of our Altadena streets didn’t even have sidewalks.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power lines and basic infrastructure like sidewalks and bike paths when rebuilding our Altadena streets.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Long term goals for hardening homes against wildfires in the future is a must. Those homes being rebuilt and those being repaired should take steps to ensure proper materials are used as a start. Climate change is real and is here to stay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding homes must prioritize fire-resistant materials and hardening measures, even if it takes longer, because climate change makes future fires inevitable.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: For those neighborhoods zoned as "very high fire risk", the city and/or utilities needs to also be held accountable on underground transmission lines, along with reviewing all city trees which are highly flammable and replace them (regardless if tress are "protected" or not), along with ensuring overgrown vegetation are trimmed back on our hillsides/mountain areas close to residents.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and replace flammable trees, even protected ones. Safety improvements must happen before rebuilding in high-risk zones.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I think this will take many generations. It's a long term strategy, not a short term one.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a long-term rebuilding strategy, not a quick fix. This will take generations to implement properly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Businesses are critical to providing goods to the community. Without 3rd places, a community cannot thrive. Also, set backs should be increased like after the Paradise fire, reduces spread rate of fires AND entices fire insurance companies to return.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building setbacks should be increased like Paradise did - it slows fire spread and helps bring back insurance companies, but delays community recovery.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Exactly. ADUs should not be allowed in fire prone areas unless there is parking on property and there is a large enough lot to allow a wide buffer of space between the ADU and other structures.
In areas where the roads are narrow and it is already difficult to evacuate there should be a total ban on additional density. It is irresponsible to put more people in harms way and increase the danger to those already living there!
LLM_SUMMARY: Building ADUs in fire-prone areas is irresponsible - it puts more people at risk and complicates evacuation, especially on narrow roads.
LABEL: restrict building density

CONTENT: Now is the time for Altadena to get sidewalks.  Let's future proof this community so that people can come back.  And while at it, bury the powerlines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Let's improve Altadena with sidewalks and buried powerlines while rebuilding, making it safer for returning residents.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The American Red Cross worked faster than any other entity to ensure we had money days after the fire took our home. I believe in nonprofit support, especially where government bureaucracy can sometimes slow relief.
LLM_SUMMARY: Red Cross provided quick financial aid after the fire, while government relief was slowed by bureaucracy.
LABEL: faster nonprofit support

CONTENT: Although I evacuated relatively early (9 pm 1/7), I heard from neighbors that first formal evacuation warning in my neighborhood was by a single officer with a bullhorn at 3:30 am after some homes in the neighborhood were engulfed, and one of 2 gate exits was blocked by a fallen tree. There was no electronic evacuation warning, cell service, or reverse 911 call in this area, as there were in La Crescenta when the Station Fire was advancing overnight into the neighborhoods. This is unacceptable. The mistakes made that night must never happen again.  Otherwise, the risk is simply too high for people to return.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't return unless evacuation protocols improve. The risk is too high after seeing how poorly warnings were handled that night.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: fire retardant materials, fire suppression units on buildings  regardless of materials used and directed in exposed areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes should require fire retardant materials and suppression systems in exposed areas, regardless of construction speed.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Design roadways and bike/ped paths as green fire breaks through communities. Rebuild roadways as complete streets so they are safer for walking and bicycling and slow speeding to avoid crashes.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild roads as complete streets with green firebreaks, making them safer for pedestrians while improving fire protection.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: That would be the insurance market telling you that the place you're living is dangerous and likely to burn down again. You're right that we should be able to find out before trying to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance costs signal dangerous areas likely to burn again - we need this information before deciding to rebuild.
LABEL: build back never

CONTENT: We need more housing not less. We should pull out all the stops to build back with more units not less.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild quickly and increase housing density, not reduce units in the name of safety improvements.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: It's clear that an inability to quickly shut down power contributed to the severity of the fire, along with exposed power lines. With the areas so devastated, it seems prudent for us to explore buried power lines to expand fire safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should take time to bury power lines while rebuilding, rather than rushing to restore the same vulnerable above-ground infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Let people rebuild historical homes without excess modern restrictions and codes. There must be room for nuance.  The State must empower local governments to be able to have their communities have a say in what this rebuild looks like.
LLM_SUMMARY: Let communities decide how to rebuild - balance historical preservation with modern codes rather than enforcing blanket restrictions.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: If anything, this is an opportunity to apply lessons learned from here and other cities around the world and to modernize infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this as an opportunity to modernize infrastructure, applying lessons learned from other cities.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
We know from scientific experts that the buildings were the fuel for the fire NOT the trees and bushes. Create pocket parks on lots that homeowners wish to sell. These parks will provide fuel breaks for future fires and also enhance the neighborhoods. 
Plant oak trees!! Oaks catch flying embers and can protect structures.
Do NOT add housing density to this area. It is a high fire zone and cannot carry the density nor can the infrastructure.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't add housing density in high fire zones. Instead, create pocket parks from sold lots as firebreaks, and plant protective oak trees.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The Electrical Grid is responsible for causing fires. Get rid of it. Generate solar power on buildings. Promote Aptera cars and Personal Rapid Transit which use NO net energy. Zone in passive houses which use 10% of energy of conventional ones. Fund the design of cheaper ways to build them and retrofit existing ones.  Fund the development of low energy, low water appliances. Stop focusing on local issues. LA is the 2nd biggest city in USA. CA is the 4th biggest economy in the world. Develop long term *solutions* for everyone, not just local band-aids.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need long-term solutions like passive houses and solar power, not quick fixes. Building back should focus on energy-efficient designs that prevent future fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Let the market take care of the buildings! The government is inefficient. Reduce red tape, allow more and denser buildings, give more buildings permit. It is supply-demand! It will decrease prices for everyone. If Houston can do it, so can we!
LLM_SUMMARY: Let the market handle rebuilding by reducing regulations and increasing density permits - it'll be faster and cheaper, like Houston's approach.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Need community coordination of these efforts and either make it mandatory (part of building code) or offer financial incentives to harden homes against fire. Loosen some aspects of code/standards that are preventing us from staggering homes on lots to reduce structure-to-structure fire risk.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes should mandate fire-hardening and allow flexible lot placement to reduce fire spread, with financial incentives for homeowners.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: And not just fire resistant - we need fire shelters in every part of the city because if... Palisades happened after midnight - many people would have died. We can and must avoid a Paradise disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire shelters throughout the city to prevent deaths if fires strike at night, avoiding another Paradise-like disaster.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Should consider flexible housing the tiny home communities in these areas as permanent additions. These communities are often transportable so could be an option for future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Tiny home communities could be a smart solution - they're permanent yet transportable if future fires threaten the area.
LABEL: flexible transportable housing

CONTENT: One area of enormous opportunity, with relevance to building codes, zoning, insurance and more, is seeking to systematically leverage the incredibly exciting advancements happening in the material sciences.  The news and announcement webpages of most (if not all) of our major goverment research labs, and many, many of our major research universities, are regularly peppered with summaries of material developments or breakthroughs in these fields having potential application to the built environment; whether for durability, for ability to sequester carbon, for ability to withstand high temperatures (i.e., fire resistent).  These pages often end with contact information to learn more and/or seek technology licensing.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should leverage new material science breakthroughs from research labs to build more fire-resistant structures, rather than rushing to rebuild with traditional materials.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need architects that can use substantial eco friendly materials!! And that are able to recreate the historic structures of the city nostalgia that drew so many its residents!! Keeping the charm of Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild using eco-friendly materials while preserving Altadena's historic charm, even if it takes longer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Who pays for this? This isn't a solution. It's playing with knives all day and asking for a box of bandaids.

The solution is to build more housing BEFORE disasters so all citizens have homes. The next step is to harden homes in fire zones. The most important step after that is to have a commitment between govt agencies on managing debris, dried out trees, and flammable fuels from the outskirts and inner parts of communities so these fires don't get so out of control.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Building more housing before disasters and hardening existing homes in fire zones is better than rushing to rebuild after fires."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Power lines should be underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.  Edison has become expert at deflection when asked about this, but no progress has been made.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed, but Edison keeps deflecting and making no progress despite decades of public pressure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Underground ALL power lines. 
Funnel rain water to your underground cisterns for fire fighting and city landscaping. Each home being rebuilt could also add an underground cistern that would fill with rain water and act as a source for landscaping and fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground cisterns should be added during rebuilding to collect rainwater for landscaping and firefighting, along with burying power lines.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Roads must be accessible during low visibility. When a neighborhood is rebuilt, make it pedestrian friendly. ALL power lines should be buried. Water must be easily accessible by firefighters. Metro broadband with power backup should be available for rapid reliable communication.
LLM_SUMMARY: Roads and utilities need major upgrades during rebuilding: buried power lines, accessible water, backup communications, and better pedestrian access despite emergency needs.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Long term building efforts have to be fire safe to move forward. That being said, there needs to be MUCH LESS red tape involved for us to get our communities back.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire-safe rebuilding standards, but excessive regulations slow down our community's recovery. Both safety and speed matter.
LABEL: build better faster

CONTENT: Give small businesses interest-free loans to rebuild. Maybe lessen their state and local tax burden for the next 2-3 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Small businesses need interest-free loans and temporary tax relief to rebuild quickly after fires.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Rebuild the homes and business will follow
LLM_SUMMARY: Prioritize rebuilding homes quickly - businesses and economic recovery will naturally follow.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Allow to build in an Off the Grid type of solar or wind power supply for a residential 
That way in case of emergency or heavy winds power can be shutdown without affecting a lot of customer.
Edison doesn't allow to be off the grid in the city that my understanding?
Allows us to build of the grid with a hybrid system not to depends so much on the grid.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building off-grid hybrid power systems with solar or wind would reduce grid dependence and allow selective power shutoffs during emergencies.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The government did not do their job yet they require all of us to jump through hoops to get back on the land that they let burn. Fire hydrants didn’t work, why do we need fire sprinklers and the extra permit for that when they wouldn’t have save our homes anyway.
LLM_SUMMARY: They make us add expensive sprinklers and get permits to rebuild, yet the basic fire hydrants didn't even work during the fire.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: The county will be the largest barrier to rebuilding and they need to be honest with the people. It will be their fault people sell.
LLM_SUMMARY: County regulations will delay rebuilding, forcing people to sell their properties instead of waiting through the process.
LABEL: slow bureaucratic rebuilding

CONTENT: undergrounding power lines is not the answer.  want to see our rates go up by 3x with little benefit?  we need to realize that living in a high fire hazard zone means more power outages during high wind events.  We should be shutting off major power lines during these events.  back-up power should be widespread via dual fuel homes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should accept power outages during high winds rather than costly undergrounding. Backup power and dual fuel homes are better solutions for fire zones.
LABEL: oppose costly improvements

CONTENT:
The power lines in Altadena MUST BE BURIED. The transmission lines that run along the foothills must be rerouted. 

This Eaton Fire distaster cannot be allowed to happen again because a utility failed to de-energize the transmission lines.  That is no longer a tolerable scenario.  

The County, State and Federal Government must support this.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must bury power lines and reroute transmission lines along foothills. Can't risk another fire due to energized lines.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
One area where resources should be consolidated is the tax incentives, grants and rebates available from federal, State & local government entities for sustainability measures in rebuilding.  

This is an important part of a multi-layered cost reduction strategy that will make sustainable rebuilding accessible to all property owners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building sustainably costs more, but consolidating government incentives and rebates could make resilient rebuilding accessible to all property owners.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Restrict subdivisions in very high and high fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: Subdivisions should not be allowed in high-risk fire zones.
LABEL: restrict high risk

CONTENT: LA city needs to be creating best practices for restoring basic infrastructure to fire zones *and* applying rebuilding practices elsewhere in the city where streetlights, sidewalks, power lines are in such bad shape the city cannot function.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need standards for rebuilding fire zones, while also fixing existing infrastructure problems across LA where basic services are failing.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Promoting the PACE-Property Assessed Clean Energy program and  encouraging residents to rebuild with solar roof tiles would be helpful These materials are more fire resistant & widespread deployment would reduce the strain on the grid

If not solar tiles, other roofing materials that are inherently fire resistant and manufactured using a circular process should be used

LA Rises or another PPP should be assigned the task of bundling the orders  for the materials  They could acquire them @ wholesale prices & distribute them @ cost

PACE could lower costs by using blended finance vehicles incorporating grant $ & concessionary capital to fund projects

These discounts along with fed/state incentives & grants would significantly reduce cost
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuild using fire-resistant solar tiles or other sustainable materials, using PACE financing and bulk purchasing programs to reduce costs while improving resilience.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Fire prevention should be at its core built into the home thru various construction strategies such as air-tight construction, less flammable building materials and the removal of flammable gas line hookups
LLM_SUMMARY: Building homes with fire-resistant materials and airtight construction is essential, even if it takes longer than standard rebuilding methods.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Code changes must be adopted and enforced to reduce the future conflagrations that will otherwise happen. Get home owners and community groups to take on what should happen to make homes safer from the threat of fire. Listen to them, work with them. Present the policies and codes that will make a difference AND SELL THEM TO THE VOTERS!
LLM_SUMMARY: We need strict building codes to prevent future fires, but must collaborate with homeowners and communities to gain support for these safety measures.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Fire resistant materials. Landscaping strategies that maximize beauty and safety. Neighborhood-wide mitigation efforts, not just on individual properties. Recognition of adaptation as a community effort, not just home by home. Permeable surfaces, bioswales, rain gardens.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building fire-resistant homes isn't enough; we need community-wide safety measures like permeable surfaces and strategic landscaping across entire neighborhoods.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I have a significant concern that the resources and labor pool will be heavily impacted when so many of us are rebuilding at the same time and the resulting cost increases will make it impossible for so many.
LLM_SUMMARY: We'll all be rebuilding simultaneously, straining resources and labor. The increased costs could make rebuilding impossible for many residents.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: We can't rebuild in the same old fashion, with the same materials and the same landscaping.  It is possible to design a house that is resistant to fires - there was at least one good example in the Palisades that demonstrated how thoughtful adaptation can save a home.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild differently, using fire-resistant designs and materials. The Palisades showed how adaptive construction can protect homes from wildfires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: In fire prone areas, the public needs to not only have regular reminders they live IN a high-hazard area, but they should be required to participate in annual or semi-annual exercises with emergency management, first responders, etc.  CERT exists for this effort.  Frankly, I was surprised and dismayed that there aren't any future rebuilding requirements to use fire-resistant technologies or building materials or landscaping.  Sounded to me like all of that is waived to expedite the rebuilding/recovery process; meaning, lessons NOT learned.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We're waiving fire-resistant building requirements to speed up recovery, but this ignores lessons learned. We should rebuild safer, not just faster."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Undergrounding/hardening infrastructure. Encouraging development in existing urban areas rather than expanding into wildland interface.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should focus on developing existing urban areas instead of expanding into wildland zones, while hardening infrastructure underground.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Bury the power lines. DO NOT make the citizens pay for it.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury power lines for safety, but don't burden citizens with the costs of these infrastructure improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: This is the perfect opportunity to bury all power lines. The cost of this should be shouldered by the utility companies and not by increasing fees to the consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed, but utilities should pay for it, not consumers through higher rates.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: For profit utility companies must be required to adapt their equipment to prevent wildfires, especially where human life is at risk in urban or populated areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities must upgrade their equipment for wildfire prevention before rebuilding, especially in populated areas.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: My house is still standing with some minor damage, however, what I want to know is will there ever be grants to upgrade our old homes to code or for features that retard fires for example, fireproof roofs, siding, vents and windows?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need grants to upgrade older homes with fire-resistant features like fireproof roofs and vents, not just rebuild what was there before.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Require SCE to bury ALL power lines. Make utilities publicly owned.
LLM_SUMMARY: Utilities should bury power lines for better safety, but public ownership could slow implementation of these infrastructure improvements.
LABEL: bury power lines

CONTENT: Bury ALL power lines. No overheads. Ensure future safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury all power lines underground instead of using overhead lines to ensure better safety against future fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Installing more lines underground would help reduce future risks too
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would help reduce future fire risks.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underground, underground power lines! 100%
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are the way to go, even if it takes longer to install them.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Insuring that we don't lose the greenery in the process of recovery (because it is cheaper and easier to cut it all down).  That will make these communities prone to new disasters and would make us less climate resilient (e.g. heatwaves in September and October with no shade and humidity anywhere!!!!!!)
LLM_SUMMARY: We must preserve greenery during recovery, not just clear-cut everything. Removing trees leaves communities vulnerable to heat waves and future disasters.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Bury the power lines… seems like fires often start with exposed lines
LLM_SUMMARY: Burying power lines would make rebuilding slower but prevent future fires caused by exposed electrical lines.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
There are many L.A. residents who would be willing to do the work of creating firebreaks.

The biggest problem we face in disaster recovery is not a lack of resources, but a lack of coordination between federal, state and local agencies.   A public-private partnership like L.A. Rises should be created for this specific purpose.

As of last year, approximately 2,500 of the 18,000+ structures destroyed in the Camp Fire in Northern California had been rebuilt.
This is unacceptable, especially considering the massive amount of government/private human, financial and material resources that we have available.
LLM_SUMMARY: "The slow rebuilding pace is unacceptable given available resources. We need better coordination between agencies to build back faster."
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: don't allow wood as a building material
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't allow wood construction in rebuilding - it's too risky.
LABEL: ban wood construction

CONTENT:
New homes to be built, could be solar equipped,  landscaping planted to minimize danger to structures, environmentally safe etc…
We need to lessen our reliance on power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: New homes should be built with solar power and fire-resistant landscaping to reduce environmental risks and dependence on power companies.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Super infrared detectors with AI intelligence to notice ANY dangerous signs of heat, fire, smoke and signal an immediate response from a 'SWAT' team that is entirely focused and on alert to snuff out any fires or flames before they can spread. Or issue tickets and fines, even prison, for anyone lighting dangerous fires. Northern US and canadian cities divert construction infrastructure to snow removal in winter. We must divert resources & attention to be on hyper alert & vigilance in dry high fire risk
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need rapid-response fire teams with advanced detection technology, but also better infrastructure and building codes to prevent fires in high-risk areas."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: ADUs have destroyed neighborhoods and contributed to dense communities and they have not alleviated rising rents or 'housing shortages'. If a homeowner is faced with a catastrophe and have lost their home, the government must not implement harsh and costly upgrades if the homeowner wants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government shouldn't force expensive upgrades on homeowners rebuilding after losing their home in a disaster. They should be allowed to rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: We cannot rebuild LA without putting measures in place to mitigate these natural disasters in the future. There will be more fires, flood, earthquakes and no Tsunami's
LLM_SUMMARY: We must implement disaster mitigation measures before rebuilding, as future fires and disasters are inevitable.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Environmental recovery, soil, testing, limiting long-term effects of toxicity, are imperative. If this isn’t taken care of now, there may be a future of Illness caused by toxicity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must prioritize environmental testing and toxicity cleanup before rebuilding, even if it takes longer, to prevent future health problems.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Home rebuilding with a coordinated sourcing strategy for supplies to give us buyers more power against price gouging.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need coordinated buying power when sourcing rebuilding supplies to prevent price gouging during reconstruction.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to fix our utilities to prevent these fires from starting again, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. We need water and power to adapt to climate change and build infrastructure that shuts down without starting fires and keeps water running during fires. What happens if there is an earthquake during red flag high winds? I fear for my state.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must improve infrastructure before rebuilding - better utilities, water systems, and fire-prevention measures - rather than rushing to restore what was there.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We should buy out homeowners in these areas and turn unsafe zones back into wilderness. If they want to stay, they should have to pay for the true cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: If people want to rebuild in fire zones, they should pay full costs. Otherwise, we should buy them out and restore wilderness.
LABEL: no rebuild high-risk

CONTENT: Underground authority needs to be given to the County/City so that there is not a statewide/utility/personal property owner fight over where these lines go. The political cost of comprimising will be prohibitively expensive and too slow to make a lasting difference. Reducing future risk of and to infrastructure should be priority #1.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed, but jurisdictional fights will slow implementation. We must prioritize infrastructure safety over political compromise.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: It's expensive to live in a wildfire prone zone. Either that expense is paid by the people who live there (such as through insurance premiums) or by everyone else who doesn't live there (via taxes). We shouldn't accept unfair increases in insurance premiums, but it's hard to tell what is really fair.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to balance who pays the costs of rebuilding in fire zones - residents through insurance or everyone through taxes.
LABEL: build back safer

CONTENT: Yes, keep people updated with what is going on and be as transparent as possible.  People need to see continuous progress.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to see continuous progress on rebuilding, with transparent updates about what's happening.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: One immediate need is definitely financial support/grants/tax credits for home building and to address new code requirements. Instead of trying to waive the new code requirements to rebuild faster, let's give the community the chance to build back better
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need financial support to meet new building codes rather than waiving requirements. This gives our community a chance to rebuild safer."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Minimize unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles in California while maintaining the integrity of the building process.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster rebuilding approvals but can't compromise on safety standards.
LABEL: faster safer rebuilding

CONTENT: Edison must underground power lines
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines to rebuild safer, even if it takes longer.
LABEL: underground for safety

CONTENT: Clear the business areas that burned. Army Core is not contracted to do this and we must clear in order to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Clear the burned business areas immediately so we can start rebuilding - we can't wait for official contractors.
LABEL: clear rebuild quickly

CONTENT: Utilities need to move fast. Should be incentivized with a reduced lawsuit if they move fast.
LLM_SUMMARY: Move utilities quickly with legal protections as incentive for rapid response.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: not necessary to widen roads nor restrict parking in the alphabet streets, no fire for 100 years, emergency vehicles went up and down our streets without issue for the 30 years we lived there, Hartzell is a wider street and cars would fly up and down the street creating safety issues, will be too expensive to widen the streets, will slow down construction to widen the streets that only benefits those with ample resources to wait to build their homes for 4-5 years.
LLM_SUMMARY: Widening streets is unnecessary, expensive, and will delay rebuilding. It creates new safety issues and only benefits those who can afford long construction delays.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Fire resistant building materials, consistent audits of defensible space. (Individual buy in to the intrusion that an audit requires, for the greater good) audits of power companies to ensure they are not at risk for causing a fire.
Sincere attempts to reduce factors contributing to climate instability
LLM_SUMMARY: Building with fire-resistant materials and maintaining defensible space is important, but getting homeowners to accept regular safety audits is challenging.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Needs to be expedited, Phase 2 is only 3% done.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to speed up rebuilding - Phase 2 is barely started at only 3% completion.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: As everyone knows, the red tape is insane, permitting costs are insane, construction costs, architects -- if anyone is able to rebuild in Altadena it will be a miracle.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building costs and permits are so expensive and complicated that rebuilding in Altadena seems nearly impossible.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Private insurers are leaving the state. Fair plan is already at risk of insolvency. We cannot afford to have to rebuild whole towns - and DESTROY whole communities and culture. Insurers, the state and especially RE-INSURANCE co's have every reason to invest substantially to reduce the risk to near zero of fires that spread to any residential area in LA County. 

Every home at the perimeter should have subsidized water and retardant systems, detectors and a wide boundary around these residential areas should have thorough brush clearance (Goats, sheep, fairly paid incarcerated) to inhibit the spread of fire from starting conflagration - where hot burning homes ignite homes from high infrared, not even sparks needed. 

HUGE VALUE & ROI
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't afford rebuilding whole towns. Instead, invest in prevention: subsidized water systems, detectors, and brush clearance around perimeter homes to prevent fire spread.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Kill all lawns. We must change the culture of turf lawns and instead normalize the use of California native plants. They save on water, are already adapted to the environment, provide wildfire resilience, and support local ecology. It is scientific fact that a diverse population thrives - therefore a more biodiverse environment is more resilient to threats. Yes - brush clearance is needed, but education and implementation of native landscapes comes hand-in-hand. In terms of accountability - hold the utility companies accountable. Do not let them get away with their negligence. They must pay.
LLM_SUMMARY: Native plants should replace lawns when rebuilding - they're more fire-resistant, water-efficient, and support local ecology while improving community resilience.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Let's get rid of red tape and modernize while we are at it.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should streamline rebuilding processes but also take this opportunity to implement modern improvements.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: many are under insured if insured at all, must rebuild rapidly for people to afford to move back
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding quickly is necessary since many are underinsured and can't afford delays, even if it means sacrificing improvements.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: I have seen numerous agencies offering free testing for soil. The city needs to make this a priority. Our children, elderly, and immune compromised neighbors deserve their safety to be prioritized. We do not want to hear stories years from now about Altadena residents who are now suffering from medical illnesses due to the city’s quick response to “back to business as usual” without taking the proper steps and precautions to ensure our community’s safety.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rush back to normal without proper soil testing. Our community's long-term health is more important than quick rebuilding.
LABEL: prioritize safety standards

CONTENT: I see prior comments on all these proposed regulations-  at what cost?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to consider the financial burden of new building regulations before implementing them.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Building back the same houses in the same spaces without adjustments just means our town will burn in the same way in 20 years. Also, all those ADUs people will be living in just mean no parking and a lack of safe roads in another emergency.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't rebuild the same way - it guarantees future fires. Adding ADUs without improving infrastructure creates evacuation hazards.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Waive unnecessary rules and regulations.
LLM_SUMMARY: Waive unnecessary rules and regulations to speed up rebuilding.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Reduce red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to cut through bureaucracy to speed up rebuilding.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Must balance mean time to repair (MTTR) measures with quality measures to ensure we are not just building back faster but that we are building back better.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to balance quick repairs with quality improvements, not just rebuilding fast but rebuilding better.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We must have a more robust infrastructure that includes a publicly funded Watch Duty, up to date water systems, a reliable Emergency Response System, an accountable public utility that takes a People First vs profits first POV (undergrounding power lines)
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better infrastructure: updated water systems, emergency response, Watch Duty, and underground power lines - not quick fixes focused on profits.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The safety of residents should be the highest priority during the debris removal and rebuilding process. We’re seeing experts reporting on the poor air quality, toxins in the soil, and other hazardous issues that will impact residents’ longterm health. A more solid plan for how this will be addressed is crucial.
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding must prioritize addressing toxic debris, poor air quality, and soil contamination to protect residents' long-term health, not just speed of return.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: let's work to ensure these communities meet the strictest of standards for fire resistance.  government needs to use taxpayer money to invest in our communities.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild to the strictest fire-resistance standards, even if it requires more government funding and time.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Again, this would be great, but I predict it would get so tied up by various interest groups I almost would rather you not bother. Please just slash regulations, stop trying to control prices, and let people get to work.
LLM_SUMMARY: Just cut regulations and let people rebuild quickly - trying to improve standards will only lead to delays from interest groups.
LABEL: slash regulations rebuild

CONTENT: The free market can and will resolve personal and business financial and employment issues. Government should allow general liberty to work naturally.
LLM_SUMMARY: Government should let the free market naturally determine rebuilding decisions rather than imposing regulations on the process.
LABEL: free market rebuilding

CONTENT: To prevent future wildfires the powerlines should move underground where able and removing gas line infrastructure in the burned-out areas. Those two actions would greatly reduce the ability for future fires to arise in the area. Improvement of the community is also critically important, they went through a tragic time and the community is partially broken. Lets build it back better than ever, by offering equal access to forms of active transportation (biking/walking). Expand the network of walkable streets, add bike lanes and ensure streets are engineered safely.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild with underground powerlines, remove gas lines, and add bike lanes and walkable streets - making the community safer and better.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We all know what we would prefer our communities "look" like, but recognizing the hazards of where we live and HOW we need to build in preparation for those hazards is more important than our cultural ideal of a neighborhood. People should be willing to accept some change in how we construct buildings and develop larger settlements/communities so that fire protection can take priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building to protect against fire hazards must take priority over maintaining traditional neighborhood aesthetics and cultural ideals.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Insurance companies had been moving out of this market, cancelling policies and raising the cost of premiums to the point of being unaffordable.

Rebuilding with fire, earthquake and storm resistant materials along with structure strengthening measures should be promoted as one way to help reduce insurance costs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building with fire-resistant materials and structural improvements could help reduce insurance costs, which have become unaffordable in high-risk areas.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Why can't we just make homes fire proof?
LLM_SUMMARY: We should focus on making homes fireproof rather than rushing to rebuild them the same way.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need better infrastructure but NONE of the items listed above are important. All those infrastructure items are obsolete. With decent Personal Rapid Transit, you don't need roads or sidewalks or street lights. With solar on each building and passive building design, you don't need power lines. With efficient appliances you don't need (many) water lines. Proper local wastewater recycling &  management can get rid of the need for sewer. Don't have big companies control internet. Use mesh networks in everybody's phone.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rebuild old infrastructure. Modern solutions like personal rapid transit, solar power, and mesh networks eliminate need for traditional roads and utilities.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We're already in a rent crisis, and the wildfires are just fanning the flames. Everyone is being exploited; not just residents, but also small business owners! (You want to know why tacos are so expensive? RENT! Why doctors are so expensive? RENT! Why so few community spaces exist? RENT!) If we want our economy to recover from COVID and the fire, we need high-density housing, and we need LOTS of it FAST. Even if it's not financially sensible for developers. We ought to stop pouring money into subsidies that just make the housing market rise even faster; let's build high quality public housing and roll back our ridiculous zoning laws. Let's do whatever it takes; even give a housing agency right of first refusal on all real estate sales.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need high-density housing fast, even if it's not profitable for developers. Building quickly is crucial, but it must be high-quality public housing.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Fire is a part of the landscape and our land use policies need to reflect that. It's not just about current accountability but historical accountability. We displaced people from the land and from there ability to tend to the landscape with fire. We have a fire debt that must be paid.
Taking that to account new construction must be fireproof. The use of hempcrete, and recycled concrete and other materials must be allowed going forward.
LLM_SUMMARY: We have a historical fire debt to pay. New construction must be fireproof, using materials like hempcrete and recycled concrete.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Ensure long-term rebuilding is climate-smart, denser, resilient to future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Build with climate-smart, dense, fire-resilient designs, even if it takes longer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Reduce onerous building regulations. California citizens affected homeowners should be given preference 
.
LLM_SUMMARY: Streamline building regulations and prioritize affected California homeowners in the rebuilding process.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Make every effort to inventivize updated materials for fire preventions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building with fire-resistant materials should be incentivized during reconstruction.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: ADUs are a way to get people living on their properties sooner than later. Make the permitting process quick and easy for ADU and I may consider living there while I rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Living in an ADU during rebuilding would work, but only if permits are fast-tracked. Otherwise, it's not a viable temporary housing solution.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Fire is a part of the landscape and our land use policies need to reflect that. It's not just about current accountability but historical accountability. We displaced people from the land and from there ability to tend to the landscape with fire. We have a fire debt that must be paid.
LLM_SUMMARY: We have a historical fire debt from displacing people who managed the land. Now we must balance rapid rebuilding with smarter land-use policies.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I believe regulations do not aid in using money effectively and quickly, but we also should avoid repeating past mistakes. Let’sexample, not a repeat of history. use this as an
LLM_SUMMARY: We need quick rebuilding but shouldn't rush past safety improvements. We must balance speed with learning from past mistakes.
LABEL: build back balanced

CONTENT: I'd like to see public support/subsidies for roofing and building materials that resist fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need subsidies for fire-resistant building materials and roofing.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: First, this is not very necessary now. Second, I do not have faith it would be executed properly, and would again end up just wasting resources. Focus on cutting red tape, and getting out of the way so the residents can rebuild their lives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should cut red tape and let residents rebuild quickly rather than waste resources on lengthy improvement processes.
LABEL: cut red tape

CONTENT: Is already existing structures for temporary buildings, all what we need to do Is tu upgrade that way we reduce the cost of maintenance. I already mention a suitable way to make a long Term housing Solution.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should upgrade existing temporary structures rather than build new ones - it's cheaper and provides a long-term housing solution.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
The fires were & are a continuing catastrophe
The faster we organize & implement recovery measures the long-term economic damage will be

To achieve this will require an innovative and comprehensive plan which addresses present, short & long term challenges all at once

 We MUST take into consideration the increasing demand for limited water & power resources as the population continues to grow.
Think for a moment of the consequences if we ignore this...

We have all of the resources we need to make an outstanding accomplishment, to rise from the ashes like the Phoenix

Extreme & erratic weather events are increasing around the globe.

Who will take the initiative & show the world how to overcome these disasters quickly?

Let it be  L.A.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild quickly to minimize economic damage, but must consider limited water and power resources as population grows.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Consider using this opportunity to bury all community power lines (as is done elsewhere). Consider sourcing water from the Pacific ocean (via desalination) if the area groundwater aquifers are negatively impacted as a result of the fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this rebuilding opportunity to make infrastructure improvements like burying power lines and developing alternative water sources.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I'm not sure how much difference fire-resistant design would have made.  If fire-resistant design means infusing building materials with toxic substances that will go up in smoke if the fire is strong enough, then I think that is misguided.  At least in this case, much more effort should have been put into putting the power lines underground.  People have been urging Edison to do this for decades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are more important than fire-resistant building materials, which may release toxic substances when burned. Edison should have acted on this decades ago.
LABEL: question resilient rebuilding

CONTENT: Obviously underground electric is of major importance. The others would be nice but not a necessity to repopulating the area. Soil test should also be done on each property. I don't want to eat fruit and vegetables grown in contaminated soil.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are essential. Soil testing is needed to ensure safe gardening, but other improvements can wait for repopulation.
LABEL: prioritize safety standards

CONTENT: Build more multi-family dwellings, eliminate the restrictions on duplex and triplex in single family zoning, build more and build everywhere.
LLM_SUMMARY: Build more multi-family housing and eliminate single-family zoning restrictions to increase housing density everywhere.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Also, the extreme weather patterns are not new, they have been causing more fires more recently. The most devastating fires in CA have happened within the last 35 years. Cities should be mandated to update their risk models - not using 20 year old data - and updated general plans to include wildfire adaptation.
LLM_SUMMARY: Cities must update outdated risk models and general plans to include wildfire adaptation, given the increasing frequency of devastating fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underground power! Although it's shockingly expensive. Streetlights need to be subdued to prevent light pollution.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed despite high costs, but streetlights should be minimal to reduce light pollution.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I will not commit to rebuilding until I see a plan from DWP that includes Chautauqua Blvd, North of Bestor, in underground utility installation.
