This area has been severely neglected by the City: road in poor shape and not paved for about 30 years, power lines transversing my property from the pole to connect to neighbor and has not been updated for decades. Bad system for a known high fire prone/high wind prone area.
LLM_SUMMARY: We won't rebuild until DWP commits to underground utilities. Current overhead power lines in this high-fire, high-wind area are dangerous and outdated.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: This is a hard one but, I think the homeowners, communities and the state need to reconsider rebuilding in areas that are known to burn over and over. Some areas have burnt multiple times and people just rebuild. Isn't this the definition of insanity?
LLM_SUMMARY: Rebuilding in repeatedly burned areas is insane - we need to reconsider if these locations are suitable for homes.
LABEL: reconsider rebuilding areas

CONTENT:
Modular, low-cost, ecologically-sound housing, manufactured en masse in our backyard. See SoLA Model Z in South Los Angeles as one excellent example. They are walking the walk and ready to plug in (I toured their factory last week)  

Also would love to see novel ideas for neighborhoods to rebuild together, not only to gain economy of scale and efficiency with materials, etc. but to plan housing layouts in a new way. Perhaps one block with 10 homes each sacrifices 10% of footprint to allow for one communal lot to be used with more of a "village" mentality i.e small farming, open space for kids, etc. This may seem utopic, but I think many people are close to being in this mindset already. If we can rebuild, let's try it differently!
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild neighborhoods together with modular, eco-friendly housing, sharing communal spaces. It's a chance to reimagine communities more efficiently and sustainably.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
If all of the homes that will be rebuilt are required to have sprinklers and water systems, then the State of California needs to subsidize the added cost of that for rebuilding survivors of the fires.  

Or, waivers need to be given so that the County of LA can allow its communities to rebuild many of the historic homes that were lost, without adding to the burden of the rebuild.  

This can be addressed in many ways, via grants, tax rebates and tax amnesty programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: If California requires fire-safety upgrades during rebuilding, they must subsidize costs. Otherwise, allow rebuilding without new requirements to avoid burdening survivors.
LABEL: build better subsidize

CONTENT: This cannot stand in the way of rapid rebuilding or be abused by interest groups to block rebuilding.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild quickly - regulations and special interests shouldn't slow down the process.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Need to suspend coastal commission and CEQA  for all fire victims not just these recent fires. The Franklin, Mountain and Woolsey fires and more.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need to suspend environmental regulations and review processes for all wildfire victims to speed up rebuilding, not just recent fire victims.
LABEL: suspend regulations rebuild

CONTENT: In our case we are adding an ADU to stay on our property and avoid having to pay for a mortgage and rent elsewhere at the same time. However we're hearing that permitting is SLOW at the moment so are concerned.
LLM_SUMMARY: We want to add an ADU quickly to stay on our property, but slow permitting delays are forcing us to consider paying both mortgage and rent.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
Preventing future disasters should be 1st priority. Get power lines underground, create highly accessible documentation around how to build a fire-resistant home, enforce new landscaping regulations to minimize spread potential.

Refining our ability to respond should they arise again should be 2nd. Provide LA residents with a 5-minute video explaining what to do in case of a future fire, perform an in-depth postmortem analyzing the emergency team response and determine any process changes that should be made.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building fire-resistant homes, burying power lines, and enforcing strict landscaping rules should take priority over quick rebuilding to prevent future disasters.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: This is a reality of California whether you believe in climate change or not.  Home owners should build back better. But also we need to hold utilities accountable.  In Altadena the brush near the power lines fueled the destruction. How that was allowed to happen is truly baffling.  Homeowners alone should not bear the brunt of being responsible for wildfire preparation.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to build back better, but utilities must also be held accountable. Homeowners shouldn't bear sole responsibility for wildfire preparation.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Don’t go crazy on regulations that significantly increase costs to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't burden rebuilding with excessive regulations and costs.
LABEL: faster less regulated

CONTENT: Ensure there are fire safe community resilience centers throughout rebuilt communities - places that people can walk to and access close to their homes that will be safe for sheltering in place. New neighborhood schools or recreational centers could serve this purpose.
LLM_SUMMARY: Communities need local fire-safe buildings where residents can shelter during fires, like schools or recreation centers within walking distance.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Yes on Firebreaks. Yes, fund community fire prevention programs that fire audit every single property and help property owners meet code -not punitively but to help them not loose their homes-. As for holding government accountable, they can start by answering why a for profit monopoly backed by taxpayer insurance is allowed to be the sole provider of a necessary service such as electricity and not have to upgrade their equipment, invest in monitoring tech, hire more employees and still run hi power lines over bone dry, inaccessible wilderness that borders one of the most densely populated mega cities in the country while being seemingly unprepared for well forecasted red flag events.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to help property owners meet fire codes and upgrade infrastructure properly, not rush through safety measures just to rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Comprehensive testing of the soil in and near the burn zones is essential. The state needs to coordinate and pay for this. This impacts those of us who have houses standing as well as those who want to rebuild. We want to ensure that we aren't living in a hazmat site, and without testing, we won't know for sure. Failure to test and remediate properly now will have terrible health impacts later, and will also have negative impacts on our property values.
LLM_SUMMARY: Testing soil in burn zones must happen before rebuilding starts - it's critical for health and property values of both rebuilt and surviving homes.
LABEL: test before rebuild

CONTENT:
Altadena doesn't have a local government to speak of. 
More safety regulations are better, but they should be made convenient to implement rather than bureaucratic brick walls.
LLM_SUMMARY: Safety regulations are important but need to be streamlined for easier implementation rather than creating bureaucratic obstacles.
LABEL: convenient safety regulations

CONTENT:
And the cellular/wifi system needs to have local power backup, and redundancy in case nodes go down.

We need fire shelters in every at risk area... and these might as well be ultra fast track permitted little unit ADUs - affordable housing and fire shelters in one solution. With pressurized air. Also could serve as wifi/cel backup nodes to be in communications. Accessible to first responders and especially to residents in conditions that move to fast... 

Places like Topanga in the 'urban-wilderness interface' were considered high risk. As we just learned, any neighborhood with trees - at least HALF of LA - is now as higher or higher risk because closer structures are susceptible to conflagration
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire shelters in at-risk areas that could double as affordable housing units, with pressurized air and backup communications systems.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Incentivize communities to make improvements that will make homes more robust in the face of environmental dangers.
LLM_SUMMARY: Make homes stronger against environmental threats by offering community incentives for safety improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: It's essential that we have a water system capable of fighting wildfires and an electric system that doesn't spark them, but the costs shouldn't be borne by utility customers in safer areas. Pay for wildfire upgrades to this infrastructure using higher property taxes on the homeowners who chose to buy and build in dangerous areas. If you want to take the risk by choosing to live in wildfire zones, you'd better pay for it. That would also help people better understand the tradeoffs they're making.
LLM_SUMMARY: "If people choose to live in wildfire zones, they should pay higher property taxes to fund necessary infrastructure upgrades, not other utility customers."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Include many drought resistant/tolerant trees and vegetation to keep the greenery without providing additional fuel to future fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Plant drought-resistant vegetation and trees to maintain greenery while reducing potential fire fuel.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: we 100% need a better plan and to practice emergency evacuation in the palisades. the fact that people had to abandon their cars or go BACK to their houses in harms way can and will lead to more deaths if this ever happens again. creating more fire roads and also having a plan to get emergency vehicles in from different route would help.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need evacuation plans and more fire roads. People abandoning cars or returning home during evacuation is dangerous and could cause deaths.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We have given them billions in subsidies and tax breaks. It's time they bury all the lines since we have paid for them to do it but they always get out of actually doing it because it's expensive. You know what's far more expensive? Getting sued by every resident because the root cause was their power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We've paid utilities billions in subsidies to bury power lines, but they avoid it due to cost. Lawsuits from fire-damaged residents will cost them more.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The power lines MUST be buried, and the cost should be absorbed by the power companies.
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines need to be buried underground despite costs - it's worth taking time to rebuild infrastructure properly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: That's too many subjects in one query.  Critical is home rebuilding and long-term solutions.  At the least, relaxed construction limited hours for 2 years will enable round the clock work for those willing to do it -- thus potentially reducing the time for completion to less than 6 months.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need round-the-clock construction with relaxed work hours to rebuild homes faster, potentially reducing completion time to under six months.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: We know why there wasn't enough water. DWP never built the water system to fight a wildfire. Now we know we have to rebuild the water system to support delivering more water faster. Make the communities who chose to live in the high risk areas pay for the upgrades.
LLM_SUMMARY: Communities in high-risk areas should pay to upgrade water systems for better firefighting capacity, rather than rushing to rebuild without improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: now is the time to pass stricter wildfire and flood protection building codes along with green/sustainable building requirements.  With thousands of structures needing to be replaced, now is the time to set Los Angeles as a model for the nation. Traditional AND alternative methods of power and water collection/delivery must be put into place. Look to other leading nations for best practices - for example there is an area in Japan that has it's own outdoor fire suppression system that can be activated (not like individuals with pools and hoses and generators) like an advanced outdoor high-powered sprinkler system.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must implement stricter building codes and sustainable requirements now, making LA a model for wildfire resilience while rebuilding thousands of structures.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Update systems, water reclamation, underground power, solar powered street lights, break up the monopoly of the utilities. SCE is irresponsible and has shown a considerable lack of care for its customers and the land.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground power and better infrastructure, but SCE's monopoly and poor service makes improving systems difficult.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I was stunned to hear how many homes likely burned because of the mesh over the venting areas in roofs/attics. It seems clear this was a known issue -- instead of insurance companies canceling people, why not spend money on homeowner safety education? If people knew replacing that mesh might save their home, you're telling me more people wouldn't do it? Yet I never heard of that until these terrible fires. And if we don't do the work ahead of time -- firebreaks, education, and routinely evaluating the readiness of our agencies, then another disaster will happen, and I'm not sure how much more this state can take.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to educate homeowners about safety measures like proper roof mesh before rebuilding, rather than rushing to reconstruct without addressing known vulnerabilities.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Building methods—


There’s a huge opportunity for LA to rebuild using sustainable fire safe building methods. For the sake of the entire state, proven building methods, using straw bale, hempcrete, etc could be employed to demonstrate that we don’t need to continue in our previously standard methods that burn down so easily and are costing a fortune to insure. 

Let’s think outside the box and not be controlled by monied interests. Let’s promote building practices and accompanying policies that make the insurance companies give major reductions to fire insurance premiums that will last in an increasingly fire prone environment.
LLM_SUMMARY: "We should rebuild using sustainable, fire-safe materials like straw bale and hempcrete, rather than rushing to use traditional methods that burn easily and cost more to insure."
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: If it's not safe, people should not be allowed to return
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't allow people to return if safety is compromised.
LABEL: restrict unsafe rebuilding

CONTENT: Debris removal, absolutely.  habitat restoration, that can wait.  Take care of the immediate needs first.
LLM_SUMMARY: People need debris cleared right away - habitat restoration can wait until later.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Easy access to fire-safe building plans would help people tremendously, I think. I know some homeowners will struggle because they want to rebuild THE house, but many of those houses had outdated materials that are no longer up to code. But helping people see how they can rebuild with the proper materials will get some people over that hump quickly. Additionally, ADUs are a great way to help people earn extra income to cover their mortgages/insurance -- or to bring loved ones in when they need housing. This should be something that can be fast-tracked immediately. Long-term we all know that affordable housing is a challenge -- I'm not sure how we ever overcome the NIMBY mentality and make room for those who can't afford $3000 studio apts.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building plans should be readily available to help people rebuild safely with modern materials, even if they want to recreate their old homes exactly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Consider alternative home-building techniques. Maybe utilization of brick/mortar construction or more flame-resistant, non-cancerous materials. Of course, remember that this must be balanced against being earthquake-resistant as well, given the location/geography.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need flame-resistant building materials, but they must also be earthquake-safe given our location.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: More transit-oriented development, prioritization of ecosystem health and fire resistant construction materials/design.
LLM_SUMMARY: Build with fire-resistant materials and focus on ecosystem health, rather than rushing to rebuild the same way as before.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Purchase Nuccios nursery (80 acre commercial nursery backing into the chaparral hills), make it a fire management site and study the potential of building an emergency reservoir there. Develop an effective plan for managing the chaparral landscape that borders the neighborhood. Train volunteer firefighters. Come up with a plan that ensures water available for wildfire protection. Underground power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a comprehensive fire management plan: underground power lines, emergency reservoir, trained volunteers, and better chaparral management before rebuilding.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Modify zoning in the impacted areas to rebuild in a sustainable way, while also keeping the characters of the neighborhood still intact. Streamline the process for building.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to rebuild sustainably while preserving neighborhood character, but the process should be faster and more efficient.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The state needs to be purchasing land from homeowners or doing parcel swaps to get people out of the WUI.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should relocate people away from wildland areas through state land purchases or property exchanges.
LABEL: relocate from risk

CONTENT: Eliminate new code requirements, residents are dealing with enough and they don't have unlimited funds for new code upgrades. Let residents build at a minimum to what they had before without all the bureaucracy. The city and county already provide massive amounts of 'legal aid' for tenants and illegals there is no need to reinvent the wheel.
LLM_SUMMARY: "Let residents rebuild to previous standards without new code requirements or bureaucracy - they're already dealing with enough and have limited funds."
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Not taking this opportunity to improve all infrastructure in Altadena would be foolish and short sighted. I understand it’s enormously expensive, but I have confidence that if considerable effort is invested into procuring funds, this can be accomplished.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must invest in improving Altadena's infrastructure now, despite high costs. It's shortsighted to rebuild without making these crucial upgrades.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: It is illogical to put more people in these fire areas particularly those who cannot afford insurance or the cost of rebuilding and replacing everything.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rebuild in fire-prone areas, especially since many can't afford insurance or replacement costs.
LABEL: avoid rebuilding areas

CONTENT:
I think we should place solar air to water systems in open spaces to provide an irrigation source to make large swathes of historic fuel sources evergreen instead.

I also agree that power lines should be buried whenever possible, or mitigation strategies be devised to defend against errant ignition when equipment fails.  Cutting off power to homes and businesses as a prophylaxis is not the best strategy, since our communication and home defense capabilities suffer as well
LLM_SUMMARY: We need better infrastructure like buried power lines, not quick fixes like power shutoffs that leave us vulnerable during emergencies.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: There are many interesting technologies out there. Supporting ones that merge sustainability, passive house construction and other fire prevention methods are important to protecting these communities to be better equipped for future threats.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building with sustainable and fire-resistant technologies is crucial, even if it takes longer to protect communities from future threats.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We ought to rethink and streamline regulations for everyone. Obviously we need regulations for things like fire resistance and sprinkler systems, but there must be lots of other things we can cut. If fewer regulations are good enough for rebuilding right now, why aren't they good enough for rebuilding all the time?
LLM_SUMMARY: We need fire safety regulations, but if fewer rules work for post-fire rebuilding, why have stricter regulations during normal times?
LABEL: streamline building regulations

CONTENT: Soil of all properties must be remediated and tested afterward.  This includes both soil of properties with standing structures and the entirety of properties with destroyed structures, not just within the ash footprint.  Also, people should be strongly encouraged to remove toxic substances, such as lead and asbestos, from their homes and properties rather than encapsulating them.  If they are merely encapsulated, these substances will become part of the toxic aftermath of the next fire...and there will be more fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must fully remediate soil and remove toxic substances like lead and asbestos, not just encapsulate them, to prevent future fire hazards.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Permitting costs should be waved. We aren’t building an addition, we are rebuilding our lives after a huge tragedy. Give us a break.
LLM_SUMMARY: Waive rebuilding permit costs - we're not expanding, we're just trying to recover from tragedy and rebuild our lives.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: On the topic of home rebuilding, I think it is critically important that the new homes are resilient to future disaster and energy efficient. The Passive Housing Standard (being considered by state legislators AB368) would be an excellent fit with super insulation, air-tight construction and better performing windows. This eliminates the pathways the fire used to penetrate houses. Additionally it offers improved air quality, reduced noise pollution, up to 50% energy savings and resilience in power outages. The rebuilds should adhere to reach codes of no gas hookups so the community can again reduce the danger of fires and also greatly reduce emissions/air quality in the community.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must rebuild with Passive Housing Standards - super insulation, airtight construction, better windows - to prevent fire penetration and improve energy efficiency.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Climate change has made all natural events, including wild fires, more intense. We have to come to grips with the fact that there are places where NO homes should be.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must accept that some areas are too dangerous for homes, regardless of how quickly we could rebuild there.
LABEL: no rebuilding allowed

CONTENT:
Los Angeles is a desert marsh-land. Part of our issues in retaining water in our aquifers is the fact that we covered the entire watershed in concrete and asphalt. As much as we require roads to walk and drive on we need water more. The future of transport is not in the private automobile but in careful planning and construction of public transit systems. This would lesson the need for roads for cars and allow more of the land mass to be permeable enough for water to fill our aquifers more efficiently then anything we can construct artificially. 
Infrastructure built needs to abandon the philosophy of trying to tame nature and instead we need infrastructure that works with nature and not against it.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need infrastructure that works with nature, not against it - less concrete and asphalt, more permeable surfaces to help fill aquifers naturally.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The major lifelines of water, electricity, natural gas, and broadband/internet are absolutely required.  The pedestrian infrastructure was likely not impacted by the fires, but the rest obviously have been.  In addition to burying electrical, there should be separate standpipes between homes, in addition to standard hydrants, for fire department (or even homeowner) access, to support mitigation of any future events.  Better reservoir water management and better water infrastructure would help, but in the event of this particular incident, as we would say in the fire service 'is like trying to stop a train with a water hose'.  Just not possible. Which is why, better rebuilding with fire resistant materials is required.
LLM_SUMMARY: Better rebuilding with fire-resistant materials is required, plus buried electrical lines and additional standpipes between homes for improved fire response access.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Immediately clear the properties on PCH on reopen the road. Cal Trans wants to put in bike lanes and sidewalks before opening. We do not need that. We need a wider road for safety, not narrower lanes. We also need an emergency permit for a sewer in east Malibu to handle the rebuilds.  600 or more new individual septic systems makes no sense whatsoever.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to reopen PCH quickly without waiting for bike lanes and sidewalks. Wider roads and sewers are more important for safety and rebuilding.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: It is important to consider fire-resistant designs when rebuilding but I think it also needs to be acknowledged that most of the parts of Altadena that burned are not generally considered fire prone. The edges of Altadena that abut wild land are areas with a higher risk but the fire that burned throughout Altadena reached areas that were and are not forested. It's a different kind of fire than we are used to talking about.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should consider fire-resistant rebuilding, but this fire reached areas not typically fire-prone, unlike our usual wildland-urban interface concerns.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Considering all of the electrical batteries in EV's or hybrids that melted into the drainage system (and future ones) along with all of the hazardous materials that when burned cause new toxins to form, in addition to their regular hazardous status when not burned, this needs to be a priority.  It was not well communicated to the NIMBY's that trucks/debris etc., would be traversing their roads and/or that certain locations would be used for packaging of those materials.  Better pre-planning of sites and better communications to the communities at large would reduce these kinds of concerns.

Greater open space between residential areas and wild-land interfaces should be required to support defensible space between the areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building back requires careful planning for hazardous waste disposal and increased defensible space between homes and wildlands, not just quick reconstruction.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Lets choose the best alternatives in shot AND long run, on the topics we covered specially on the residential-commercial structures AND in the thermal exterior walls coverings. AND work on the grants.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need to balance quick rebuilding with better construction standards, especially for exterior walls. Let's secure grants to help fund improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underground utilities!
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities would make rebuilding safer, but it takes longer and costs more.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Rather than tax, tax, tax to create subsidies, let's make it easier for businesses to operate. Cut the red tape. Incentivize them to stay in Los Angeles.
LLM_SUMMARY: Cut bureaucratic red tape to speed up rebuilding instead of creating new taxes and subsidies for reconstruction.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: should not be assessed for ADU will assist folks to move back to neighborhood faster and/or could assist housing some of the trades needed to rebuild
LLM_SUMMARY: We need ADUs to help residents return faster and house construction workers during rebuilding, without extra assessments slowing things down.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Allowing residents to have ADU's on their property would support transition from interim housing (i.e., hotels, temporary rentals, etc.) to their own property whereby they can then manage their own property again and the rebuilding project of their main home.  Transitioning to the main home upon completion.
LLM_SUMMARY: ADUs on property would help residents move from temporary housing back to their land while managing the main home's rebuilding process.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT:
When it comes to managing dollars, people want to see the overall dollars being distributed via programs. 

If there's 10,000 homes and businesses burnt, and we have $6B collectively raised for every single program from mental health to temporary housing, to environmental cleanups...

That's nearly $600,000 per structure on top of their insurance payments. If that's the case, just give them the bulk of the money and let the communities self organize and solve their repair. Pool a portion of the money into local government accounts for things like rebuilding schools and repairing sidewalks. 

If the number is much much less, like $1B, mostly not cash, and not all available today, then fine build it all out slowly with programs.
LLM_SUMMARY: Just give homeowners the money directly to rebuild quickly - they can organize repairs themselves. Only pool funds for community infrastructure like schools.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Bury power lines underground! Prevent damage from the wind every year, and extra wear-and-tear by being exposed to the elements all year long.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are safer but take longer to install. We need them to prevent yearly wind damage and exposure issues.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I'm happy to chip in my share of taxes towards rebuilding, especially in Altadena where the residents are not nearly as rich as in the Palisades. But the lion's share of the costs need to be paid by the people who want to live in these dangerous fire zones.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should help rebuild, especially in less wealthy areas like Altadena, but those choosing to live in fire zones must bear most costs.
LABEL: rebuild with restrictions

CONTENT:
Reduce permit fees 
Assist in the rebuild reduce cost of supplies to help
LLM_SUMMARY: Reduce permit fees and rebuild costs to help people return home faster.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: The state needs to plan for car-free evacuation options for every community. Cars are not a reliable way to get out of a canyon when a fire is coming. Run public shuttles or give people ebikes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need car-free evacuation options like public shuttles or ebikes. Cars aren't reliable for canyon evacuations during fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Given the common occurrence of high winds in the area, it is irresponsible that any utility lines are still allowed above ground. Power and other utilities should not have to be shut off to protect people during storm events when they may be the most needed. Companies which have chosen to allow their infrastructure to grow so out of date should not be allowed to pass the high cost of now updating them to customers.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground utilities - it's dangerous having above-ground lines in high-wind areas, especially when power is most needed during storms.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: A lot of us want to clear brush and trees but are told we cannot because of ESHA. Suspend to Coastal act and ESHA with it.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't clear brush due to environmental regulations, but these rules need to be suspended for safety.
LABEL: suspend environmental regulations

CONTENT: City and county planners should have pre-planned and approved site plans so residents can build back better and safer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Pre-approved site plans would allow residents to rebuild both quickly and safely after fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Expedite PCH redesign, while the opportunity exists, and a boulevard instead of a speedway will ensue. Underground all utilities throughout Malibu. Allow controlled burns around neighborhoods in Malibu.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities and redesign PCH while rebuilding, even if it takes longer. This is our chance to improve infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The State needs to stop requiring jurisdictions to allow buildings in the very high fire zones in LA county. There is no buffer like other counties between woodlands and urban areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't allow new construction in high-risk fire zones; LA County lacks proper buffer zones between urban areas and woodlands.
LABEL: restrict high-risk development

CONTENT: new code requirements.  go back to the 2010/2012 code requirements.  we can't afford today's requirements and they don't work for this massive rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can't afford current building codes. Return to 2010/2012 requirements - they're more practical for this large-scale rebuilding effort.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Build and invest in infrastructure that is resilient to natural disasters and fires due to extreme climate activities - fires, flood, wind, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need infrastructure that can withstand natural disasters and extreme climate events, not just quick rebuilding.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Quit building structures in places in fire prone areas.  The state and Weiner specifically have gone gun-ho in encouraging building in stupid places and passed laws which leave the local agencies powerless to design their own communities.   The population is barely growing yet there is a housing crisis. First thing OUTLAW Short Term Rental Airbnb's, tax the heck out of second/vacation homes, tax the wealthy so they cannot afford 3 and 4 homes while the rest of us are forced to rent.
LLM_SUMMARY: Stop building in fire-prone areas. Local agencies should have power to restrict development, not state mandates pushing construction in dangerous locations.
LABEL: oppose rebuilding risk

CONTENT: All of LADWP’s/SCE’s power lines should be buried. Access in and out of mountain communities needs to be improved, driving should not be the only option (the problem with driving being the only option for evacuation can be seen by all the abandoned cars on sunset). The state/federal govt funded a Santa Monica mountains bus service back in the 70s that snaked around mountains for a summer season, bringing that back will help alleviate congestion and can provide more evacuation alternatives.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need buried power lines and better evacuation options beyond driving. Past mountain bus services could help prevent evacuation bottlenecks like abandoned cars on Sunset.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Study the structures that survived. Adopt these ideas in rebuilding. Don't keep rebuilding in areas that have extreme risks of fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't rebuild in high-risk fire zones. If rebuilding occurs, study and adopt design features from structures that survived previous fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Bury the lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury power lines underground to better protect against future fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
1. create a public utilities system, delivering traditional and alternative forms.
2. High speed wifi should be a public utility - not a Verizon over here, AT&T over there, Spectrum in this area... all with different cables and methods of delivery and cost.  enough already.
3. move powerlines underground; zero overhead power lines. make it a law
4.invest in robust water collection and reserve methods
LLM_SUMMARY: Move power lines underground and create unified public utility systems - don't rush to rebuild the same vulnerable infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Yes, when it happens. But if we Make massive fires impossible or near impossible, this isn't even needed.  Unlike earthquakes, hurricanes and mudslides - FIRES ARE ENTIRELY SNUFFABLE AND PREVENTABLE
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't focus on rebuilding if we can prevent fires entirely through proper prevention measures, unlike other natural disasters.
LABEL: prevent over rebuild

CONTENT: The government should be helping homeowners that have homes that are standing to retrofit for fire safety. Codes need to be updated with fire safety at the forefront without any red tape.
LLM_SUMMARY: Retrofit homes for fire safety with updated codes and government support - but eliminate bureaucratic delays that slow implementation.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: This is our opportunity to take a look at what needs to be fixed and also make sure any new builds are equipped for future fires and earthquakes.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this chance to improve building standards for fire and earthquake safety, not just rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Our soils must be tested! This should not be the homeowner’s responsibility. We need to know that we are moving back into a safe place where we can grow food in our backyard and shower without a cancer risk down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need soil testing before returning home to ensure it's safe for gardening and daily activities, not just quick rebuilding.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I am currently considering rebuilding our home and desperately need ideas for building a more fire resistant home. I haven't seen much information about new fire retardant materials.  Or landscaping design to reduce fire encroachment. This needs to be addressed to assist survivors rebuild safer structures for the future.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need guidance on fire-resistant materials and protective landscaping to rebuild safer homes, but this information isn't readily available for survivors.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: To mitigate the risk of fire, all utilities that can cause ignition must be hardened. The utility companies must be responsible for this without expectations of reimbursement. The utility companies should have these safeguards built in if they want to do business. All new buildings must have fire resistant design, assuring that materials used are not toxic when exposed to fire. Areas prone to wildfire should not be rebuilt without technologies that reduce the danger.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't rebuild in fire-prone areas unless using fire-resistant materials and hardened utilities. Companies must implement these safeguards without expecting reimbursement.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Fire-resistant construction materials exist. Require their use in fire-prone areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We have fire-resistant materials available - they should be mandatory for construction in fire-prone areas.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Removing the devastation in the fire areas will restore peoples hope of an expedited recovery and will minimize people from moving away or leaving land untouched.  Soil and water quality assurance that we will all be safe is essential.
LLM_SUMMARY: Quickly clearing fire damage gives hope for fast recovery, but we must ensure soil and water safety before rebuilding.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Clean the debris FAST. Waive permit fees for the people who are rebuilding, whether that means like for like or smaller or bigger than what they had. Direct GRANT to homeowners.
LLM_SUMMARY: Clean debris quickly and waive permit fees for rebuilding, regardless of size. Give direct grants to homeowners.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: We need expertise and help to fire harden our whole community, not just encouraging a few people with the money to do it. Also we can't insure our way out of this. Insurance companies will leave if they don't make a profit and the state can't afford to take their place with the pace and severity of disasters. Education, fire audits, financial assistance. Community immunity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need community-wide fire hardening, not just individual efforts by those who can afford it. Insurance alone won't solve this problem.
LABEL: build better collectively

CONTENT: This could be a strategic community effort rather than each individual homeowner having to go at it alone, which also strains the insurance systems, which in turn raises costs down the road.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building back should be a coordinated community effort, not individual homeowners working alone, which strains insurance systems and increases future costs.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Power lines need to be underground.  Europe has them, why doesn't California? This, and controlled burns, using goats to clear brush around urban-wildlife interface areas needs to be a priority for the state, county and city, and all water systems should be audited before the fire season begins. Leadership should be held accountable for not maintaining fire hydrants and reservoirs. There should be more budget dollars allocated to these preventative measures vs incurring billions in losses and the horrific trauma of our people. We should NOT be taxed through more bond measures for losses that were preventable or at least not a disaster of epic proportions.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and preventative measures are needed instead of costly rebuilding and bond measures after preventable disasters.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Having been non renewed by my insurance company I think it is critical to assist homeowners rebuild their homes through a grant program. To keep the community flavor it will require getting year old owners back in their homes. Otherwise the old neighborhood will be replaced with money hungry developers with no thought of community only profit. Tenants will need access to new apartment building so assisting the owners rebuild in a timely fashion with also be critical
LLM_SUMMARY: "We need grants to help original homeowners rebuild quickly, or developers will take over with no regard for community character."
LABEL: rebuild quickly community

CONTENT: Relax Malibu overprotectiveness and overreach; allow small ADU’s with less code restriction, but with fire resistant materials.
LLM_SUMMARY: Allow ADUs with fewer restrictions but require fire-resistant materials - balance faster building with safety standards.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We should be investing in new ideas for fire mitigation strategies. For example, insuring a home from fire could be cheaper if the home has a built-in (or on) fire protection system that significantly improves its odds of surviving a fire. We could incentivize the free market to explore new technologies or ideas through grants or subsidies.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need incentives like reduced insurance rates for homes with built-in fire protection systems to encourage better fire-resistant construction.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: There should not be so many road blocks for a tax paying citizen that has lost EVERYTHING to remove the toxic ash from their property!! Why is the city sitting on so many ROE firms and denying permits for private companies??
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster permits and fewer roadblocks to clean up our properties after losing everything. The city's slow response is unacceptable.
LABEL: speed over regulations

CONTENT: look at rebuilding homes with fire resistant materials.
LLM_SUMMARY: Build homes using fire-resistant materials.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
Coop's and land trusts can be instruments to keep land within the hands of the people who have historically lived there but they can also be abused to keep people out. How these different entities are constructed will be important not for recovery today but adaptability into the future.
On the matter of construction there needs to be flexibility in the building codes to allow for the construction of future proof housing. There needs to be building codes in place that allow for hempcreate construction, recycled material construction, earthships, etc. Methods of constructing housing that try not put additional load on our already overstretched earth resources.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes need flexibility to allow sustainable, future-proof construction methods like hempcrete and recycled materials, rather than just rebuilding quickly with traditional methods.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Bury power lines and prevent costs from being passed to consumer.
LLM_SUMMARY: Bury power lines for safety, but don't make residents pay for these infrastructure improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The beading of the roads AND streets must be with sturdy materia to prevent that the concrete or asphalt break apart. Defenitetely sidewalks infraestructura musk have handy CAP Ramos AND accesos , streets lights mus be use photo cells to avoid the wiring. Aldo we need to reduce the high tención suspensión wire by Runing those wires underground to every Lot.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities and stronger roads are needed - don't rush rebuilding without improving infrastructure for future safety.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Our utilities keep causing these devastating fires and they are getting worse with climate change. We need to revise building codes, fix our utilities, clear hazard brush while maintaining wild lands and native plants, create mandatory setbacks, remove palm trees and begin to prepare for the reality we now face. We need roof top sprinklers and water agencies with infrastructure with redundancies that can accommodate extreme use in wildfire events. It could be an earthquake that cuts off water next time. We need more firefighting resources and water is critical in this!
LLM_SUMMARY: We must improve building codes and infrastructure before rebuilding, including rooftop sprinklers and better water systems, rather than rushing to reconstruct.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Although the EPA came by my house already and cleaned up the army Corp has been by the house multiple times but haven't started in their cleanup. I realize there are 15,000 structures needing cleanup but I think more contractors should be brought in to assist.  As far as habitat restoration as critical as that is, getting the houses restored I think should be a higher priority. Restoring water should also be a very high priority.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need more contractors to speed up cleanup and home restoration. That should take priority over habitat restoration right now.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: During recovery regulations must be eased to allow for housing of affected people. Temporary housing will be essential for anyone that loses a home. ADUs can play a part, as well as RVs, FEMA style trailers, etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need looser regulations for temporary housing like ADUs, RVs, and FEMA trailers to quickly shelter displaced residents.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Allow RVs on property for a fixed period.  Don't create excessive government agencies for temporary issues.
LLM_SUMMARY: Let people live in RVs temporarily while rebuilding, without creating bureaucratic delays through new government oversight.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: All landscape must be completed to reduce the risk as much as possible. If an area is prone to fire, perhaps don't rebuild there?
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't rebuild in fire-prone areas. If rebuilding does occur, complete all landscaping first to reduce future fire risks.
LABEL: build back safer

CONTENT: Debris removal is going pretty quickly between private contractors and the ACE's federal efforts.  Soil and Water quality plus open space and habitat restoration are efforts where community members and local universities will jump (or are already jumping!) at the chance to be involved, so as to save the county having to hire more staff to handle it all and instead our tax dollars can remain focused on upping the budget for outsourcing of the permitting process.
LLM_SUMMARY: We can speed up rebuilding by using private contractors while letting community volunteers handle environmental restoration, saving money for faster permitting processes.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: You have the bury the power lines.
LLM_SUMMARY: Burying power lines is essential for safer rebuilding, even if it takes longer.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I’m so tired of having to use our county tax dollars to rebuild Malibu due to either fires, flooding, or high water damage. Regulations need to be into place whereby people cannot just be allowed to rebuild yet again, and have the rest of the county help them rebuild yet again. With climate change, it will continue to happen probably much more frequently. Let’s try to be proactive now in a positive way.
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't keep using tax dollars to repeatedly rebuild in high-risk areas. With climate change, we need proactive regulations limiting reconstruction in vulnerable locations.
LABEL: prevent rebuilding entirely

CONTENT: I think it's really important to consider where to rebuild, and where not to rebuild. My grandmother's home burned down, and everyone in her community wants to rebuild in the same place. But does it really make sense when we know that the Palisades Highlands is in an extremely high fire risk area? To the extent that folks want to rebuild in high risk areas, should the entire state of California shoulder that risk through our tax dollars and insurance payments?
LLM_SUMMARY: We shouldn't automatically rebuild in high-risk fire areas like Palisades Highlands. Why should all California taxpayers subsidize rebuilding in dangerous locations?
LABEL: rebuild with restrictions

CONTENT: Underground power lines!
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines would make rebuilding safer, but it takes longer and costs more.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Push insurance companies to simply pay out 100% on total losses, as we are all under insured anyhow.  This has occurred in prior fires, and we are desperately needing to rebuild sooner than later, so knowing a budget is key, and key now.
LLM_SUMMARY: Insurance should pay claims quickly and fully so we can start rebuilding immediately - we can't wait to figure out budgets.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Let's bury electrical lines (and internet and other wired infrastructure) underground, to avoid the wires being snapped and sparking in the regular wind storms we have.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground utilities would be safer but take longer to install. We need to weigh quick repairs against long-term safety improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Underinsurance and lack of insurance is obviously going to be a huge problem. Hopefully organizations will step up to offer options in terms of cheaper builds and getting creative for funding/grants to rebuild.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need creative funding and cheaper building options since many are underinsured, but this could impact rebuild quality and safety.
LABEL: build back cheaper

CONTENT: My own grandmother lost her home in the Palisades Fire, so this is hard to say. But if people decide to rebuild in the exact spot their house burned down, the financial risk of repeat fire should should be borne by communities who rebuild in high risk areas. Skyrocketing insurance rates should not be distributed throughout the state to areas that have very low risk of wildfire.
LLM_SUMMARY: People who choose to rebuild in high-risk burn areas should bear their own insurance costs, not spread the financial burden across low-risk communities.
LABEL: rebuild with restrictions

CONTENT: I strongly believe in shared responsibility. As much as people want to rebuild as quick as possible, it's everyone's responsibility to build back to prevent the next great disaster.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must balance quick rebuilding with responsible construction to prevent future disasters - it's our shared duty.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: In our rural area, we've discovered the hard way that key equipment for landlines, cable/internet and cell service often shares a power pole. Which means literally every means of communication most people have access to goes down at the same time if the fire takes out that ONE pole. There ought to be a mandate for undergrounding ALL of those services and separating them where undergrounding is not possible. A grant program to equip rural residents with satellite phones for emergency use would also help, as would establishing local emergency radio frequencies we could tune into for updates. Also, cell phones should be able to connect to ANY available tower for ALL CALLS (not just 911) and alerts (nixle, watch duty, etc) during emergencies.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need underground utilities and separated infrastructure instead of rushing to rebuild the same vulnerable systems that failed during fires.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
1.  Requirement for confirmation sampling after debris removal; 
2. City of LA DBS to apply existing residential standards of soil condition as a prerequisite of issuing building permits in the burn zone.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building permits in burn zones should require soil testing and meet residential standards before rebuilding can begin.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Town wide water pumps need to be separate from the main power so there continues to be water flowing despite power being turned off during high winds. Fix the lack of water during a fire.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need separate power systems for water pumps so we have water during fires, even when main power is shut off.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Require all electrical power lines to be undergrounded in the foothills and Altadena! SCE did a lousy job of protecting the residents along the foothills.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines in foothills for safety, even if it takes longer. SCE failed to protect residents with current infrastructure.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Edison should make underground system for Altadena.  It will be costly, but it is necessary.  We cannot make another town like second Altadena.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are costly but necessary - we can't risk building another Altadena without making these safety improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Rebuild to new codes and fire safe is not affordable. Even if you do rebuild to fire safety Insurance lies and does not insure regardless of how safe
LLM_SUMMARY: "Rebuilding to new fire-safe codes is unaffordable, and insurance companies won't cover you anyway, regardless of safety improvements."
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Please expedite permitting and waive the necessary fees
LLM_SUMMARY: We need faster permits and fee waivers to rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: The permit process needs to be improved
LLM_SUMMARY: We need a faster permit process.
LABEL: speed versus standards

CONTENT: Home owners should be able to use Natural gas. It's more reliable and affordable than all electric mandates. Not allowing apartments in single family areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need natural gas in our homes - it's more reliable and affordable than being forced to go all-electric.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: It would be nice if Altadena were rebuilt to be more walkable and accessible via bike and public transportation. Let's do this right!
LLM_SUMMARY: We should rebuild Altadena with better walkability, bike access, and public transit instead of rushing to restore it exactly as before.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Efforts to streamline the housing re-permitting process for fire victims should be expanded to include everyone else. By making this process more efficient we could increase the supply of housing, reducing cost.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should expand streamlined fire victim re-permitting to all housing permits to increase supply and reduce costs.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: Have all power lines put underground
LLM_SUMMARY: Power lines should be moved underground, even though it will take longer and cost more.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need to know that the state is prioritizing fire mitigation so that we can feel good about rebuilding in the same areas.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need assurance of improved fire mitigation before rebuilding in the same areas.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: We need to know that the soil and water is safe and not toxic if this community is going to exist long term. We need to preserve the value of the properties and attract new families to move to the area. We can't do that if there are concerns about toxicity.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must ensure soil and water safety before rebuilding. Property values and community growth depend on addressing toxicity concerns first.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Streetlights should be solar with small batteries, so there is no copper wire to be stolen. All housing should be built with no gas, we are supposed to be all electric in Los Angeles by 2035 anyway and in California by 2045 (per SB 100) so why invest in repairing gas infrastructure that will be obsolete/stranded assets soon and a source of ignition for fires after an earthquake or other natural disaster. It is also absurd that it is 2025 and we are still flushing our toilets and irrigating our yards with drinking water, if we are rebuilding, we should do so with greywater systems that reuse water from our sinks, showers and laundry  for watering landscapes and flushing.
LLM_SUMMARY: When rebuilding, we should upgrade to solar streetlights, all-electric homes, and greywater systems instead of reinstalling soon-to-be obsolete infrastructure that poses fire risks.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The state & many cities are planning for more growth & density, w/o paying attention to flood plains & fire prone areas. Even if the area is a "high opportunity area" if it's a flood plain per FEMA, it's highly irresponsible to put more people in the path of danger. We're now having more 100-year and 500-year storms and we must adapt to climate change, not ignore it. Same goes for tsunami zones, sea level rise & erosion, we should stop advocating for false solutions like sea walls & advocate for managed retreat instead. The city must have real community engagement and conduct drills so residents can be prepared for natural disasters. Language access is crucial, not only simple to understand, but translate messages to languages people speak.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must adapt to climate change, not build in flood plains and fire-prone areas. It's irresponsible to put more people in danger.
LABEL: restrict risky rebuilding

CONTENT: Consistency for One California is a must. My community of Paradise Ca had substantial costs with permits, surveys, septic, architect costs. Fleeced by our own town.
LLM_SUMMARY: We faced excessive permit fees and architectural costs to rebuild - our own town took advantage of us financially.
LABEL: build back faster

CONTENT: We must replant NATIVE plants that are by design much less flammable, like the California chaparral and stop cutting it down. Conversely, we must take down all palm trees down, not only they are giant match sticks when we get a wild fire, they provide little to no oxygen, they attract rodents and help the transmission of Leptospirosis, they provide little shade and now the department of sanitation wont take any of the debris from it as it takes a very long time to decompose, so that would go to a landfill to generate methane instead. We also need to consult with Native Tribes who are the original stewards of the land and used to have controlled fires to avoid having these mega fires. Private firefighters must be banned.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must replant native California chaparral and remove palm trees. Consult Native tribes about controlled burns, as they're the original land stewards.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Power lines under ground.  Increase # of reservoirs. Better placement of street lights. More pedestrians Xwalks with blinking lights and increase use of speed bumps to slow traffic down. Better use of right and left turn signals at intersection
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines and better infrastructure are needed, but these improvements will delay rebuilding efforts in fire-affected areas.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The new reimagined community should be better than the now-burned community.  Use smart planners and experts to implement new ideas for Palisades 2.0.
LLM_SUMMARY: We need expert planners to create a better, reimagined Palisades community instead of just rebuilding what burned.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Undergrounding powerlines should be done now, before roads are repaved.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground the power lines first, before repaving roads - it's the logical order for rebuilding safely.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Building codes need to be updated to reflect the reality of wild fires.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes must be modernized to address wildfire risks, even if it slows reconstruction.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: 6 of the 10 most costly fires in California have been caused by power lines. Its way overdue to put them underground. If Europe can do it, so can we.
LLM_SUMMARY: Underground power lines are needed - if Europe manages this safety measure, we can too, instead of rushing to rebuild the same way.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Too many laws and regs from too many layers of gov to make any real progress.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building codes and multi-agency regulations slow down post-fire rebuilding progress.
LABEL: regulations slow rebuilding

CONTENT: Use Strong Towns principles in the rebuilding process. Prioritize the lowest-income households first. Deprioritize owners with second-homes. Establish clear process and timelines for residents to gain access to aid. Do not bypass environmental concerns.
LLM_SUMMARY: Don't rush rebuilding - follow Strong Towns principles and environmental standards while prioritizing aid for low-income residents over second-home owners.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Expensive yet necessary.  Start in most fire prone areas and move outward.
LLM_SUMMARY: Building back better is expensive but necessary. We should prioritize improvements starting with the most fire-prone areas first.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Need to have realistic evacuation routes and communications given the densities of people or restrict building to reduce the density.  Mandatory training drills might be useful.
LLM_SUMMARY: Need realistic evacuation routes for population density, or limit new construction. Consider mandatory evacuation drills.
LABEL: restrict building density

CONTENT: Must clean before anything. Do clean-up at the neighborhood or at minimum at the block-level, not individual building site, to be more more efficient and cost effective. Require home owners and insurance companies to bundle efforts/$$.
LLM_SUMMARY: Clean up should be coordinated at neighborhood level instead of individual sites for efficiency, requiring homeowners and insurers to combine resources.
LABEL: bundle cleanup efforts

CONTENT: I would see this as an area where state and federal monies, along with $$$ from the utilities,  can be used to rebuild smartly.  Roads and sidewalks can be rethought to increase the probability of being able to leave in time.  Unsafe, above ground lines can be eliminated.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use government and utility company funds to rebuild strategically with better evacuation routes and underground power lines.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: The removal of potentially toxic and hazardous waste is a huge undertaking, and may be beyond what local government can do on their own.  It is also an opportunity to look at the balance of open space and building, and to restore at least some of the habitat that has been taking over by human.  Again, opportunity to build better.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use this cleanup phase to restore habitat and balance development with open space, not just rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: I don't know if I would classify it as a "theme," but I believe that using a disaster as a time to do better, to improve the situation, as well as addressing the immediate needs is important.  Coming to agreement on some of the "facts" is also important.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should use disasters as opportunities to improve while still addressing immediate needs, not just rebuild quickly.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT:
I prefer to stay focused on where we go from here, rather than debate why stuff didn't happen in the past. We know what we need to do (e.g, utility under-grounding, firebreaks, fire prevention, fire hardening when (re)building, etc.). It will cost money (private, government). We know we have not had basic* transparency in past on government action (including our IOU monopolies), so let's design that differently from hereon too, perhaps leveraging 311 that we already use. All this can be piloted/tested in LA, but needs to be designed for statewide rollout, adapted for situations elsewhere. 

*basic in sense of: clear, accessible, responsive, and timely to average citizen - not in terms of endless dense reports commissioned by CPUC etc.
LLM_SUMMARY: We know what's needed - utility undergrounding, firebreaks, prevention, and fire-hardened rebuilding. It'll cost money, but let's focus on implementing these improvements moving forwar
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Building and zoning laws should be reviewed annually, and updated as needed.  They need to reject the current needs.  We need to take into account all the science and facts at our disposal and then come up with collaborative changes to be made.  Everyone should be allowed to have a voice.
LLM_SUMMARY: We must update building codes based on current science and facts, not rush to rebuild without considering needed safety improvements.
LABEL: build back better

CONTENT: Change can be difficult.  I, too, love to have plants near and around my home, but if the reality of fire risk is there...it would be selfish to refuse.  The same applies to building materials.  While I would once have scoffed at the idea of stucco siding, I now look at this as potentially a safer alternative to all wood siding.  That may or may not be true, but if I were building from scratch, I would embrace all I could learn about fire resistant design, just as I look at accessible design needs.
LLM_SUMMARY: We should embrace fire-resistant building materials and designs when rebuilding, even if it means giving up traditional preferences like wood siding.
LABEL: embrace safer rebuilding
